quote: Why the Xepolites?
Because the Xepolites have often served as intermediaries for us in the past.
So have the Lissepians.
But the Xepolites have never been caught.
The Xepolite ship isn't responding to our hail, sir.
Of course they're not responding. Would you respond to a Federation hail if your cargo bays were full of Cardassian weapons?
Scan their ship, Major. Let's see what they're carrying.
Our scanners can't penetrate their hull.
No wonder. It's composed of a sensor reflective material. They obviously value their privacy.
Chief, you and Gul Dukat remain here. Major, you're with me. Let's go see if it's their privacy or their guilt they're trying to protect.
Sorry, Commander, but you can't transport over. They just raised their shields.
You're wasting time. Xepolite ships can reach a maximum speed of warp nine point eight. If they decide to run, we'll never catch them.
So what would you suggest?
I would breach their shields with my phasers and destroy their bridge.
Killing everyone there.
That's correct. Then I would lock onto the ship with my tractor beam and tow it and its cargo back to the station. Very simple. Very effective.
And needlessly bloody.
Sounds like a Cardassian plan to me.
Chief, fire a phaser across their bow. Let's see if we can't get their attention.
Yes, sir.
That woke them up. They're hailing us.
On my monitor, Chief.
I am Drofo Awa, Hetman of this vessel. What do you want from us?
I'm Commander Benjamin Sisko of the United Federation of Planets. We believe you're carrying Cardassian weapons to their colonies in the Demilitarized Zone.
Then you believe wrong, Commander. My ship is carrying five kilotons of Regreein wheat husks, nothing more.
Five kilotons. That's a lot of wheat husks. With your permission I'd like to come aboard and see what that looks like.
Permission denied. Any attempt to board my vessel will be considered an act of piracy. Is that clear?
Call it anything you like, but you're not going anywhere until we search your ship.
(on monitor, threatening tone) In that case, Commander...
In that case, you'll do exactly as you're told. You'll allow us free access to your ship, so that we can verify that you are indeed carrying Cardassian weapons into the Demilitarized Zone.

You will then follow us back to Deep Space Nine, where your cargo will be confiscated and you will make a full confession detailing everything you know about the smuggling of weapons into the Demilitarized Zone. You will then sign that confession, after which you and your ship will be allowed on your way. Is that clear.
I don't understand... you're a Cardassian.
I'm not just any Cardassian. I'm Gul Dukat, Commander of the Second Order. You have fifteen seconds to lower your shields or we'll destroy your ship.
No... wait.
Ten seconds.
It's not that simple.
Seven seconds.
I've already been paid.
Four seconds.
Stop counting... stop counting.
He's lowering his shields.
(on monitor, a defeated man) I'll await your arrival, Commander.
I think you can take over from here.
I hope you're happy.
I am a Vulcan. My emotional state is irrelevant.
Well I'm a Ferengi. And my emotional state is very relevant. And right now, I'm miserable. And it's all your fault.
You were well paid for your assistance.
Not well enough. Look, why don't you just tell them what they want to know?

(continuing, talking confidentially) I know the Cardassians can't be trusted. I know that the Central Command would like nothing better than to destroy the Federation colonies in the Demilitarized Zone.
Then you agree with our position?
Not for a second.
Why not?
Because your position is... (searching for the right word) Illogical.
Do you propose to lecture me on logic?
I don't want to, but you leave me no choice. It all comes down to the third Rule of Acquisition. You don't know that one, do you?
I am not well versed in Ferengi philosophy.
Remind me to get you a copy of the Rules. You never know when they'll come in handy. Now, the third rule clearly states, "Never pay more for an acquisition than you have to."
Logical. But I fail to see how that applies to my situation.
You want to acquire peace. Fine. Peace is good. But how much are you willing to pay for it?
Whatever it costs.

That's the kind of irresponsible spending that causes so many business ventures to fail. You're forgetting the third rule. Right now peace could be bought at a bargain price and you don't even realize it.
I find this very confusing.

Then I'll make it so simple that even a Vulcan can understand. The Central Command has been caught red- handed smuggling weapons to their settlers. So from now on, every ship approaching the Demilitarized Zone will be searched. Without the support of the Central Command, the Cardassian settlers won't be so eager to fight.
You forget the weapons they already have.

They have weapons... you have weapons... everyone has weapons. But right now, no one has a clear advantage. So the price of peace is at an all-time low. This is the perfect time to sit down and hammer out an agreement. Don't you get it... attacking the Cardassians now will only escalate the conflict and make peace more expensive in the long run. Now I ask you, is that logical?
A concealed weapons depot located within a civilian population center?
According to Sakonna, the Maquis are going to attack the depot sometime within the next fifty-two hours.
But she didn't tell you on which colony the depot's hidden?
She says she doesn't know.
How convenient.
I believe her.
Why? Because Vulcans don't lie?
As a rule, they don't.
They don't blow up ships either... as a rule. But let's assume she is telling the truth. I trust you haven't shared this information with the Central Command?
No. I haven't.
Good. Because they would never trust you to handle this matter alone.
But they would be able to tell me where the depot is located.
Leave that to me. I may no longer be a favorite with the Central Command, but I know people who are.
In the meantime, I'll go to Volan Three. See if I can talk some sense into the Maquis.
And if you can't?
Don't worry, Dukat. I told you I'd stop them. And one way or another, I will.
I've also been recently informed that thirty-five people had to be hospitalized on Umoth Eight after eating from public food replicators. Sabotage is suspected.
From now on, guards should be posted at all public replicators throughout the colonies.
Now... about the new curfew.
(not pleased at the interruption) Commander Sisko, what a pleasant surprise. If you'll just wait a moment or two, I'll finish up this meeting and we can talk privately.

That won't be necessary. I want everyone to hear what I have to say. I don't know how many of you here actually belong to the Maquis. Those of you who don't probably have friends who do. So please make sure you pass along what I'm about to tell you. There is a treaty currently in place between Cardassia and the Federation. If you make yourself the enemy of Cardassia, you'll make yourself the enemy of the Federation.
Now I know the Maquis plan on attacking a Cardassian weapons depot. My advice to them... to you... is to call it off. Because I'll be waiting there. And I'll stop you.
A very rousing speech, Ben. I suppose my best rebuttal would be to kill you.
But you won't.
What's this?
Your uniform.
You always were an optimist.

I have reason to be. The way I see it, now that we've stopped the shipments of Cardassian weapons, there's no longer any need for the Maquis. You and I can work together to reach a peace agreement with the Cardassian colonies.
It's too late for that. We're in a war here. And I intend to win it.
I could use your help, Ben. I'm asking you as a friend.
And as a friend, I have to say no. If you attack that depot, you're going to have to get through me first.
I hope not. I truly hope not.
The Bryma Colony. According to my sources, that's the location of the weapons depot.
Then our objective is simple -- prevent the Maquis ships from reaching Bryma.
We're going to have to intercept them before they're picked up by the colony's sensors.
Good point. If the Cardassian colonists even suspect they're about to come under attack, they'll send a message to Cardassia asking for reinforcements.
I don't care how much the Cardassians care about the treaty. If the Maquis launch an assault against a civilian target, the Central Command will have to respond.
We could wind up with a full scale war on our hands. We have to stop the Maquis. Our runabouts will take up a defensive position just outside Bryma colony's sensor range.
The best way to detect incoming ships would be to hide a couple of dozen sensor probes in the system's Oort Cloud.
That way, we'll be able to spot the Maquis no matter what route they take.
How many Maquis ships are we expecting?
According to Sakonna, they only have two ships capable of mounting the weapons she purchased.
So we'll have three ships and they'll have two. The odds are in our favor, anyway.
Don't expect that to give us much of an advantage, Julian. The colonists are used to being outnumbered. They'll fight just that much harder.
How do you propose to stop them?
(before Sisko can answer) What's that human expression? "Shoot to kill."
We'll stop them with words if possible... with force if necessary.
So if they fire at us, we have orders to shoot back?
That's correct. We'll target their warp engines and weapons arrays, try to disable them.
How noble. I hope the Maquis will be as obliging to you.
I've known Cal Hudson a long time. I doubt he would harm Federation citizens.
A week ago, you'd never've believed he was capable of joining the Maquis.
Rio Grande to Mekong and Orinoco. How do you read me?
Orinoco here. You're loud and clear.
Mekong here. Our communications channel is fully operational and secure. The remote sensor probes I set up still haven't detected any sign of the Maquis ships.
Do you really think they're coming? I mean, they know we're waiting for them.
It is possible they changed the time frame of their attack. Postponed it for a day, or a week.
They'll be here. The longer they wait, the greater the chance that the weapons depot will be moved to another location.

I remember one night on Pelios Station. Curzon convinced Benjamin and Cal to challenge two Zakdorns to a game of Dom-Jot. Seven hours later they still hadn't won a single game. That's when Curzon admitted he had been betting on the Zakdorns all along. Those were good times.
I'm picking up two Federation ships headed our way.
Sisko to Hudson. It's not going to work, Cal. Turn those ships around before someone gets hurt.
I was going to say the same thing to you.
Please, Ben. Don't make me open fire on you.
He's not going to listen.
Initiating evasive maneuvers. Signal Niles to follow my lead.
Commander, they're making a run for it.
Lock on tractor beams.
Dammit.
They've got Niles, too.
Let us go, Ben.
You know I can't do that.
Then I suggest you duck. Fire on their beam emitter.
What are you waiting for?
We're losing tractor lock.
They're breaking away.
Commence firing.
Niles's propulsion system is down. He's drifting.
We'll have to even the odds.
They hit our navigation array. I've lost attitude control. Attempting to compensate with manual thrusters.
It's not working. Thrusters are still locked.
Hang on. Chief, you go after the Orinoco. I'll handle Hudson.
Right. Major, lower your shields. We'll beam you out of there.
They're coming back around.
It's just you and me, Ben.
I can't let you start a war.
I'm not turning back.
And you're not going forward.
We're hit... our photon torpedo tubes are out.
Switch to phasers and come about. Heading one-one-five mark two-three- six.
We've taken a direct hit on our primary fusion core.
Initiating emergency core shutdown.
The port nacelle is flooded with ionized deuterium. We've lost warp and impulse engines.
We still have maneuvering thrusters.
They're coming back around. Use your phasers.
I can't. They've knocked out the power couplings to our weapons array.
What do we do?
The only thing we can do. Get the hell out of here.
He's turning away. Now's your chance. Fire.
It's over, Cal.
For now, anyway. Next time tell Starfleet to send someone else. Doesn't feel right, us shooting at one another.
There won't be a next time. Stand down.
I don't think so.
(checking panel; anger rising) He's getting away.
You run now and I won't be able to protect you. Starfleet'll track you down. You won't be safe anywhere, even in the colonies.
Don't be so sure. I have a lot of friends here, Ben. Besides, I have to help the Maquis finish this thing.
But you'll be an outlaw. A hunted man. You're throwing away your entire life.
And starting a new one.
What are you waiting for? He's helpless. Finish him.
I'll miss you, Ben. You've been a good friend.
So have you.
No...
I thought you were strong, Commander. But you're not. You're a fool. A sentimental fool.
I said I'd stop the Maquis and I have. But I won't kill a good man for trying to defend his home.
You disappoint me, Commander.
Don't expect me to lose any sleep over it.
Mister O'Brien, when you have a moment, I could use your help with these engines.
Yes, sir.
Commander, Gul Dukat has left the station.
I'm sure he's glad to be going home.
Chief O'Brien says the Orinoco and Rio Grande will be up and running in a few days.
Thank you, Major.
I just got a communique from Starfleet congratulating me on my good work and thanking me for preserving the peace with the Cardassians.
You deserve it. You prevented a war.
Did I? Or did I just delay the inevitable?
Kira, we've got six Byzatium transports coming in this afternoon. I've got to have more cargo space.
All right... have them offload into Cargo Bays three and four, but that's it. We're pushing our storage capacity as it is.
Oh, that reminds me... we got a message last night saying the Byzallians want to move up their conference by a week.
I haven't had a chance to read through last night's reports... anything else I should know?
Well...
What?
Starfleet wants a complete report done on our computer calibration subroutine.
The whole subroutine? When?
Tomorrow.

Someone -- probably a certain bartender we know -- has been using a public terminal to falsify inventory records and cargo manifests on the last three Ferengi transport ships that were here. In other words, we have no idea what they've been shipping in and out of this station for the past month.
That means we've got to open every single Ferengi container on the station.
We have another problem as well... the Tholian Ambassador reported that someone broke into his quarters during the night and stole three cases of latinum.
Three cases?
It was the dowry for his wedding.
When's the wedding?
Tomorrow.
Major, the scheduled transport's been delayed and I need those medical supplies by the end of the week at the latest.
We can't spare a runabout to go all the way to Vulcan right now.
I'm supposed to set up a field hospital for the new colony on Campor Three next week. If I don't have those supplies, it could set the entire colonization schedule back by at least --

Listen to me. You can't have a runabout, you can't get your medical supplies, and I don't give a damn about the colonization schedule. We've got problems of our own, so those colonists can make do with a box of bandages for all I care.
Stop right there, Major.
When was your last day off?
I don't know. What does that have to do with--
If you can't remember, it's been too long. You're off duty as of this moment.
What do you mean, I'm off duty? You can't do that.
Oh, yes I can. And not even Commander Sisko can overrule my judgement as chief medical officer.
Wait a minute, Julian... just because I snapped at you isn't enough to--
My diagnosis is that you're overworked and suffering from extreme stress and borderline exhaustion. As for my prescription... come with me.
Karvino juice... Lorvan crackers... a holosuite program... a jumja stick... and gambling tokens.
Now, at least two of these items must be used and fully enjoyed before you can leave this facility.
Julian...
I'll be giving you a full report on her activities, Doctor.
If I hear you didn't relax and have a good time tonight, we'll do this every night until you do. Have fun.
Looks like you've got your evening all planned out.
I hope you left room for... the unexpected.
Welcome aboard, Commander.
Thank you. And call me Wil.
What brings you to Deep Space Nine?
Strictly pleasure. I've built up about three months worth of leave and Doctor Crusher finally insisted that I take some of it. In fact, she nearly shoved me out the airlock.
D.S. Nine isn't exactly known as a vacation getaway.

I'm actually just passing through on my way to Risa. The last time I was here, I only got to spend two hours at Quark's... but by the time I left, I had all his latinum and a date with one of his dabo girls. I thought I might try my luck again.
Be careful... Quark's dabo wheel has been a little stingy recently. And one of his Dabo girls is dating my son.
In that case, maybe I better spend my time in the holosuites. It sounds safer... all the way around.

Is there anything I can do for you while you're here? A look around the station... maybe a tour of the Defiant? Chief O'Brien's working on her polaron deflector this morning... I'm sure he'd love to show you around.
Thanks... but to be honest, the last thing I want to do on my vacation is look at polaron deflectors.
I can't say that I blame you.
Now... which Dabo girl is your son dating... just to be on the safe side?
Who's in there?
What?
Who's in with Benjamin?
Oh... it's Wil -- Commander Wil Riker from the Enterprise.
Wil Riker...
You know him?
Met him at Quark's about a year ago. Quite a dabo player. Do you know him?
Yes... a little. We met at Quark's... last night.
You met... last night... and...
And we talked.
And then...
And then nothing. We just talked. For three hours.
We... just... talked. And yes, he's a very warm... very charming man... but I'm involved with someone.
Of course. So why do you keep glancing at Sisko's office?
If you can find the time, you have an open invitation for dinner with Jake and me.
I just might take you up on that.
I hope you're not here for another loan.
Don't tell me you've forgotten who staked you three strips of latinum when your winning streak ran dry?
Oh, my God... of course. Sorry... most of that night is still a blur. How are you, Dax?
Fine.
Major.
Commander.
Well. I better get out of your way and let you get back to work. I hope I see you all again soon.
Oops. Sorry about that.
It's all right.
My mind was a million light years away. Should've been paying attention to where I was going.
So... doing some shopping?
I'm just exploring the Promenade actually. I thought about heading over to Quark's, but... I wasn't really in the mood. Where're you off to?
I'm just... coming off duty. I was about to call it a night.
I see. Well... good night.
Would you... like a tour of the station... ?
I'd love one. Where should we begin?
Well, we could walk along the Promenade for a start. There's quite a bit to see here.
You think we'll have a chance to take a look at that new starship of yours? What's it called... ?
The Defiant.
Yeah, the Defiant. I hear it's quite a vessel.
I'm sure we could arrange that.
Please identify for access to USS Defiant.
Major Kira Nerys, Bajoran militia.
Identity confirmed.
Commander William Riker, Starfleet.
Identity confirmed.
Chief. I didn't know there was anyone aboard tonight.
I hadn't planned to... just putting in a little extra work on the deflector targeting arrays.
Commander. I heard you were aboard, but I hadn't--
I have nothing to say to you, Chief. And I think you know why.
Maybe we should come back another time.
No... no, that's all right, Major. I was just leaving. Commander.
What was that all about?
It's a long story. And I'd rather not get into it right now.
Well, let's have a look at this ship of yours.
Okay. I'll show you the tactical systems first.
I think you're going to be surprised at how big a punch this little ship has...
Running the plasma conduit through the primary phaser coupling has almost doubled your phaser power. But doesn't that reduce warp drive efficiency?
Not at all. In fact, it's thirty percent more efficient.
That's ingenious. I want to see how this is all routed through the tactical display.
Command authorization required.
It's a new security procedure. Computer, release Bridge lockout -- authorization Kira delta five-four- seven alpha.
Thank you.
What's going on?
I'm not sure... but something's happened to the warp core on the Defiant. It looks like it's going to breach in about sixty seconds.
Is anyone on board?
O'Brien was working there this morning. But I don't know if he--
Incoming signal from the Defiant. It's Commander Riker.
On screen.
We'll beam the two of you away as soon as you're clear.
Docking clamps released.
Okay... I'm engaging thrusters...
Fifteen seconds.
Lock on and beam them out of there, Chief.
I can't get a lock. The Defiant's shields are up.
What?
She's gone into warp. I've lost them.
We're beyond their sensor range.
Set course for the Badlands. Warp seven.
Tamal, secure that conduit.
Course laid in. We'll be in the Badlands in six hours.
You did it, Tom.
Yeah... but it's not over yet.
Nine years ago, a transporter accident created two William T. Rikers... one of them returned to his ship, the other was marooned on Nervala Four.
The second Riker was finally discovered two years ago. He chose to use his middle name -- Thomas -- to distinguish himself from the other Riker.
The two men are physically identical in every respect -- right down to their DNA coding. There was no way for the security computer to know that it was Thomas, not William who boarded the Defiant.
A very entertaining story... but why am I listening to it?
We have reason to believe that Thomas Riker... is a member of the Maquis.
What?
Thomas Riker was serving aboard the starship Gandhi. While he was there, he began to express certain... political opinions... opinions that support the Maquis and their goals.
The Gandhi's captain said that Riker was adamantly opposed to stopping Maquis raids against Cardassian targets.

You're telling me that one of the most heavily armed warships in this quadrant is now in the hands of Maquis terrorists? Do you have any idea what kind of response this will provoke from the Central Command?
They'll probably want to send ships into the Demilitarized Zone to conduct a search. We understand that. But... any entry into the zone must be a joint operation between Cardassia and the Federation.
The Central Command won't be interested in any "joint operations," commander. They're not going to believe this story of yours about transporter duplicates and security failures.
They'll assume that Starfleet wanted the Maquis to have the Defiant... and they'll respond accordingly.
What does that mean, exactly?
It means they'll take this opportunity to finally eliminate the Maquis. They'll send a fleet into the zone with orders to search and destroy every last Maquis base as well as your missing starship.
Starfleet is willing to cooperate in a search for the Defiant... but they will not allow the Central Command to use this as an excuse for a full- scale invasion.

Of course not. So you'll send your own fleet into the zone to protect the Federation colonies... at some point the two fleets will meet... tensions will rise... nerves will fray... someone will make a mistake...
And we'll have a war on our hands.
It is a prospect that I do not relish.
Neither do we.
That's why we need to work together to prevent it from happening.

Unless I can bring something to the Central Command that will prove your good faith... and your willingness to help stop the Defiant... I don't believe that anything will prevent this conflict from beginning.

Then bring me with you. I can help you stop the Defiant and prove our good faith. I was in charge of the shipyard where the Defiant was built... I helped design it. I know her vulnerabilities... her weaknesses...
You'll help us destroy one of your own ships?
I want to try and disable it first.
I'm sure you would, but you're in no position to bargain. You want to prevent a war? Then come back to Cardassia with me and help me destroy the Defiant.
When do we leave?
I don't care who you are or what your name is.
Look, I'm sorry about lying to you, and about... using you. But it was an operational necessity.
You were a resistance fighter... you know that sometimes you have to do things that you're not proud of in order to accomplish the mission.
Well, you've accomplished your mission, so now what? Everyone's going to be looking for you -- the Cardassians and Starfleet. How far do you think you can get with this ship before they find you?
(with a confident smile) A lot farther than anyone anticipates.
Kalita to Riker. We've reached the rendezvous point.
On my way.
The other Maquis ships just arrived.
The rest of the team's ready.
Lower the shields and beam them aboard.
The Maquis ships are heading for the border, Tom.
All defense systems on-line and operational... warp power standing by.
Lay in a course for the Cardassian border. Warp eight.
Course already laid in.
This ship was built to fight... I think it's time she got her chance. Engage.

Commander's Log: Stardate 48467.3 Gul Dukat and I have arrived on Cardassia Prime. I am about to do something which goes against twenty years of Starfleet training: help an enemy hunt down one of our own ships.
This is where I will be conducting the search for the Defiant. From this room, I can control every Cardassian ship, outpost, and space station anywhere in...
Commander, allow me to introduce Korinas -- our "observer" from the Obsidian Order. Commander Sisko.
Korinas.
Welcome to Cardassia Prime, Commander.
Thank you.
Excuse me. Secure that console while the Human is here. Anything else classified as Level Four or above should also be secured.
I'm sure you can understand that although we all respect Gul Dukat's decision to bring you here... we must take some precautions.
Of course. I would've done the same. But then I would've been more discreet.

Since you're here to provide technical expertise on the Defiant, I suggest you begin briefing us on the ship's defensive capabilities. Please describe for us -- in detail -- the weapon systems of the Defiant, beginning with the ship's phaser array and --
Before we discuss weaponry... there is a more urgent matter that you should be aware of.
The Defiant's equipped with a cloaking device.
I wondered if you were going to share that little detail with us.
You knew about this?
The Obsidian Order has known for some time about the... "loan" of a cloaking device from the Romulans to the Federation.
And the Order chose not to share this intelligence with the Central Command?
Until now, the Order has not considered this one cloak to be a threat against Cardassia.

Under the terms of our agreement with the Romulans the cloaking device was to be used only in the Gamma Quadrant... and they only agreed to that in exchange for all our intelligence reports on the Dominion.
Well, your Lieutenant Riker isn't likely to respect that... agreement with the Romulans. And there's no known way to locate a ship under cloak.
There is one possibility. The Dominion managed to penetrate the cloak by using some kind of anti- proton beam.
Can you give us the specifications of that beam?
Not precisely, but I can give you what we learned from our sensor logs. It'll at least give you a chance to find the Defiant before she attacks.
Give him everything you know. I'll have the information transmitted to all units.
We're approaching the security perimeter, Tom.
All right... this is it. Cloak the ship. Stand by weapons.
Squadron Baker has arrived at their checkpoint.
Transmit the go-ahead signal.
We'll be in Cardassian sensor range in... five minutes.
There's a perimeter alert in the Almatha sector.
Put it on the main viewer.
Who's commanding the outpost nearest that ship?
Gul Toran of the Sixth Order. And he's identified the vessel... it's the Defiant.
Order all warships in that sector to converge on the Defiant.
Something's wrong... why wouldn't they be cloaked? Can you show me the sensor information on the Defiant?
The Defiant is attacking Outpost Sixty-one...
Tell Gul Toran that he has permission to pursue the Defiant into the Demilitarized Zone.
No, don't pull your ships off the border.
Commander, you don't expect me to give up pursuit of the Defiant just because the treaty --

That's not the Defiant. It's a decoy... they're trying to draw your patrol ships out of position. (points to console screen) That ship's sending out a fake warp signature identical to the Defiant, but the phase variance and subspace harmonics don't match.
Order Toran to break off pursuit. Have him redeploy his--
Sir -- another perimeter alert! Outpost Forty-seven has detected a cloaked ship with their anti-proton beam!
Tell Toran to head for Outpost forty- seven!
The Defiant has decloaked and begun to attack the outpost.
We've lost contact with Outpost Forty- seven.
Incoming message from Gul Toran.
The Defiant has recloaked... it's last know heading was... one four eight, mark two one five.
Directly into the heart of Cardassian territory.
Commander Sisko, you should be commended. I only wish we had someone with such keen tactical instincts who could've prevented this... invasion of our territory.
We're past the security perimeter... out of their sensor range.
They were using anti-proton beams to scan for us... We'll have to adjust the cloak's resonance frequency so they can't detect us again.
Right.
Damage report.
We took six hits on the port shields... there's been some minor damage to the outer hull... but all systems are operational.
Tough little ship. Set course for the shipyard at Omekla Three. We'll let that be --
Report.
We've lost main power... and the cloak is off-line.
It looks like two plasma conduits blew out.
Where?
Deck three... section fifteen. Crew quarters.
It looks like Major Kira's been busy.
You crossed the replicator power converter with the plasma manifold, I take it?
That's right.
Nice work. You realize we'll have this bypassed in thirty minutes.
At least you'll be visible for thirty minutes.
Fortunately, I was able to move us into a nebula. No one's going to see us.
Thanks.
You're lucky you only got a little singed. That whole plasma relay could've exploded.
That was the idea.
You spent most of your life fighting the Cardassians. I know you sympathize with what we're trying to do here.
I fought the Cardassians because they invaded my home. You don't live in the Demilitarized Zone... you don't have any family there... why are you in this fight?
People are dying in the Demilitarized Zone and Starfleet isn't doing a thing about it.
Taking the Defiant just raises the stakes. The Cardassians are going to send a fleet after you... and they're going to kill more people hunting you down than they did in those border raids.
You're assuming the Defiant will stay in the Demilitarized Zone.
Let's go to the bridge.
I think we'd all feel better having you someplace where we can keep an eye on you.
Fifteen outposts have checked in... no sign of the Defiant. Twenty-six warships have scanned fourteen cubic light years of space with anti-proton beams... no Defiant.

What are the possibilities? They're still under cloak and heading deeper into Cardassian territory. They're laying low and waiting for some unknown reason. Or they've encountered some kind of problem...
Dukat, are you listening to me?
I'm sorry Commander. I was thinking about my son's birthday.
What?

(still staring at console) This is my son's eleventh birthday. I'd promised to take him to the amusement center in Lakarian City. He's always wanted to go and I've never had the time. I told him, this year will be different... this year I'll make the time.
I've had the same experience with Jake. They never understand... all we can do is hope that one day when they're older, they'll look back and say, "Now I understand... now I know why he did that."

When my son looks back on this day, the only thing he'll remember is that a Federation officer on a Federation ship invaded his home... and kept his father away from him on his eleventh birthday. And he won't look back with forgiveness... he'll look back with hatred.

The cloak is operating within normal parameters... but the plasma conduit damage has caused a slight neutrino leak in the port nacelle. The Cardassians might be able to detect it even through the cloak.
A chance we'll have to take. Lay in a course for Omekla Three and engage at warp eight.
Warp eight, aye.
Omekla Three? You're heading for the shipyard? There're at least half a dozen better targets in this sector alone.
I hope the Cardassians have the same reaction -- "What's he doing and why?"
All right, so you're trying to keep them off-balance... keep them guessing. Why?

The Maquis have been hearing rumors about shifting loyalties within the Cardassian government. Certain hardline elements were "unsatisfied" with the Federation Treaty and are looking for a way to scrap it.
We got our hands on an intelligence report outlining a suspected military buildup in the Orias System. A secret buildup that even the Central Command is unaware of.
Are you telling me that you've done all this to attack a secret base that may or may not exist?
I'm convinced it does. They're building an invasion fleet... and if we let them finish it, these... "renegade" Cardassians are going to use it.
You're really not cut out for this are you? Being a terrorist, I mean. You're not very good at it.
Really?
That's right. You're still acting like a Starfleet officer who's more worried about intelligence reports and Cardassian politics than about actually hurting the Cardassians.
You have one of the most powerful ships in this quadrant under your command. Why aren't you out destroying every Cardassian outpost along the border?
Because the stakes here are far greater than border outposts.

Not for the Maquis there're not. That's because the Maquis are a group of terrorists and all terrorists care about is destroying their enemy. I know... because I was a terrorist. And if I had this ship in those days, I would've destroyed Deep Space Nine... I would've hit the Cardassians so hard that they would have screamed for peace... but I wouldn't have gone flying off into the heart of Cardassia on some wild goose chase.
Maybe we're just different kinds of terrorists.
No, you're trying to be a hero... and terrorists don't get to be heroes.
We'll see.
So far, the Defiant has attacked a shipyard in Omekla Three... a weapons depot in the Dameron System... and a communications relay on the Rokat colony.
The Central Command is starting to wonder if you're ever going to stop them. Frankly, I am too.
That's it. That's where they're going.
Watch. This is the deployment of your ships before the Defiant's first attack.
And this is where they are now...
Don't you see what's happened? Each Defiant attack has been designed to draw your ships away from... (he points to a certain point on the display) ... this sector, leaving it virtually defenseless.
But there's nothing of value in that sector.
There must be something. Are there any Class-M planets there?
There's one. Orias Three. It's uninhabited... desolate.
I don't know... everything seems to point to the Orias System. It might be worth sending at least one warship there just in case the Defiant does show up.
All right. Contact Gul Ranor and tell him to dispatch one warship to the--
No.
You'll send no ships to the Orias system.
You're an observer here. You have no authority to --
That sector is under direct control of the Obsidian Order and you will not enter it.
Why?
The matter is classified.
You can file a protest with the Central Command later. Open a channel to Gul Ranor and--
Any warship sent into the Orias system will be destroyed.
Are you saying that you will... fire on another Cardassian ship?
What I'm saying is that the Obsidian Order will take whatever steps are necessary to protect the Orias system. And so will I.
I've spoken to a few... friends in the Central Command. The Obsidian Order isn't giving them any answers either.
The Order has to answer to someone, don't they?
In theory, they answer to the political authority of the Detapa Council just as the military does. In practice... we both run our own affairs.
Not the most efficient system.
It's worked for over five centuries.
Gul Dukat... there's an incoming message from the warship Kraxon. They say they've found an unusual neutrino signature in their sector... it looks like radiation from a damaged warp plasma relay.
Is this... signature moving?
No. But they're scanning the area with anti-proton beams.
Where is the Kraxon?
If it is the Defiant, they're in position to make a run for the Orias system.
We still don't know that Orias is the target. Until we do, I can't risk pulling ships away from other potential targets to chase a... neutrino signature.
They're coming around for another pass.
Are there any other ships nearby?
There are nine Galor-class cruisers about six light years away bearing one eight seven mark zero three five.
Any ships between us and the Orias system?
No.

If you make a run for it, that ship out there is going to see our neutrino signature go through a phase shift... and then they're going to call their nine friends... and you're going to have a small fleet chasing you all the way to Orias.
They can chase me all they want... as long as they don't catch me.
Sir -- the Kraxon reports that the neutrino signature has just phase- shifted... it's now moving at warp speed directly for the Orias system.
Order the Kraxon to pursue at maximum warp and order all other ships in the sector to follow.
The Kraxon is pursuing... but they won't catch us before we reach Orias.
The Orias system is within sensor range.
Full scan... I want to see everything that's in that system.
When you make out your report for the Obsidian Order... be sure to mention the fact that I could've prevented the Defiant from reaching Orias... if you hadn't interfered.
They'll never make it to Orias. You can count on that.
Three more ships have just appeared in the Orias system!
What kind of ships?
Cardassian warships... Keldon Class.
Whose ships are those?
Why are you asking me?
Because if they were military ships, I would know about them. So that leaves the Obsidian Order.
I thought the Obsidian Order didn't have any ships.
(keeping his eyes on Korinas) They're not supposed to. In fact, they're explicitly forbidden to have military equipment of any kind.
It looks like we're going to have to fight our way to Orias.
Listen to me. Those three ships up ahead will lock on to our neutrino leak and open fire... that means you'll have to fight back.
With this ship, it'll be a short fight, I can promise you that.

Let's say you can disable or even destroy those three ships ahead of us. But fighting them at all is going to slow us down and then those ten ships back there will catch up to us. And even the Defiant can't win against those odds.
We've come too far to quit now.
You're an experienced Starfleet officer. Analyze the situation, Tom.
Going to Orias is suicide... the smart move is to make a run for it while we still can.
Maybe that's what... "an experienced Starfleet officer" would do... maybe that's what Wil Riker would do... but that's not what I'm going to do. I'm going to continue the mission.

It's not the mission you're thinking about... or even the colonists in the zone... this is all about you isn't it? Or should I say it's about you and that other Wil Riker out there... that other man with your face, your name, and your career. You're looking for some way to set yourself apart from him... some way to be different.
You shouldn't go fishing today... you won't catch anything. Take us in.

Dukat... you want to know what's going on in the Orias system... I know how you can find out. Give Riker the chance to surrender. The Defiant's scanned the Orias system by now... its sensor logs can tell you everything you want to know.
I'd be happy to accept his surrender... but I doubt he'll want to hand over his logs.
He will if you agree to turn the ship and his crew over to the Federation.
Impossible. I cannot let a group of terrorists just... walk away after invading our territory and --
Then you should decide which is more important -- your sense of... ... "Cardassian justice" or the information contained in the Defiant's sensor logs.
I do want that information, Commander. And I am willing to return your... wayward ship. But someone will have to pay for what's happened... and I don't want that someone to be me.
If you return the Maquis to the Federation, I can promise you they will stand trial for what they've done.
A Federation trial...
It's the best I can do.

I would be willing to hand over the Maquis and the ship... but not Riker. He led the mission... if I can bring him to justice, and obtain information on Orias, that might be enough for the Central Command.

I might be able to get him to agree to that... on one condition. We both know that Cardassian sentences are determined well in advance of the trial. I'd like you to arrange for a sentence other than death.
I'll have to clear it with the Ministry of Justice.
You'd better make it quick.
Go to impulse, decloak the ship, raise shields and stand by phasers.
Come to heading one one eight, mark three zero one, lock phasers, and fire.
Direct hit on the cruiser's port nacelle... their shields are down by thirty percent.
We've been hit on our starboard shield...
Shields holding.
Quantum torpedoes... full spread.
Torpedoes locked.
Fire.
Their defense systems are off-line and they've lost main power.
Tom... three more cruisers have just appeared in the Orias system. That makes five ships ahead of us... and ten behind.
Resume our original course to Orias... stand by emergency power to the shields and --
Incoming message... from Cardassia Prime... ... it's Gul Dukat and Commander Sisko.
On screen.
This is Gul Dukat of the Second Order... I am authorized to tell you that if you will surrender your ship... none of you will be harmed.
Is that right...
Listen to him, Lieutenant... if you surrender, the Defiant and your crew will be handed over to a Federation starship at the Cardassian border.
Why the sudden generosity?
He wants the Defiant's sensor logs on the Orias system. And they're worth a lot more to him than Maquis prisoners.
I don't buy it. The Cardassians aren't going to let us just walk away.
You're right. Someone has to pay the price.
Me...
The deal is -- you're tried and convicted in a Cardassian court. And then sentenced to spend the rest of your life in the Lazon Two labor camp.
No death sentence, huh? That must have taken some doing.
Some.
Tom, there's no reason for you to continue... they're giving you a way out. The only reason not to take it... would be that you want to die.
I came here to complete a mission.
That mission is over, Tom. You'll never make it to Orias... you know that. There may be five ships ahead of you now... but there might be fifty waiting there for all we know.
Be a Starfleet officer one last time and think of your crew. You may want Tom Riker to go out in a blaze of glory that they'll talk about for the next ten years... but don't drag them along with you.
I accept your terms.
You'll need to reverse course and surrender the Defiant to one of the ships that've been following you.
Why?
It'll take too long to explain. But the ships coming out of the Orias system are not under Dukat's control.
I've ordered the Kraxon to put her shields around you as soon as you arrive. You'll be safe once you get there.
Understood.
Bring us about. Lay in a course to the Kraxon.
Do it.
Those are faster than any Keldon class ships I've ever seen. What's going on in that system?
We're one hundred million kilometers from the Kraxon.
Incoming message...
Let's hear it.
This is Gul Ranor of the Kraxon. Cut your engines in five seconds, and we'll extend our shields around you.
Acknowledged. Kalita?
All stop...
They won't fire on another Cardassian ship. They can't.
They're moving off... they've set course back to the Orias System.
Transmit the Orias Three sensor logs to the Kraxon. And tell them... to prepare to beam me aboard.
I'm turning command over to Major Kira... she'll get you back to the Federation. I'm holding you personally responsible to see to it that they all receive a fair trial.
You have my word on it.
We'll get you out of there somehow, Tom. I promise you that.
Riker to Kraxon. One to beam aboard.
Set course for the Federation. Warp eight.
Have a seat, Jake. Dinner's almost ready.
Let me guess, you convinced the Peljenites to exchange ambassadors with the Federation.
How did you know that?
You're cooking chicken paprikash. You only cook Hungarian food when you're in a really good mood.
I always said you were a smart kid.
Runs in the family.
You know, I've got some good news, too. Captain Yates is back on the station.
Kasidy Yates. The freighter captain I told you about.
The one you want me to meet?
I really think you'd like her.
Maybe I'll run into her.
I could invite her over for dinner. How about tomorrow night?
You're not going to give up on this, are you?
Is nineteen hundred hours okay?
I think we're getting a little ahead of ourselves here. (before Jake can protest) Look, Jake I know you want me to meet her, and I will. Just let me handle it my way.
You're going to like her, Dad.
You never know.
The place is packed. Where's Nog?
I gave him the night off.
You what?
He's studying. For his Starfleet exams. He's a very dedicated student.
He's a disgrace to his family... and to Ferengi everywhere. He should be here, helping us earn profit, not in his room, learning how to be more like a... Human.
He doesn't want to be Human, Brother. He just wants to join Starfleet.
It's the same thing.

Don't you see? This is how it begins. All it takes is for one impressionable youngster to join Starfleet, and the next thing you know, a whole generation of Ferengi will be quoting the Prime Directive and abandoning the pursuit of latinum. It's the end of Ferengi civilization as we know it and it's all your fault.
Relax, brother. Nog isn't going to destroy the Ferengi way of life. He just wants a job with better hours.
You must be Quark.
That's me. What can I do for you?
Brunt. F.C.A.
The Ferengi Commerce Authority.
A Writ of Accountability.
We're in trouble.
All right, everyone. The bar is closed. Everybody out. Go, go, go. Now, now, now.
So, how do you get to be an F.C.A. liquidator anyway?
(concentrating on his work) Hard work, bribes, and sucking up to the boss. Just like any other job.
You've had a very profitable year, haven't you?
(simultaneous (simultaneous with Rom) with Quark) No. Yes.
(simultaneous (simultaneous with Rom) with Quark) Yes. No.
What we mean is, it's been a profitable year, but not as profitable as others. You know how it is...
... with the Dominion and the Maquis, people just don't like to travel anymore.
Are these all your assets?
Down to the last slip of latinum.
You realize that concealing financial information from the F.C.A. can result in severe fines?
I would never dream of trying to hide anything from the F.C.A.
We'll see.
Could I look over those figures again?
Wait a minute. That can't be right.
Rom, you forgot to include the profit figures for the tulaberry wine franchise.
But you told me...
Go get them. Now.
Yes, Brother.
You'll have to excuse Rom. He means well, but he can be a lobeless idiot sometimes.
Please provide a dermal imprint for F.C.A. records.
You haven't even told me what I'm being charged with.
No. I haven't.
Oh... How rude of me.
For your trouble.
You're charged with violating the Ferengi Trade Bylaws... subsection one thousand twenty-seven, paragraph three.
Subsection one thousand twenty-seven, paragraph three? I'm not sure I'm familiar with that one.
In that case what you need is a copy of the Bylaws.
Which you just happen to have.
Subsection one thousand twenty-seven, paragraph three. Improper supervision of a family member?
That's correct.
I knew it. This is about Nog, isn't it?
Nog? Nog hasn't done anything wrong.

You see what I'm up against? I know that as the eldest male I'm responsible for the actions taken by members of my family. But what am I supposed to do? I told Rom not to let the boy apply to Starfleet Academy, but he wouldn't lift a finger to stop him.
Your nephew is going to Starfleet Academy?
Did I say that?
You're clearly incapable of controlling your family.
If this isn't about Nog, then why have I been served with a Writ?
You are being held accountable for the criminal activities of one Ishka, daughter of Adred, wife of Keldar.
Ishka? You mean... Our mother? What's she done?
She's charged with... earning profit.
Earning profit? Our Moogie?
Odo, I'm holding you personally responsible for the safety of my bar and personal possessions for as long as I'm off the station. And make sure my thieving brother doesn't touch anything.
Going somewhere?
Back to the homeworld to take care of some business.
A little trouble with the F.C.A.?
How'd you know?
I won't be gone long. All I have to do is get my mother to confess to her crimes and I'll be on the next transport back to the station.
Your mother? What's she done?
It doesn't matter. The important thing is I'm required by law to get her to admit her wrongdoing, make reparations and reveal her accomplices. And that's what I'm going to do.
Assuming she cooperates.
She'd better. I have no intention of spending my latinum to make restitution for her crimes. I'll wring that confession out of her if I have to.
(surprised at Quark's vehemence) This is your mother you're talking about.
Don't remind me.
Chief O'Brien wants to know when you can stop by and inspect the new runabout.
I'll be available at fourteen hundred hours. And tell him I want to name it the Rubicon.
The Rubicon it is. You know, at the rate we go through runabouts, it's a good thing the Earth has a lot of rivers.
So, have you met her yet?
Met who?
Captain Yates.
How do you know about her?
Jake introduced us. So are you going to ask her to dinner?
I'm considering it. What did you think of her?
Let me put it this way, if I was Curzon, I'd have stolen her from you already.
Which is one of the reasons I'm glad you're not Curzon anymore.
Brother, wait.
I'm coming with you.
No, you're not.
Yes, I am.
What did I tell you about contradicting me?
You told me not to do it.
That's right. So you're going to stay here and watch over the bar while I'm gone.
No, I'm not. The bar is closed. There's no reason why I can't come along.
You want a reason? I'll give you a reason. I don't want you to. And you know why? Because you'll just take her side.
You mean Moogie?
Yes, I mean Moogie. And stop calling her by that infantile nickname.
But she likes it.
Well I don't.
Well she does.
You see? You always take her side.
Somebody has to. After all, she is our mother. Now I'm coming with you. And that's final.
Fine. Come if you want. Just remember one thing... this is between Moogie... , I mean Mother, and me. So if you know what's good for you, you'll stay out of the way.
I don't think so.
(a traditional welcoming ceremony) Welcome to our home. Please place your imprint on the legal waivers and deposit your admission fee in the basket by the door. Remember, my house is my house...
(a traditional response, handing back the towel) As are its contents.
It's good to be back, isn't it Brother?
Now that you mention it... no.
But you haven't been here in twenty years.
Mother certainly has been... acquiring quite a few new things.
Doubtlessly with the generous stipend you give her.
Look, Brother. The latinum tooth-sharpener I used when we were children.
All I had was a cheap wooden chewstick.
Excuse me for interrupting, but we have business to attend to.
As a registered liquidator, it is my duty to present a formal list of the infractions committed by your mother. You have three days to obtain an admission of guilt from the accused.
Three days? Is that all?

If you are not able to obtain a confession, your mother will be placed in indentured servitude and you will be required to make restitution for her crimes. Do you understand everything I've said to you?
He understands, all right.
Not that it matters. I'm not confessing to anything.
Moogie!
It's good to see you, Son. You look well.
And you look... Dressed.
Your mother is wearing clothes.
Mother, get undressed this instant.
Hello, Quark. You haven't changed a bit.
Perhaps I should leave.
Perhaps you should.
Was she addressing me?
No no no, not at all.
Of course I was. This is my home and I'll speak to whomever I want.
But Moogie, he's a stranger, and you're a female.
It's all right, Rom. I know what I'm doing.
Perhaps you do, but I will not stand here and be spoken to by a female.
You have three days to get your house in order.
Now see what you've done.
Quark, you're upsetting your brother.
He's not the only one who's upset. Not that anyone cares how I feel.
That's not true... I care.
Then imprint this... and take off those clothes.
I'm not doing anything of the kind.
Yes you are. You're going to make a full confession, so I can go back to my bar and pretend none of this ever happened.
You mean we're leaving so soon?
Rom, this is your home. You can stay as long as you like. Or leave whenever you like. It's up to you.
Same old Moogie.
Are you sure this is absolutely necessary?
Well I don't know if I would call it "necessary."
Constable, there's no telling how long Quark will be gone. Besides, all we want is our dartboard.
Can't you just replicate another one?
We could...
But we're not going to. That's our dartboard and we want it back. If Quark was going to run off, you think the least he could do is give us a little warning so we could retrieve our property.
It's the principle of the thing.
Well getting it back might not be as simple as you think.
This is one of Rom's special security locks. I've never seen anything so convoluted.
Is there a problem, gentlemen?
It seems Quark locked some of Chief O'Brien and Doctor Bashir's personal property inside his bar.
Let me guess... your lucky dartboard?
We never said it was a "lucky" dartboard.
We're just used to playing on it, that's all.
A little defensive, aren't they?
Hmm, a tripartite microsealing mechanism. That's going to take a while to get through. (but it's not his problem) If you want any suggestions, I'll be in cargo bay...
Four.
Seven.
Oh, I just thought...
Thought what?
Thought you were going to visit that freighter captain.
You know... Jake's friend.
How do you two know about that?
The chief told me.
Captain Yates seems like a very capable woman.
(trying to be one of the guys) Not bad looking either... Or so I've been told.
Exactly how many people has Jake talked to about this woman?
Everyone.
Tube grubs, extra juicy, just the way you like them.
What's wrong, Brother? Aren't you hungry?
What are you doing?
Serving dinner.
That's mother's job.
She's not feeling well.
Not feeling well? Wait a minute, that's not bad. We could say she's having emotional problems. We might even be able to get the F.C.A. to drop the charges in light of her illness.
Actually, all she has is a slight rash. Her skin's still a little sensitive to clothing.
That's hardly an excuse not to serve her sons dinner.
Look at this... she hasn't even softened these grubs for us.
You know Moogie. She never liked to chew our food for us.
Not even when we were children.
She always had her own way of doing things.

Remember how the other children used to tease us about her. "Your mother won't chew your food. Your mother talks to strangers." It's like she went out of her way to embarrass us. Not to mention Father. I remember there were nights when I would find him sitting, slumped in that chair. He'd say to me, "Quark, I don't know what I'm going to do about that female." No wonder he never made much profit. He was too busy worrying about her.
I thought Father did all right.

He could've done a lot better, if she'd just behaved herself... showed him the respect he deserved. Well, she may have dragged Father down, but she's not doing the same to me. It's time someone put her in her place.
Have anyone in mind for the job?
Mmm, dank and musty.
I hand picked them from the cellar.
Mother, we need to talk.
We can talk later. These tube grubs are getting warm.
The tube grubs can wait. You've had your fun, you've proved you could earn a little profit, but now it's over.
Forget it, Quark. I'm not imprinting any confession.
Why not? Imprinting the confession doesn't take away your... achievement. Just admit to what you did and tell the F.C.A. the name of any male who might've helped you.
What exactly did she do, Brother?
Never mind what she did.
Why don't you tell him? Or would you prefer I did?
All right. She took part of the monthly stipend that I send her and invested it in a Hupyrian beetle farm.
High quality beetles. The best.
Really? How much did you make, Moogie?
Three bars of gold-pressed latinum.
Three bars of latinum? Isn't the F.C.A. overreacting a little?
It doesn't matter if it's one slip or a hundred thousand bars, females are not allowed to earn profit.
Why not?
Because it's the law. And without law, society would descend into chaos.
If you ask me, our society could use a little chaos...
Not if I have anything to say about it.
Gee, I wish Father were alive.
Then it'd be just like old times... sitting around the family table, eating tube grubs, discussing important issues of the day.
Mother, I know you're not like other females. You like to think about things... you have opinions...
Is that a compliment, or an accusation?
It's a fact. But what's also a fact, is that if you don't imprint this confession, you'll be sold into indentured servitude, and I'll be forced to make restitution.
But Brother, it's only three bars of latinum.
And I'm not going to allow those three bars to destroy our family. If our disgrace is made known, do you think we could ever do business with another Ferengi again? I wouldn't do business with me.
Mother, please, for our family's reputation, for your sons' financial future, please, imprint the confession.
I can't. I wish you could understand, Quark.
I understand perfectly. You're a selfish female, who never cared about this family, about Father, or about me.
Rom, could you pass the millipede sauce?
I see you haven't changed your bedroom, Moogie. It's still very... traditional.
I keep it this way to remind myself how idiotic Ferengi tradition can be when it comes to females.
Oh.
Rom, is something wrong?
Wrong... No... Not really... except... Your clothes.
Would you feel more comfortable if I took them off?
Well, maybe... just a little.
All right... if it makes you feel better. But only for you.
Better?
Much. You know, Moogie, it really would mean a lot to Quark if you imprinted that confession.
He's made that quite clear.
I know he can be headstrong and overbearing, not to mention mean... and insulting... and rude... but he's not all bad. He works hard. You should see the bar. It's thriving.
I'd like to. But Ferengi tradition doesn't allow females to travel.
Quark doesn't make the rules.
He just lives by them.
Like a good Ferengi.
Like an unenlightened Ferengi.
Moogie, can't you give back the three bars of latinum? If you don't, you're going to destroy everything Quark's worked for.
You always were a good boy. I don't think Quark knows how lucky he is to have a brother as loyal as you.
He knows. He just doesn't like showing it.
This isn't about money, Rom. Quark has always been very generous with my stipend. I have more than enough to live on.
If it's not about money, then what is it about?

It's about pride. And knowing that I'm just as capable of earning profit as any male. Don't you see, if I imprint that confession, it'll mean admitting what I did was wrong. And I'm not going to do that. I'd rather be sold into servitude.
But what about Quark?
He's a smart boy. He can take care of himself.
Now that's enough about your brother. Let me see those teeth.
My teeth? Why?
They're looking a little dull. Why don't you sit down. I'll sharpen them for you.
Aw, Moogie... You're the best.
Pardshay, don't be an idiot. Go get an anti-grav sled before you hurt yourself.
Why don't you just beam it to your cargo hold?
I wish I could. But it's unstable biomatter.
The transporter should still be able to handle it, as long as you adjust the phase transition inhibitor.
Provided I had a Mark Seven Transporter.
You're still using a Mark Six?
A Mark Five.
A Mark Five? I thought they stopped making those...
Fifteen years ago. But when you're working for the Petarians, you have to make do with what they give you.
Let me guess... Commander Sisko.
Benjamin.
Kasidy... Kasidy Yates.
I know.
My son's told me a lot about you.
I think Jake fancies himself something of a matchmaker.
He means well. But he does get a little too enthusiastic now and then.
Damn, that sounded like the inertium ore. I'd better see what's going on.
I'll give you a hand.
I can take care of it.
Of course. Sorry about Jake.
How about coffee? Tomorrow evening... say eighteen hundred hours?
Sounds good.
Then I'll see you tomorrow.
There's nothing like sleeping in your old room.
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: So, how was your night?
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: Mother's been busy.
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: Really, I didn't even know she was up yet.
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: I mean she's been busy. I've been doing some checking. This isn't about three bars of latinum.
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: You mean she earned more?
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: A lot more. So much that I haven't even been able to track it all down.
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: It means Moogie's got the lobes for business.
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: Even if I sold everything I had I couldn't come close to paying back what she's earned. I'm ruined.
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: Coffee? That's it? All you're going to have is coffee?
Well, I was thinking of having an icoberry tart.
You know what I mean. A cup of coffee doesn't give you a lot of time to get to know someone.
We're not even sure we want to get to know each other.
I haven't heard any news, but I'm sure when Quark gets back you'll be the first to know.
So what are you two going to talk about?
I have no idea.
Well, you should think about it, rehearse a few clever things to say, come up with a couple of good stories to catch her interest...
Jake, this isn't exactly my first date.
It's your first date in a long time.
You're just going to have to have a little faith in the old man.
I guess you'll do fine. So what are you going to wear?
This.
Your uniform?
Brother, is everything all right?

I'm so proud of you, Quark. (still no response from Quark) I mean other people in your situation might overreact and lose their temper, make a bad situation worse. But not my brother. You're too smart for that. You're going to sit there and study the problem, and then come up with a clear, simple solution.
I already have.
You see, I told you. What is it?
I'm going to kill her.
Moogie?
A-ha. Caught you. Give me that.
Give you what?
That PADD you just hid under the mattress.
It's a letter to your cousin Stol.
A likely story.
I knew it. You were trying to hide more profits. Well it won't work. I know all about your little financial empire.
It's not so little.
Then you admit it?
Brother, calm down. I'm sure Moogie has a perfectly good explanation for what she's done. Don't you, Moogie?
Since when does a Ferengi have to make excuses for earning profit?
You're a female.
And when it comes to profit, this female is a better Ferengi than you'll ever be.
You expect me to believe you did all this on your own? You had help, admit it. Tell me his name. I'll see to it that the F.C.A. hangs him by his lobes in the Sacred Marketplace.
Quark, sometimes you can be so thick- headed.
Now, Moogie, there's no need to be insulting.
Of course there is. Insults are the only thing he understands. He's so blind with jealousy, he can't even think straight.
Me? Jealous of you? Hah.
You're just like your father.
Why would Father be jealous of you?
Because he knew I had the lobes for business and he didn't. I tried to help him, give him financial advice, but he wouldn't listen to me. Because I was a female.
What other reason did he need? Females don't belong in business.
Give me one reason why not.
Because it's wrong.
You're going to have to do better than that.
No I'm not. It's the law. That was good enough for Father, and it's good enough for me.
A lot of things were good enough for your father. He was a lobeless failure... and if you're not careful, you're going to end up just like him.
That does it.
Brother, where are you going?
To the F.C.A. Let's see what they have to say about your... "Financial Empire."
Brother, wait.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Out of my way, Rom.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: No. I'm not going to let you hurt Mother.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: She's no mother of mine.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Why? Because of what she said about Father? Did it ever occur to you that she might be right?
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: How dare you take her side against Father?
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Don't tell me about Father. I knew him a lot better than you did. You ran off as soon as you reached the Age of Ascension. But I stayed here for ten more years. And you know what I learned in those ten years? I learned that Father was no financial genius.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Take that back.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: It's the truth.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: He went from one bad deal to the next, one failure after another. He couldn't hold onto latinum if you sewed it into his pants.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: That does it.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Quark. Rom.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: That's enough.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Let him go.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: But Moogie...
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Stop it, both of you.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: If your brother wants to go to the F.C.A., let him.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: But you'll get in trouble.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: I'll worry about that.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Go on. What are you waiting for?
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: That's the steepest forty flights of stairs I've ever climbed.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Seven slips of latinum to use the elevator. Talk about inflation. Refined dilithium down ten percent?
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: The name's Quark. I'm here to see Liquidator Brunt.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Oh, of course.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: And two more.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: For use of the financial data net.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: But I barely looked at it.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Which is why I'm only charging you two slips.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: I'll tell Liquidator Brunt that you're here. Have a seat.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: How much?
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Three slips. A bargain.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: I'll stand.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: That'll be one slip.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: (getting back into the swing of things) I'll give you two for the chair.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: If you're here to deliver an imprinted confession, you can leave it with me. I'll see that Liquidator Brunt gets it. For a nominal handling charge.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Tell Brunt I need to talk to him now.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: I have information that could shake the very foundation of the Ferengi Alliance.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Brother. Wait.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: I have to sit down.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: That'll be three slips of latinum.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Brother, can you loan me...
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Yeah, yeah. Here.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Now what do you want?
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: (finally catching his breath) I have a message from Moogie.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: There's nothing she could say that would interest me.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: She'll share it with you.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: What was that?
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Her profits. Fifty-fifty.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Tell Brunt I'll talk to him later. Come on. Let's try out that elevator.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: But it's so expensive.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: I can afford it.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Mother, I want to apologize for all the terrible things I said. I was angry, and I got carried away. I'm sorry.
Apology accepted. I'm just glad that Rom was able to catch you before you made a horrible mistake.
It would've been a shame to waste all that profit.
I'm glad we agree.
So, just how much latinum have you made?
Does it matter?
I only want to make sure everything is divided fairly.
Divided?
Fifty-fifty. Just like you said.
I never said that. You said he'd let me keep all the profit for myself.
I said no such thing.
So I lied to both of you. I had no choice. It was the only way to get the two of you talking again.
There's nothing to say.
Don't get your lobes caught in the door on your way out.

That's enough bickering. You're both acting like children. I will not stand by and let this family fall apart. Quark, you should be ashamed of yourself. I've seen you treat Cardassians with more respect than you show your own mother. And Moogie, if Quark can uncover your hidden investments, eventually the F.C.A. will too. And all that profit will be lost. Think about that for a moment.
Now neither of you is going to leave this room until you've settled things. Is that clear?
And no shouting. I'm going to take a nap.
He's a sweet boy.
That's easy for you to say. He doesn't live next door to you.
You're too hard on him. You always have been.
I had to be. You were always too easy on him. Maybe if you'd pushed him a little harder, he would've amounted to something.
I doubt it. When it comes to business, he takes after your father.
You enjoy insulting Father, don't you?
I'm not insulting anyone; I'm just being honest. Rom's a lot like his father... And I suppose, you're a lot like me.
I never knew you felt that way.
Your father might've bought you your first copy of the Rules of Acquisition, but who helped you memorize them?
You did.
I don't think I've ever been prouder than the first time you made it through all two hundred and eighty- five rules without a mistake.
Rom knows them just as well as I do.

But you understand them. Rom never did. And neither did your father. But even if Keldar didn't know the first thing about profit, he knew everything about family. He was a good husband and a wonderful father. And I loved him for that. The same way I love Rom... And the same way I love you.
You mean that?
Yes, I suppose I do. If it'll make you happy, I'll give back the money.
You'll imprint the confession?
You're my son, Quark. How can I refuse you?
You don't know how much this means to me.
I know exactly how much it means to you.
Oh, Moogie. I love you.
There's no place like New Orleans for simple pleasures... good food, good music...
Sounds like a great place to grow up.
The best. Can I get you another raktajino?
No, I'm fine.
You seem a little... preoccupied.
It's just... when we made our plans I forgot I had a... previous engagement.
I see.
It's not what you think. It's kind of a family obligation. You see, my youngest brother's a colonist on Cestus Three.
That's on the other side of the Federation.
It's so far away, it takes two weeks for a subspace transmission to get here and I'm expecting one tonight. I promised my brother I'd listen to it as it came in.
I hope nothing's wrong.
Not unless he hurt himself again. Last time he tore some ligaments in his knee.
How'd that happen?
(doesn't know how to explain) He was doing something called "sliding into second."
"Sliding into second?" That sounds like baseball.
You know about baseball?
It's my favorite sport. But no one's played it in two hundred years.
Well they're playing it on Cestus Three... at least they have been for the past six months.
I had no idea. That's fantastic. How many teams are there?
Six. But they're trying to organize a couple more. I didn't know you liked baseball.
I didn't know anyone liked baseball, except for Jake and me.
Look, this transmission I mentioned, it's an audio recording of a game between my brother's team, the Pike City Pioneers and the Cestus Comets. If you'd like you're welcome to listen to it with me.
I'd love to.
So does your brother's league use the designated hitter rule?
No. They thought about it, but decided against it.
Wood bats or polyduranide?
Wood, of course.
Could they use a right handed pitcher?
There. I hope that's satisfactory.
Everything seems to be in order.
I'm glad we can finally put an end to this matter. And I certainly hope you've learned your lesson.
And what would that be?
She's speaking to me again.
No she wasn't.
She was speaking to me. Now what were you saying about a lesson?
The lesson is... No one can outsmart the F.C.A.
I think she's certainly learned that. Right, Mother?
Your mother's confession will serve as a warning to females all over the Alliance.
Oh, I don't think anyone has to know about this.
After all, what would people say if they knew a female had made that much latinum?
I shudder to think.
Goodbye. I sincerely hope I never see any of you again.
The feeling is mutual.
I thought he'd never leave.
Mother, must you?
Quark, I've just given up a sizable fortune. I'm in no mood for your nagging.
You're absolutely right. If you want to wear clothes, go ahead... What do I care? I'm leaving anyway.
So soon?
I have to reopen the bar. It's supporting all of us now.
You know you could call your mother every once in a while. Maybe even visit.
I will... I promise.
Let's go, Rom.
I'll be along in a moment, Brother.
I'm glad to see you two are finally getting along.
I think things will be a lot better between us from now on.
As long as he doesn't find out you only gave the F.C.A. a third of your profits.
If you ask me, a third was too much. But it's my own fault for not hiding it better.
You sure the F.C.A. won't find the rest?
I've got it so well hidden, I'll be lucky if I can find it.
Moogie...
Now don't start crying, Rom. You'll have me doing it. Go on. Quark's waiting for you.
And take care of your brother. I worry about that boy.
Lot of kick for a forty-five Dom.
Thank you, Mister... Mister... ?
BASHIR. Julian Bashir.
Who's that?
An uninvited guest.
Nice tux.
Thank you.
Now get out.
But Doctor, I've only just arrived.
Garak, breaking into a holosuite during someone's program is not only rude, it's illegal. I should call Odo and have you arrested.
What an extreme reaction that would be. You must be quite embarrassed by this program.
I'm not embarrassed. I'm annoyed that you've intruded on my privacy.

Privacy, Doctor? I'd say it goes far deeper than that. Ever since you received this new program, you've been spending virtually all of your free time in the holosuite. But you haven't told anyone what the program is.
Am I supposed to?
No. But you're a -- forgive me -- a talkative man and it's unusual for you to have secrets.
I must've picked up the habit from you. Now, if you'll excuse me...
Is this fantasy of yours really that revealing of your inner psyche?
What?
Is that why you're so protective? Afraid that I might learn some humiliating secret about the real Julian Bashir?
This is just a fantasy, Garak. I'm not hiding anything.
If you have nothing to hide, then why not let me stay.
All right. But I've only got another two hours before I go on duty and I want to enjoy myself. So keep quiet and don't rain on my parade.
Your parade?
Nevermind.
Don't worry, Doctor. I can be quite discreet. You'll barely know I'm here.
Good.
But if I may make one observation.
Garak...
I just wanted to point out that your lovely companion is leaving.
Odd. She seemed so interested in your advances only a moment ago. I wonder what scared her off?
Oh, no. I do apologize. You must be incensed. In fact, if I were in your shoes, I would... grab a bottle of champagne and shoot me.
I can see I'm going to regret this already...
Come on, Doctor we're going to have a wonderful time... after all, what could possibly go wrong?
You live here?
That's right.
Decorate it yourself?
The decor is appropriate for the period. Nineteen sixty-four.
How did you pronounce the name of this city?
Kowloon... it's part of Hong Kong.
And the nightclub was in Paris, which, if I remember correctly, is on the other side of the --
Mister Bashir, I didn't expect you home so soon.
I decided to leave Paris a little early. Allow me to introduce my friend, Mister Garak. Garak, this is Mona Luvsitt, my personal valet.
I'm pleased to make your acquaintance. Would you like to change into something more comfortable?
That would be perfect. See if you can find something for Mister Garak as well.
I'll see what I can do. Shall I put this away?
Please.
Care for a drink?
Not just yet.
Is she your valet or your personal assassin?
Valet. And Mona's very capable. Speaks seven languages, has degrees in chemistry, physics, and biology, can fly anything from jets to helicopters... and she makes an excellent martini.
I take it that your character is some kind of... rich dilettante, with a fascination for women and weapons.
