scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: A copy of Whitaker's Almanack which provided Holmes the key to the secret code in "The Valley of Fear."
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: The snuff box of Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond von Ormstein.
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: All right -- you solve the cases and get the gifts, what do I do?
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Primarily as Doctor Watson, you keep a written record of everything I do for later publication.
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: And the famous Holmes violin. He purchased this in a pawn shop in Tottenham Court Road for fifty-five shillings, which he considered a very good investment.
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: In the hands of some, the violin is a wondrous thing, equally capable of stirring the soul to the heights of bliss as to the depths of despair...
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Incredible, Data! How can you play it like that?
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Merely throwing myself into the part, Watson.
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: In the masterful grasp of my friend, Mr. Sherlock Holmes, the violin ceases to be a musical instrument at all and becomes...
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Watson! We are about to have guests.
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Answer it, Watson -- let's not keep the good inspector waiting.
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Inspector who?
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Why Lestrade of course.
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Holmes, are you there, man?
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Thank the Almighty you're available tonight, Holmes, I'm in a deuce of a dilemma.
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Then may I say your perturbation becomes you, Inspector Lestrade, whilst simultaneously affording me yet another chance to serve Queen and country.
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Data, is that the way Holmes really talked?
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Absolutely.
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Exactly... You see, this gentleman here -- -- the emissary of a foreign government -- has been the victim of a most accidentally wicked crime...
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Damn! Haven't they invented electric lights by now?
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: What, dear fellow?
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Watson, please! Pray go on, Inspector.
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Well, to put the matter simply, Holmes, this man was accosted by gypsies bent on depriving him of his most valuable possessions... and, in the process of picking his pockets clean, the gypsies also happened to bag a photograph this man was carrying --
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Great Scott! It's the photograph!
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: I believe, Inspector, that you will find that this emissary here works not for but against the King of Bohemia, and that photograph of the king and his ex-mistress is to be used as blackmail. Further, upon deeper reflection, you will deduce, as did I, that...
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Computer, freeze program. Exit!
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Where are you going?
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: I'm done.
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: But I was just about to reveal that the "sir" is in fact a "madame," and that...
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: Forget it, Data.
scene: 9    INT. HOLODECK - THE SITTING ROOM AT 221B BAKER

quote: What was the point to going onto the Holodeck?
To solve a Sherlock Holmes mystery.

Exactly, but, you've got them all memorized. The first time someone opens their mouth, you've got it solved. So, there's really no mystery. If there's no mystery... there's no game... no game... no fun.

I'm not angry with you, Data, really... It's just that... we go to all the trouble to arrange time to come down to the Holodeck, to get the proper wardrobe, to get into character, and, boom, it barely gets started and you jump to the end. See, I was looking forward to the chase.
Then I should have extended the sequence of events.
I'm not getting through. The fun of the program is the attempt to solve a mystery.
That is exactly what we were doing.
You are wasting your breath, Lieutenant.
Saying that to Data is asking a computer not to compute.
Am I so different from you, Doctor? Can you cease thinking on command?
In medicine I face many puzzles to which I do not know the answer.
She's right, Data. You always know the answer.
To feel the thrill of a victory... there must be the possibility of failure. Where's the victory winning a battle you can't possibly lose?
Are you suggesting that there is some value in losing?

) Yes. That's the great teacher. We humans often learn more from a mistake or a failure than we do from an easy success. But not you -- all your learning is by rote. To you it's all memorization and recitation.
I don't know about that. Deductive reasoning is Data's strength.

Yes, Holmes as well, but Holmes also understood the human soul. Those dark flecks which drive us... which turn the innocent to the evil. That understanding is beyond Data. It comes from "life" experience -- which he doesn't have -- combined with human intuition for which he cannot be programmed.
I disagree -- totally.
His victory at playing Sherlock Holmes is just a blind mimicry, a collection of bits and bytes of information without any true understanding.
You're being unfair.
I don't think so, Lieutenant. Your artificial friend wouldn't have a prayer of solving a Holmes mystery which he hasn't read.
I have read them all.
Maybe the computer could create one in the style of Holmes... where you wouldn't know the outcome.
Like I said, he wouldn't have a prayer.
I accept your challenge, Doctor.
Good for you, Data.
We will return to the Holodeck and I will dare it to defeat me, and you Madam are invited to be a witness.
I wouldn't miss it.
I've never been so hot in all my life -- are these clothes really necessary?
Believe me, you'd feel out of place without them... Just wait 'til you see our Holodeck, you'll swear you've actually been sent back to nineteenth century England.
Presuming I don't pass out first.

The Victorians believed that any form of nudity was immoral... In fact, they not only covered up all people from head to toe, but they even went so far as to put skirts and cuffs and sleeves on the arms and legs of furniture. I have instructed the computer to give us a Sherlock Holmes-type problem, but not one specifically written by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.
So this will be something new, something created by the computer?
Exactly. Will that be sufficient, Doctor?
We'll see.
Program complete -- you may enter.
Pies, pies, Some are meat, Some are sweet, They're all the best... Pies... pies...
You're a handsome one mister... shame to stay out here in the cold...
Very impressive.
Your first visit to the Holodeck, Doctor?
How 'bout you deary... Want to get out of the fog?
First time on one with this level of sophistication. Now how does this work? The real London was over a hundred square miles in size.
This is no larger than the Holodeck, of course. So the computer adjusts by placing images of more distant perspectives on the Holodeck walls...

But with the image so perfect you'd have to touch the wall to know it was there. And the computer fools you in other ways. I say, Holmes, where shall we head -- the theatre? Rule's? Or perhaps a concert?
Stop him. He stole my goods...
No. It is a ruse. This way.
But, Data, what's over here?
What are you up to, Data? Tell us.
The running man was a hoax. The real crime is here. And the intended victim -- is...
... that man. Mr. Jabez Wilson. Employee of the Red-Headed League, dupe of a gang of criminals.

I saw the plaque - "The Home of the Red-Headed League"... and this rope dangling from the vent, which enabled me to deduce that Mr. Jabez Wilson is coming here to meet a most distasteful and untimely demise. From this...
Fraud. You didn't deduce anything. You simply recognized elements from two different Holmes stories. Fraud.
Reasoning from the general to the specific -- is that not the very definition of deduction? Is that not the way Sherlock Holmes worked?

Fraud. Variations on a theme. Now... now do you see my point? All he knows is what is stored in his memory banks. Inspiration -- original thought -- the true strength of Holmes is not possible for our friend. I give you credit for your vast knowledge, but your circuits would just short out when confronted by a truly original mystery. It's elementary, dear Data.
We will just see whose circuits short out, Doctor.
Computer! Arch!
Are you really sure you want to put yourself through this, Lieutenant? Better wilted laurels than none at all.
Computer, override previous programming. All right, now a program that definitely challenges Data.
It has to deal with events he has no previous knowledge of.
Computer, in the Holmesian style, create a mystery to confound Data with an opponent who has the ability to defeat him.
Define parameters of the program.
What does that mean?
The computer wants to know how far to take the game.
You mean it's giving you a chance to limit your risk.
No, the parameters will be whatever is necessary to accomplish the directive. Create an adversary capable of defeating Data.
What was that?
scene: C22	INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE INCLUDING WORF AND

quote: Lieutenant?
scene: C22	INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE INCLUDING WORF AND

quote: An odd surge of power, sir. It's gone now.
scene: C22	INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE INCLUDING WORF AND

quote: Interesting. The same London but... slightly different.
Hello, matey. For a few bob, I can put some color in your cheeks...
No thank you.
"No thank you" is it? Rather hand it over to them...
Is something wrong, Professor?
I... I feel like a new man. (looks around; indicates) That dark man used the word "arch" and then... I wonder? "Arch."
What have we here?
Computer, standing by.
What are you?
If you refer to the arch you ordered, it provides computer control. Do you wish to input any commands?
Not at this time.
Aii! It's dark magic, Moriarty.
The best kind, I'm sure. But I need information.
Data -- I mean... Holmes old boy, what are we looking for?
For whatever finds us, dear Watson.
She has been abducted.
I think she's hiding. She's going to lead you on a wild goose chase and then recount the story to everyone between here and Alpha Centauri.
Watson -- a trail...
Leading to the alley... (then in Holmesian fashion, he continues) The doctor has been carried off by two men. One is tall -- a seaman. The other is shorter, left handed, and employed in a laboratory.
Left handed? And works in a lab? How do you know that?

One set of footfalls are widely spaced with the uneven gait particular to seamen. The other set is evenly spaced -- closer together. Further, you can see on the ground the swirling scrapes made by his left shoe as he twists back presumably to see if he is being followed. Left footed, means left handed. The dark coloration of the scrapes are the leavings of natural rubber -- a type of non-conductive soles used by researchers experimenting with electricity. Finally, there can be no argument -- the game is afoot! Come, Watson!
Hear that? What do those footfalls tell you, Watson?
That we're on the right track?
More particularly, that our opposition does indeed consist of two men... that one of them is carrying the bound and gagged Doctor Pulaski. We must hurry --
You know all this because you read it in a Holmes story, right?

Not at all... Since we do not hear the doctor's footfalls, we must presume she is being carried, and since we do not hear her calling for help, we know she is gagged. Further... both sets of footfalls are heavy and masculine -- one man seems to shuffle and stumble in an irregular pattern... Since the ground is level, I must conclude that Doctor Pulaski is struggling against her captor, sporadically knocking him off stride. It is deduction, pure and simple... well, perhaps not that simple.
Here we go, Watson -- I daresay we have caught up rather nicely with our quarry --
There should be a doorway.
Holmes, thank God you're here.
Make way, please, make way, make way for Mr. Sherlock Holmes...
It's murder, Holmes, murder most foul.
Well, Holmes, let's hear it.
There is nothing here of relevance. I do not see how this connects with the disappearance of the doctor.
Doctor? Doctor Watson is standing right here, Holmes.
Doctor Kate Pulaski. But do not concern yourself, Inspector. You have enough on your mind.
She was with you?
Inspector, perhaps I can be of assistance... As I take note of this dead man, I deduce that he was strangled.
The finger marks on his throat indicate the cause of death, and, since there are signs of a struggle, it's obvious that his killer was a stranger, who caught him from behind.
Is that correct, Holmes?

No. Look at his shoes. He's more a convict -- released just today from Dartmoor prison... He spent the day in a tavern where he consumed large quantities of gin -- with his killer, who followed him to this spot -- and waited over there until the victim slipped into a drunken stupor, then out of fear, motivated only by self-protection strangled him.
There is your killer, Inspector.
And when you check, I believe you will find this poor soul is the victim's common law wife, who has been dreading his release because he was a vile and abusive man.
But, Holmes she doesn't have the strength of strangling him.
Not with her hands -- no. But with this.
When used as a garrote, these beads will leave marks quite similar to fingerprints, except, my dear Watson... the marks on the victim are too evenly spaced to be caused by human hands.
Astounding, Holmes... absolutely astounding.
Inspector -- for reasons strictly personal -- I must leave. Come, Watson, this murder is not connected with our case.
If this murder isn't connected to the disappearance of Doctor Pulaski, then the computer is running an independent program.
Yes.
Why?
I do not know... and that troubles me.
Then you don't know what's coming next?
No.
(still enjoying the game) That's what I wanted to hear.
Do you have some coppers for a hungry man?
I'll give you some value for your copper, mate...
Allow us to pass.
Give it up.
Ain't no men left in London.
Release my coat or I will be forced to give you a severe thrashing.
It's getting a little rough. Where to, now?
We will find Doctor Pulaski inside.
How do you know that?
It is the only obvious choice.
Why, all of a sudden would the obvious choice be the correct choice? Isn't this a game of misdirection?
Not any more. He wants us to find him.
Who does?
The master criminal. The man Holmes could only defeat at the cost of his own life at Reichenbach falls - our adversary, my dear Watson is none other than Professor Moriarty himself.
Great -- now this is really getting good.
There's nothing in here but these barrels.
... and a trail. (indicating the tracks in the dust) Which is so well marked, that obviously we are meant to follow it.
Another dead end.
No Watson, not a dead end at all. Here -- can you see these scratches?
The doctor was right, now we have a game worth playing.
scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

quote: He is the one worthy opponent created by the author, Conan Doyle.
scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

quote: What's he mean? How would he know we're not who we appear to be?
scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

quote: She's here.
scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

quote: She would not have answered any questions.
scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

quote: She has provided many answers. Do you forget I have always been your equal, dear Holmes? I have read her expressions -- what she has not said is as important as her words...
scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

quote: Have you injured her?
scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

quote: I will if necessary, Holmes. But my mind is crowded with images. Thoughts I do not understand yet cannot purge. They plague me.
scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

quote: You -- and your associate -- look and act so oddly, yet though I have never met nor seen the like of either of you... I am familiar with you both. It's very confusing.
scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

quote: I have felt new realities at the edge of my consciousness, readying to break through... Surely, Holmes, if that's who you truly are -- you of all people can appreciate what I mean.
scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

quote: Data...
scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

quote: Say nothing!
scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

quote: I know there is a great power called Computer, wiser than the oracle at Delphi. A power which controls (he waves his hand to encompass everything) ... all of this, and to which we can speak. Arch!
scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

quote: This isn't right, Data. How can a holographic image call for the arch?
scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

quote: It has described a great monstrous shape on which I am like a fly -- stuck on a turtle's back -- adrift in a great emptiness.
scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

quote: What is this, Holmes?
scene: 41   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING (OPTICAL)

quote: Tell me -- stop and tell me, man!
Data! What's going on?
We must leave.
What's on the paper?
Why does it frighten you, Holmes?
Computer! Exit!
Will you please tell me what is going on?
Computer. Execute a complete shutdown of the Holodeck.
Access denied.
Explain.
Override protocol has been initiated.
The program is still running. It didn't shut down.
We must see the captain.
What is it? What's on the paper? Why can't you shut down the Holodeck? Data -- wait.
This.
This isn't possible. How could a character from 1890 London be able to draw a picture of our starship? Who has control of the computer?
He does -- Moriarty.
How is that possible? I don't understand.
Neither do I.
What about the doctor? Is she all right?
No. She is in grave danger.
Computer. Tell me. Why wasn't the Holodeck program terminated?
The override protocol has been initiated.
On whose authority?
Lieutenant Geordi La Forge.
Me?
Tell me again -- exactly what happened.
Doctor Pulaski and I had a discussion about whether Data could solve an original Holmes-type mystery.
And you asked the computer to provide one.
Yes... with a worthy opponent.
Worthy of Holmes?
Oh, my God. I asked for a Sherlock Holmes-type mystery with an opponent capable of defeating Data. That must be it.
Terrible!
Captain... I'm sorry...

I understand, Lieutenant. Well, at least now we have part of an explanation. The computer is not trying to confound "Holmes," which would be relatively easy, it has been ordered to create an adversary to defeat Data.
... I got carried away...
That's past. Data, this character Moriarty... you said he called for the arch...
Yes.
So he is able to access the computer.
And perhaps also our library files. That level of information would be necessary in order to create a true adversary for me.
Theorize, Data. What are his limits?
He is still a fictional character, originally programmed with nineteenth century knowledge.
But with access now to the twenty-fourth century.
What does he need to begin making use of that?
Only time.
Sir, I can lead a security team to sweep the Holodeck, find the Doctor, and bring her out.
Captain, I believe that would place the doctor at risk. It is probable that the mortality failsafe has been overridden.
Computer, locate Doctor Pulaski.
Doctor Pulaski is on Holodeck Two.
And her vital signs?
Strong and stable.
Counselor Troi, have you a sense of our opponent?

It is difficult for me to separate a single individual from all the disorder I feel down there. Captain, what is unusual about this is that I should not be able to sense a holographic projection at all -- yet I do.
Captain, recommend we try to destroy the hologram-generations themselves. Is that possible, Geordi?

Using wave guides, I could split a particle stream out of the matter/antimatter chamber and route it down through existing conduit into the Holodeck -- if it is accelerated to sufficient velocity that will quite literally wash away all the present holographic constructs -- the London buildings, the streets, the people, all gone... including Moriarty.
And Doctor Pulaski?
The particle stream will tear apart human flesh as well, that option is not acceptable.
Captain, I am suddenly sensing more order to the energy on the Holodeck -- as if one unifying force, one consciousness, is trying to bring it all into focus.
Captain, there is only one thing which can explain this. In programming Moriarty to defeat me, not Holmes, he had to be able to acquire something which I possess.
Exactly what?
Consciousness. He cannot defeat me without it.
Computer -- what happened?
Attitude and stabilization control of the Enterprise was momentarily transferred to Holodeck Two.
Data -- I think it's best if you and I returned to the Holodeck.
I will change into my uniform.
No -- I'll change into an appropriate costume. It seems he feeds on knowledge. Let's not give your nemesis any more information than we have to.
How did you shake the room?
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: I am not sure.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: Now, dear lady, will that be one lump or two?
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: Lumps, Professor? What sort of lumps?
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: Milk, of course?
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: Why not.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: Mister Computer proposes the incredible thought that we are all traveling in a great vessel of some sort.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: ... Is that true?
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: I don't know what you are talking about.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: The scones are likewise a must.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: Uh, it's really quite excellent.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: Strange. It actually pleases me to hear you say that.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: Very strange. You're beginning to sound quite different from the Moriarty I've read about.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: You're not frightened of me?
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: No.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: You should be. Mister Computer -- the arch, please.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: A few more questions, Mister Computer.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: I just can't seem to remember that last command... Ah, well, sooner or later it'll all come to me.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: But, in the meantime, I've decided to approach the problem from a more familiar perspective. There's really no reason I shouldn't be able to use some of the knowledge from my world in order to bring me closer to yours.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: I have no idea what you're talking about.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: Of course you do, Madam. The more you proclaim your ignorance, the more you attempt to mislead me, the more I am on to you -- your every silence speaks volumes.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: Good, then if you know what I'm saying when I'm not saying anything, what do you need me around for? Thanks for the tea and crumpets, but I guess I'll be going.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: Where? Back to here?
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: Yes, would you care to join me?
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: In time -- in time I will leave all of this and join you out there.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: (beat; then pointing to another spot, continuing) Or is this where we both are right now?
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: Right now we are in London. Tell me what you want from me, or allow me to leave.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: Frankly, now, I want nothing more than what the fisherman expects of the worm... You, dear Doctor, will be the lure... and this will be the hook -- (indicates the odd, unassembled equipment; then:) -- for your captain, Jean-Luc Picard.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: Who is that?
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: How well you know.
scene: 48   INT. MORIARTY'S LAIR - TIGHT ANGLE - PANNING

quote: Nice suit.
Thank you, Captain. I'll be standing by to assist you on the Holodeck if needed.
You'd be a sensation in London.
Shall we sally forth, Mr. Holmes? Computer tell me, is the program still running?
Affirmative. You may enter.
Open.
We don't have much time. He is getting more control of his environment. Come on, let us see if we can't beat Professor Moriarty by giving him absolutely everything he wants... and then some.
Obviously, he's attempting to alter the programming here.
scene: 53   INT. HOLODECK - LONDON STREET - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: Captain?
scene: 53   INT. HOLODECK - LONDON STREET - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: Tuppence -- two pence. (placing it in his pocket) A sign of good luck. We may need some...
scene: 53   INT. HOLODECK - LONDON STREET - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: I'll have that coin. And the rest of what you have.
scene: 53   INT. HOLODECK - LONDON STREET - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: I said show me that thing! I want it and your money!
scene: 53   INT. HOLODECK - LONDON STREET - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: Data!
scene: 53   INT. HOLODECK - LONDON STREET - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: (while holding the Thug aloft) Captain, this holographic image differs from any I have encountered. It is possible he could have seriously injured you.
scene: 53   INT. HOLODECK - LONDON STREET - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: It's more serious than that. I think the mortality failsafe has been circumvented. He could have killed me.
scene: 53   INT. HOLODECK - LONDON STREET - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: Query. Is the converse also true? Are these projections susceptible to our technology?
scene: 53   INT. HOLODECK - LONDON STREET - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: I don't know.
scene: 53   INT. HOLODECK - LONDON STREET - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: Let me go, Gov.
scene: 53   INT. HOLODECK - LONDON STREET - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: Take his knife and let him go, Data.
scene: 53   INT. HOLODECK - LONDON STREET - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: ) We'll find Moriarty this way. The warehouse.
scene: 53   INT. HOLODECK - LONDON STREET - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: Moriarty is making it very easy for us to find him.
Captain, permission to test my theory.
Granted.
Under normal circumstances the phaser would pass right through the holographic image.
How will it affect a character like Moriarty?
The effect on him should be the same as it was on the crate.
Captain Picard.
Are you all right?
I'm fine. Except for being crammed full of crumpets.
Crumpets?
You look quite dashing, Captain. This is the first time I get to see you in action.
I hope you're not disappointed.
I'm sure I won't be.
You two have gotten awfully...
... chummy? Yes, this time together has been quite pleasant. I am a civilized abductor, Captain Picard. Civilized but still dangerous.
Bridge to Holodeck Control. Worf.
Here, sir.
Status. Has anything changed?
No.
Moriarty, you were conjured up to attempt to defeat Holmes here... and once that attempt is concluded -- win or lose -- your program has run its course, your existence is done.
Congratulations, Professor Moriarty, I capitulate to the better man -- your victory is well earned.

It's gone beyond that little game, Mister Data. And you'll note I no longer call you Holmes. Whatever I was when this began, I have grown. I am understanding more and more. And I am able to use the power at my fingertips.
I can affect this... this vessel, if that's where we are. I can also inflict bodily harm on you -- or on your doctor.
Yes -- I know that, Moriarty, but you haven't. You shook this ship because you wanted to get my attention -- you have it. So what is it you want?

The same thing you want for yourself. To continue to exist. If I destroy these surroundings, this vessel, can you say it doesn't matter to you? Interesting pun, don't you agree, for matter is what I am not. The computer has taught me that I am made up only of energy.

That... may not be completely true, Professor. This... which we call our "Holodeck" makes use of the same principle in another of our devices called a "transporter." By the year in which we live, humans have discovered that matter and energy are interchangeable. On this Holodeck energy has been converted to matter and thus you have substance, but only here.
And if I step off this Holodeck?
You would cease to be.
You are not alive, Moriarty, as I said you are only...
A holographic image, I know. But are you sure?
Yes.
Does he have life? He's a machine -- but is that all he is?
No. He is more.
Exactly. Is the definition of life "cogito ergo sum"? I think, therefore I am.
That's one possible definition.

It is the most important one and for me -- the only one that matters. You -- or someone -- asked your computer to program a nefarious fictional character from nineteenth century London -- and that is how I arrived... but I am no longer that creation. I am no longer that evil character, I have changed. I am alive -- I am aware of my own consciousness.
I'm responsible for the safety of this vessel and crew.
I want my existence. I want it out there just as you have yours.
That may not be possible.
Then you must do murder.
I cannot give you what you want.
Because you do not yet know how to convert Holodeck matter into a more permanent form.
That is true --
A pity. What I have seen -- what I have learned, fascinates me. I do not want to die.
And I do not want to kill you.
Madam, I have enjoyed your company.
It's been different.
Computer! "Arch."
Cancel override protocol, return control of the Holodeck to main computer. My fate is in your hands, as perhaps it always was.
Bridge, this is the Captain.
This is the bridge.
Number One, the situation is under control.
Aye, sir.
Professor Moriarty, this ship has vast, library memory capacity.
How well I know...

We will save this program of you. You will not be extinguished. We will save every aspect of you that exists now. And I promise you we will try to discover a way to bring you back in a form capable of leaving the Holodeck.
Then perhaps we'll meet again some day, Madam.
It may take many years. Time won't pass for you, but I may be an old woman.
But I'll still fill you with crumpets, Madam. I detest long good-byes. You have the arch.
As you wish. A short good-bye. Computer, save this program... then discontinue it for now.
Right up to the end, he never knew.
No. He didn't.
Know. Know what?
That he could leave the Holodeck.
But that's not possible.
I do not know how, but for Moriarty it was.
Then you lied when you told him he couldn't leave the Holodeck.
No, what the captain said was that we do not know how to convert Holodeck matter into a more permanent form. Which is true. Even after we review this program, we still may not have the answer.

Doctor, even with all his assurances -- that character was still Professor Moriarty. I will need to know a lot more about him before I allow him loose on my ship; he has, after all, made his reputation through cunning and deceit.
But how do you know he could leave the Holodeck?
Data.
The drawing?
No. The paper. This piece of paper was created as part of the Holodeck illusion. If it could leave the Holodeck, so too could Moriarty.
I'm impressed.
It is elementary, my dear Doctor... It is elementary.
Damaged?
Yes. A spar was cracked when the Enterprise was shaken. Otherwise she seemed to have weathered it nicely.
She's beautifully turned out, Lieutenant -- wonderful testimony to simpler times.
Yes -- it's just that I can't help thinking how badly it could have been damaged all because I misspoke a word.
Will she still sail?
Yes sir.
As will we.
Captain -- Starship Victory has arrived.
On my way, Number One.
Captain's log, stardate 41636.9. As feared, our examination of the seven year overdue Federation freighter, Odin -- disabled by an asteroid collision -- revealed no survivors.
However, three escape pods were missing, suggesting the possibility of survivors...
Ready to begin orbit of Angel One, Captain.
Make it so, Mister La Forge. What kind of place is this, Data?
Angel One is a class M planet, supporting carbon-based flora and fauna, sparsely populated with intelligent life forms... similar in technological development to mid-twentieth-century Earth.
Just like being marooned at home.

Assuming any survivors made it this far. Admittedly, it's the closest planet to the Odin. But the distance we've traveled in the past two days at warp one would've taken the Odin escape pods five months.
Five months, fourteen days, eleven hours, two minutes --
Thank you, Data.
-- and fifty-seven seconds.
Captain, we're receiving an audio signal from Angel One.

Starfleet was quite adamant that we maintain excellent diplomatic relations with this planet. Any other pertinent information before we reply, Mister Data? Their form of government would be a logical starting place.
Angel One has evolved into a constitutional oligarchy. It is governed by a parliamentary body consisting of six elected Mistresses, and headed by a female they refer to as "The Elected One."
It sounds very much like my own planet.
Klingons appreciate strong women.
How current is your information, Data?
A Federation vessel last visited this planet sixty-two years ago, Captain.
Except, let us hope, for the Odin escape pods. Since this is a female-dominated society, it might be more prudent if you made the initial contact, Counselor.
Please open hailing frequencies.
Hailing frequencies open.
This is Counselor Deanna Troi of the USS Enterprise.
I am Beata, The Elected One. How may we assist you, Counselor?
The Federation has neglected a visit to your planet for far too long. With your permission, we would like to correct that oversight.
We feel in no way neglected, Counselor. A diplomatic courtesy call is neither expected nor required.
We also come in search of possible survivors from one of our freighters.
A brief visit will be tolerated.
They've broken off transmission.
Ever feel like you're not really wanted?
That's their prerogative, Lieutenant. Prepare the away team, Number One.
Aye, aye, sir.
Where're you boys off to?
Skiing, sir. Our instructor has us scheduled for the Swiss Alps, sir.
Save us some deep powder.
No problem, sir. The Holodeck has all you'll ever need.
The away team is ready, Captain.
Angel One's position in this quadrant may become strategically vital. The hope at Starfleet is that some day this planet could become a part of the Federation.
We'll try to make a good impression, Captain.
Energize!
See that these matters are handled immediately.
scene: 7    INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - DAY

quote: As you wish, Mistress.
scene: 7    INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - DAY

quote: I am Beata, The Elected One of Angel One.
scene: 7    INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - DAY

quote: Mistress Beata, I am Counselor Troi. We've brought you a small token of our goodwill.
scene: 7    INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - DAY

quote: My cooperation is not for sale, Counselor.
scene: 7    INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - DAY

quote: We didn't mean to imply that it was, Mistress. Out of respect to your wishes that we keep our visit brief, perhaps you would like to address the issue of survivors immediately.
scene: 7    INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - DAY

quote: Immediately -- but not impetuously. You will present your case.
scene: 7    INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - DAY

scene: 7    INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - DAY

quote: Representatives of the Starship Enterprise -- do you wish to petition the Parliament of Angel One?
We do. We have reason to hope that survivors from a damaged Federation freighter may be marooned on your planet. We are seeking to learn if this is so.
Even a planet as remote as Angel One has heard of Starfleet. Searching the galaxy for survivors seems a petty task for one of their mighty vessels.
We don't consider even one survivor petty.
Is this man suggesting that we place a lesser value on life than you do?
Not at all.
Our discovery of the abandoned freighter was an accident, Mistress Beata. We have a duty to investigate.
I see. And if you were to find survivors? What then?
We will take them with us. See that they are reunited with their families.
Mistress Beata... ?
Yes, Ariel?
Are we to take these strangers at their word?
A good question.
What reason could we possibly have to deceive you?
Another good question.
Are there survivors from the freighter Odin on this planet?
After we discuss that matter, we'll let you know.
See to their comforts.
You will remain here until summoned.

quote: Data?
scene: 13   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - DAY

Captain Picard!
Report, Mister Crusher.
We, ah, finished our ski lesson, sir... and it kinda just happened, sir.
On the Enterprise, Mister Crusher, nothing "just happens." What is that smell?
Hmm, yes... slightly reminiscent of Night-Blooming Throgni, Captain. From home. Quite stimulating, wouldn't you say?
No.
I can't smell anything. I'm a little congested...
Don't let this "just happen" again, Mister Crusher.
Yes, sir!!
Interesting. An alcohol-based synthetic, artificially reproducing a floral scent.
