quote: You claim you intend to remove these survivors from our planet. Are you prepared to give us your solemn word on that?
We are.
You should know that the vote was not unanimous. Some among us are suspicious.
Yet, the majority feel that we have no choice but to trust you.
We don't understand the source of your misgivings, Mistress, but we appreciate your faith in us.
Make certain that our faith has not been misplaced. There are four survivors from the ship you call the Odin. All male. Their leader is a man who calls himself Ramsey.
If you'll bring these men to us, we'll have them off your planet immediately.
If they were mine to deliver, I would do so without hesitation. Unfortunately, their hiding place has long eluded us.
Hiding place? Why are they in hiding?

Because they are fugitives on Angel One! And the sooner we are rid of them, the better! When these men arrived seven years ago, they accepted our hospitality quickly enough. But gradually, they grew restive. Making unreasonable demands, going against the natural order -- there seemed to be no end to the trouble they created.
Using the technology of the Enterprise, we might be able to find these men.
I assumed as much. But be warned, Counselor -- -- these men are dangerous.
This is worse than Hesperan Thumping Cough. What is it, Mom?
You and your friend probably picked up something on the Quazulu Eight field trip last week. Whatever it is may have been activated by your exposure to the cold ski environment of the Holodeck.
But the transporter biofilter is supposed to kill stuff like that.
If this is our first contact, it wouldn't have been programmed into the biofilter computer yet.
Mom...
Sickbay to Captain Picard.
Picard here.
Wesley and one of his friends have contracted some form of respiratory ailment -- most likely a viral infection.
Is it contained?
I believe so. I've isolated the twelve students who were on the field trip where I believe the problem began.
How contagious is it?
Unknown. Nor do I have a clue as to how it's transmitted.
Please stay with it, Doctor. Starfleet has important business for us as soon as the away team returns. I don't relish having my crew infected.
At the moment, my only suggestion is that all crew avoid any cold-weather Holodeck simulations until further notice.
Agreed. And keep me advised.
Data, how can we best go about finding Mister Ramsey and the other survivors?
scene: 27   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: Assuming the survivors have retained some remnants of their lives aboard the Odin, we might not have a difficult task. If we can isolate something unique to the survivors -- perhaps an element not otherwise found on Angel One -- we can utilize the Enterprise scanners.
scene: 27   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: Mister Data will need access to your library.
scene: 27   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: Our library is far too sophisticated for a man to comprehend.
scene: 27   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: I am an android, Mistress, though anatomically, I am a fully functioning male.
scene: 27   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: An amusing notion. Perhaps you could teach our males a thing or two. Trent -- see to the android's needs.
scene: 27   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: Do not forget your promise.
scene: 27   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: Bridge to Captain Picard.
Go ahead, Lieutenant.
The away team has requested that we scan the planet surface for traces of platinum.
Have Mister La Forge break fixed orbit and initiate a search pattern.
Aye, Captain. Geordi.
Search pattern initiated now.
This is all quite unnecessary, Doctor. I'm merely fatigued.
Because you are very ill, Captain. You have the virus. Captain, in my opinion, you are no longer physically able to effectively command this vessel.
Don't be ridiculous, Doctor. I've got an away team down there, in less-than-friendly territory, not to mention an appointment with the several Romulan battlecruisers...
You have an appointment in your cabin, Captain. With your bed.
Is that an order?
Yes.
I guess I'm better at giving orders than taking them.
I think I may sneeze...
A Klingon sneeze?!
Only kind I know.
Lieutenant La Forge -- you have command until further notice. Please make the proper entries in the ship's log.
Aye, sir.
Scanners indicate a platinum trace. Should I notify the away team?
Make it so.
The Enterprise reports a possible location for Mister Ramsey and the other survivors.
scene: 32   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - NIGHT

quote: So soon? I'm impressed with your haste.
scene: 32   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - NIGHT

quote: I am suspicious of it.
scene: 32   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - NIGHT

quote: You've had your opportunity to object, Ariel. You were in the minority.
scene: 32   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - NIGHT

quote: Excuse me, Mistress. I have matters to attend to elsewhere.
scene: 32   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - NIGHT

quote: With your permission, we'd like to begin our search immediately.
scene: 32   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - NIGHT

quote: By all means. But I'm sure that Counselor Troi and the others can do that without you. If I recall, you had a gesture of goodwill you wished to give me... ?
scene: 32   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - NIGHT

quote: That can certainly wait until we've recovered the survivors.
scene: 32   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - NIGHT

quote: Are you suggesting that the women in your party are incapable of performing this task without the help of a man?
scene: 32   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - NIGHT

quote: Not at all. Lieutenant Yar and Counselor Troi are completely qualified.
scene: 32   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - NIGHT

quote: How generous you are with your praise. Inform them you will remain here with me.
scene: 32   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - NIGHT

quote: Riker to Lieutenant Yar.
scene: 32   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - NIGHT

quote: This is Yar.
Tasha - you'll be leading the team without me.
Commander... ?
In the interest of diplomatic relations, I'll remain with Mistress Beata while you conduct your search.
Certainly, sir.
Relax. We have much to discuss.
Set phasers to stun.
Is that really necessary?
A justified precaution, Counselor. Mistress Beata observed that Mister Ramsey and his men were dangerous.
Lieutenant Yar to Enterprise.
Go ahead, Tasha.
Three to beam to the location of that platinum trace, Geordi.
Coordinates set.
Energize!
Welcome. I've been expecting you.
Picard to bridge.
Pardon me.
La Forge here, Captain.
Status report, please.
Eighty-two more reported cases of the virus, sir. Doctor Crusher has converted the Holodeck into an isolation ward.
And the --
-- away team?
No recent contact, Captain. But I've informed them of the medical situation up here and the growing Romulan threat to our Neutral Zone outpost.
Keep me-- --advised. You'll have the bridge until Commander Riker returns.
Engineering reports a computer malf...
Sorry, I'm... getting sick.
I'm sure half the ship knows that by now. Report to Sickbay.
Engineering to bridge.
La Forge here.
Sir, the computer won't accept the variant climate controls Doctor Crusher wants in the quarantine areas.
I'm on my way.
With all respect, Lieutenant, there are other people to do that job now.
bridge to Engineering. Lieutenant Wong knows the system. I'm sure she'll be able to resolve all problems.
I'll ask her to look at it right away, sir.
Worf...
Thanks for the advice.
We haven't much time, Mister Ramsey. The Enterprise has urgent business elsewhere.
Certainly we have time for a drink.
How did you find me?

Actually, it was quite simple. I accessed all possible elements available to the crew of the Odin, cross-referenced those to elements endemic to Angel One, then eliminated the common denominators. Angel One has no platinum. Enterprise scanners did the rest.
Platinum, was it?
My wings. I kept them for their sentimental value.
Where are the other survivors, Mister Ramsey?
Oh, they're nearby. Packing, as a matter of fact, since we can no longer remain here. As the unofficial leader of our little group, I've been chosen to speak for us all.
Marooned seven years on an alien planet. Rather than excitement or anticipation at being rescued, I sense a feeling of calm in you.
What is it you think you're rescuing me from? My shipmates and I have all taken wives. A few even have children. You can't "rescue" a man from the place he calls his home.
... Why were you so hesitant at first to tell us about the Odin survivors?

Simply because Ramsey and his men are anarchists. Tampering with the laws of nature. Obsessed with spreading untruths, and encouraging dissent among our people. I had to be certain you weren't here to fuel their struggle.
It's not our place to interfere in the domestic affairs of other societies.

Not you, perhaps, because you understand a man's place. But Ramsey is not so well-mannered. Sometimes I fear that it is actually the men who are the clever ones, enjoying all that life has to offer while we women devote ourselves to the drudgery of making life work.
In our society, men and women share equally in all that life has to offer.
Don't misunderstand me, Riker. I'd be the last to imply that men are in any way inferior to women. But, after all, men are... men -- with a natural place in the scheme of things.
We gave up those distinctions centuries ago. In our world, equality among the sexes is so well established, we no longer consider it an issue.
You deny that differences exist between men and women?
We not only acknowledge the differences. We delight in them.
That's so like a man. So emotional. What would we do without you... ?
Thank you, Trent.
You may go.
With compliments of the USS Enterprise.
It's called an Albeni meditation crystal.
Very impressive.
And now, of course, I must repay you in kind.

... Five months in a rescue pod no bigger than this room is an eternity I hope none of you ever have to face. When we finally made it here, we all thought we'd died and gone to heaven. You've seen the women of the planet -- tall and strong and lovely.
But once the newness wore off, we started to see how men on this planet were treated. No vote, no opinions... no respect.
None of which is any longer your concern, Mister Ramsey. Call the others in, please. It's time to leave.
Despite its problems, Lieutenant, we like it here on Angel One. We're not going anywhere.
But Mistress Beata --
Mistress Beata be damned! Her wish is not my command. And neither is yours. You can't force us to go.

Mister Ramsey is correct, Counselor. The Odin was not a starship, which means its crew is not bound by the Prime Directive. If he and the other survivors wish to stay here, there is absolutely nothing we can do.
Bridge to Sickbay -- how are you Doing, Doctor?
We have more sick than we do beds.
I've been forced to confine over three hundred to their private quarters.
We're going to be seriously undermanned if we're forced to engage the Romulans in battle.

The Romulans are your problem, Lieutenant. Trying to find an innoculant is mine. This virus mutates every twenty minutes. On the positive side, the virus is debilitating -- but so far we haven't had any fatalities.
If this continues, there'll be no one left to run the ship.
If it continues, no one will be healthy enough to care.
Lieutenant Yar to Enterprise.
Enterprise, go ahead.
Prepare to beam three back to our previous location, Geordi. After we regroup with Commander Riker, we'll return to the ship.

Suggest you make that on the double. We have a real medical emergency brewing up here. A third of the crew is down. And the latest report from the Neutral Zone outpost is that more Romulan battlecrusiers are entering the area.
I'll inform the commander. One thing before we go. You said you were expecting us. Why?
I'm sorry. I can't tell you.
We wish you well, Mister Ramsey.
Energize!
They are gone.
It is such a refreshing change to be with a man who knows what he wants.
You mean without a woman having to tell him?
Exactly! I knew you were bright enough to understand. Women, by our very nature, want only what is best for their men.
Men are not objects to be possessed, Mistress Beata.
Of course they're not. It was merely a figure of speech.
Enter.
Why do you bother me?
Forgive the disturbance, Elected One...
I expect so little from this sorry excuse for a man. Perhaps even that much is too much...
What is so important you find it necessary to intrude on my privacy?
They have returned, Mistress. But without Ramsey or the others.
Your advanced technology has proven inadequate?
What happened, Troi?
Mister Ramsey and the other survivors refuse to leave.
But you promised!
I'm sorry. There's nothing else we can do.
I am sorry as well.
Since you refuse to take them with you, I am left with no choice... but to sentence them all to death.
Enter.
It looks horrible, tastes worse -- but it's absolutely guaranteed to make you feel better.
Knew you'd like it. New cologne?
Same... you gave me last birthday.
Uh-uh, different. Like something I smelled earlier. Something... I don't know... like a flower I remember. Something Klingon, I think.
Lieutenant Worf and I... detected a similar scent when we bumped into... your son at the Holodeck.

It's that smell! That must be how the virus travels! An airborne microbe whose sweet scent inspires deep inhalation... ... And once inside the body, becomes this damned virus! I have a great deal of work to do.
You are excused, Doctor.
What's the latest on the Enterprise's medical situation?
scene: 54   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: Doctor Crusher feels the virus will undoubtedly run unchecked through the entire ship's contingent. Attempts to develop an innoculant have so far ended in failure. Lieutenant La Forge still has the Conn pending your return.
scene: 54   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: What about the Romulans in the Neutral Zone?
scene: 54   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: The border outpost reports a contingent of seven Romulan battlecruisers within sensor range. The USS Berlin has answered their distress call, and is standing by. However, should hostilities erupt, the outpost and the starship will be outgunned. It is felt that the Enterprise's presence in the area will be a vital show of force.
scene: 54   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: Some show of force. The Enterprise may be able to fly on autopilot. But with that virus knocking down our crew, we're going to be in sorry shape if things turn ugly.
scene: 54   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: The Romulans won't know our strength, Lieutenant. It's time for us to leave this place.
scene: 54   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: It feels terribly wrong to leave while Beata is determined to execute those people.
scene: 54   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: She has to find them first. Ramsey and his bunch have been fugitives for years. I suspect he's pretty good at evading capture. As cold as it sounds we're going to have to treat this mission as if it never happened. Everything will remain exactly as it was before we arrived.
scene: 54   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: Something is wrong.
scene: 54   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: Your presence on Angel One no longer amuses me.
scene: 54   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: Amusement was never our intention, Mistress.
scene: 54   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: Before you go back to your ship, there is something I wish you to see.
scene: 54   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: We were no harm to anyone. Why did you tell them where to find us?
scene: 54   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: Don't blame them, Ramsey. You brought this upon yourself. You... and the traitor.
scene: 54   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: One doesn't need the technology of the Enterprise to follow Mistress Ariel sneaking off to warn her husband. Let her stand with him now...
scene: 54   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: ... For tomorrow they will die together.
scene: 54   INT. ANGEL ONE GREAT HALL - NIGHT

quote: You're out of commission, Geordi. Report to your quarters.
Can't leave my post... until I'm relieved.
I've been aboard the Enterprise long enough to know she's designed to run herself.
But the innoculant --
I can do my research on the computers here.
Then I can convalesce here.
You claim to be an advanced society, yet you resort to tyranny and executions in order to suppress those who don't share your views.
scene: 58   INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - NIGHT

quote: I don't expect you to understand.
scene: 58   INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - NIGHT

quote: Why? Because I'm only a man?
scene: 58   INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - NIGHT

quote: You'll accomplish nothing with that attitude.
scene: 58   INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - NIGHT

quote: Mistress Beata, if you could avoid executing Ramsey and his followers, would you do so?
scene: 58   INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - NIGHT

quote: Is that not the way of an advanced society?
scene: 58   INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - NIGHT

quote: Then let us talk to men from the Odin one last time. Let me try to convince them to leave with us.
scene: 58   INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - NIGHT

quote: But what of the others? Their minds have been poisoned. Will you also include those from this planet who unwisely chose to follow Ramsey and his group?
scene: 58   INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - NIGHT

quote: Yes. All of them.
scene: 58   INT. ANGEL ONE EXECUTIVE OFFICE - NIGHT

quote: Mistress Beata is giving you a second chance. We're prepared to take your entire group with us.
That's very kind of you, sir, but we're not going.
Haven't you been paying attention, Ramsey? You're scheduled to be executed tomorrow.

We don't want to die. We don't want to leave, either. I'm not Academy educated, but I've studied a little history. The ancient Christians faced their lions, the natives of the African continent faced their suppressors.
Even the women of the twentieth century chose to settle for nothing but full equality.
There's no time to debate the issues, Ramsey. We're taking you with us whether you choose to go or not.
Excuse me, Commander, but removing any of these people against their will would be a violation of several Starfleet regulations, not the least of which would be the Prime Directive.
I realize that, Data. But I'd rather be facing a court martial than trying to live with the guilt of leaving these people to their deaths. Commander Riker to Enterprise.
This is the Enterprise.
scene: 61   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: Things must be worse up there than we thought.
scene: 61   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: Doctor, where is Lieutenant La Forge?
scene: 61   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: He's right here, Will, but he's in no shape to be here.
scene: 61   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: We're on our way, Doctor. There'll be fourteen to beam up. Two groups, five each. I'll be in the last group of four.
scene: 61   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: I'm afraid I can't allow that, Will. The virus is totally out of control. Until I know exactly what I'm dealing with, I can't let anyone new be exposed.
scene: 61   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: There are people facing certain death down here, Doctor.
scene: 61   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: They could well be facing the same thing up here, Will. I have no idea what effect living on Angel One might have on a person's immune system. I'm sorry.
scene: 61   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: Understood. Doctor -- would this virus have any effect on Data?
scene: 61   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: None that I can imagine.
scene: 61   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: You're going back alone, Data. We have no idea what the Romulans plan to do to that outpost. You're going to have to get the Enterprise to the Neutral Zone before it's too late.
scene: 61   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: That's a direct order, Mister Data.
scene: 61   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: Neutral Zone before it is too late. Understood, Commander.
scene: 61   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: This is Data, standing by to beam up.
scene: 61   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: And what of them?
scene: 61   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: I don't know, Deanna.
scene: 61   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE - (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: Mistress Beata invites you to witness this morning's reaffirmation of Angel One's moral imperative.
scene: 65   INT. ANGEL ONE - GUEST QUARTERS - DAY

quote: Is that supposed to be the fancy name for murder on this planet?
scene: 65   INT. ANGEL ONE - GUEST QUARTERS - DAY

quote: Send Mistress Beata our regrets.
scene: 65   INT. ANGEL ONE - GUEST QUARTERS - DAY

quote: The Elected One will not look fondly upon --
scene: 65   INT. ANGEL ONE - GUEST QUARTERS - DAY

quote: Enterprise to Commander Riker.
scene: 65   INT. ANGEL ONE - GUEST QUARTERS - DAY

quote: They are still here?
scene: 65   INT. ANGEL ONE - GUEST QUARTERS - DAY

quote: This is Commander Riker.
scene: 65   INT. ANGEL ONE - GUEST QUARTERS - DAY

quote: I gave you a direct order to head for the Neutral Zone immediately. Explain the delay.
scene: 66   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE (INTERCUT AS DESIRED)

quote: To be precise, Commander, you ordered me to reach the Neutral Zone "before it is too late." I have computed the length of time the border outpost and USS Berlin can safely withstand a Romulan attack... deducted our time to destination at maximum warp speed. That leaves Doctor Crusher with forty-eight more minutes to complete her research and develop an innoculant to the virus.
scene: 66   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE (INTERCUT AS DESIRED)

quote: Which means there's still time for us to do something.
scene: 66   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE (INTERCUT AS DESIRED)

quote: Forty-eight minutes... I think we're down to splitting hairs.
scene: 66   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE (INTERCUT AS DESIRED)

quote: Splitting hairs is a figure of speech I recognize, Commander. Speaking for those whose hair is soon to be split, forty-eight minutes may make a great deal of difference. Excuse me -- forty-seven minutes.
scene: 66   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE (INTERCUT AS DESIRED)

quote: Perhaps, Data, just perhaps. Thanks for following my orders so precisely, Data. Riker out.
scene: 66   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE (INTERCUT AS DESIRED)

quote: On second thought, Trent, we would be honored to watch your moral imperative in action.
scene: 66   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE (INTERCUT AS DESIRED)

quote: Sickbay to bridge.
Go ahead, Doctor.
Bingo, Data.
Bingo? I fail to see the relevance, Doctor. Is that not a reference to an ancient Earth game?
It's also a reference to success, Data. I've got the innoculant.
Excellent, Doctor. And we still have a margin of seventeen minutes. I will inform the away team immediately. Enterprise to Commander Riker.
We are ready to have you beamed up, Commander.
scene: 72   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - DAY

quote: Data, I want you to lock the transporter on the holding area where they're keeping Ramsey and the others. If we don't hear from Beata in the next ten minutes, you are to begin the beam up sequence, five at a time. The away team will beam up last.
scene: 72   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - DAY

quote: Understood, Commander. Enterprise out.
scene: 72   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - DAY

quote: The Elected One wishes to see you.
scene: 72   INT. ANGEL ONE GUEST QUARTERS - DAY

quote: Welcome home.
It's good to be back. Is everyone recovering?
Slowly... but yes.
Enter.
How are you feeling, sir?
On the mend, thank you. Tell me about Angel One.
Set coordinates for the Neutral Zone, Mister Data. We have a call to pay on the Romulans.
Coordinates set, Commander. On your mark --
As Captain Picard would say -- make it so, Mister Data.
That was an incredible program.
I am glad you approve. I have always found the Black Sea at night to be a most... stimulating experience.

Worf, we were strolling barefoot along the beach while balalaika music played in the air... ocean breeze washing over us... stars in the sky... a full moon rising... and the most you can say is "stimulating"?
It was... very stimulating.
The truth is, I don't spend nearly enough time on the Holodeck.
I should take my own advice and use it to relax. Next time, I'll choose the program. If you like the Black Sea, you're going to love Lake Cataria on Betazed.
Deanna... perhaps before there is a "next time" we should discuss... Commander Riker.
Why, is he coming along?
No... but I do not wish to... I mean, it would be unfortunate if he... if you and I are going to continue... I do not want to hurt his feelings...
Worf... I think it's all right to concentrate on our feelings... yours... and mine.
Counselor!
What's today's date? The date?
Stardate 47988.
Captain, what's wrong?
I'm not sure... I don't know how... or why, but... I'm moving back and forth through time.
It was as though I had physically left the ship and gone to another time and place... I was in the past...
Can you describe where you were... what it looked like?
It's all slipping away so fast... like waking up from a nightmare...

It was years ago... before I took command of the Enterprise. I was talking with someone... I don't remember who... But then -- everything changed. I wasn't in the past any longer... I was an old man, in the future... I was doing something outside... what was it?
I'm sorry. It's gone. I can't remember...
It's all right. Have you considered the possibility that this was just a dream?
It was more than a dream... the smells and the sounds... the way things felt to the touch... it was all so real...
How long did you stay in each of these time periods? Did it seem like minutes... hours?

I'm not sure. At first... there was a moment of confusion, of disorientation. I wasn't sure where I was. But that passed... and then I felt perfectly natural... as though I belonged in that time. But I can't remember how long I stayed there. I know this doesn't make much sense... it's a feeling more than a distinct memory.
Maybe we can identify specific symbols. Can you remember anything you saw, an object, a building perhaps --
Captain Picard to the Bridge!
Sir, I think we have a problem with the warp core, or the phase inducers, or some other damn thing.
Geordi...
Hello, Captain... or should I make that Ambassador?
Hasn't been Ambassador for a while either.
How about Mister Picard?
How about... Jean-Luc?
I don't know if I can get used to that.
Good Lord, Geordi. How long has it been?
Oh... about nine years.
No, no... I mean, since you last called me Captain? When was the last time we were all together... on the Enterprise?
Close to twenty-five years.
Twenty-five years... Time's been good to you.
It's been a little too good to me in some places.
Can I give you a hand?
Oh... I'm just tying some vines.
Looks like you've got leaf miners. Might want to use a bacillus spray. My wife is quite a gardener. I've picked up a little bit of it.
How is Leah?
Busy as ever. She's just been made director of the Daystrom Institute.
And the little ones... Bret and Alandra? And...
And Sidney. Not so little any more. Bret's applying to Starfleet Academy next year.
So what brings you here?
Oh... I just thought I'd drop by. I'd been thinking about the old days on the Enterprise... and I was in the neighborhood...
Don't give me that. You don't make the trip from Rigel Three to Earth just to... drop by.
No.
So. You've heard.
Well... Leah has a few friends at Starfleet medical... and word gets around.
I'm not an invalid, you know. Irumodic Syndrome can take years to run its course.
I know. But when I heard I just... wanted to come by all the same.
Well... as long as you're here, you can help me carry in some of these tools.
My cooking may not be up to Leah's standards, but I can still make a decent cup of tea.
By the way, I read your last novel. Not bad. I thought the protagonist was written a bit flamboyantly, but that's just my --
Captain, are you all right? Captain?
Captain?
Are you all right, sir?
Sir... ?
I'm sorry, Lieutenant. My mind seems to have wandered for a moment... What were you saying?
I was asking if you'd ever been aboard a Galaxy Class starship before, sir.
No. I'm, of course, very familiar with the blueprints and specifications... but this will be my first time aboard.
Well then, sir, if I may be so bold -- you're in for a treat. The Enterprise is quite a ship.
I'm sure she is.
Have I done something wrong, sir?
No. You just seem very... familiar.
Enterprise to Shuttlecraft Galileo. You are cleared for arrival in Shuttlebay Two.
Acknowledged, Enterprise.
There she is...
Captain?
Tasha... I was just with Tasha, in the shuttle...
Troi to Doctor Crusher. Something's wrong with the Captain. We're on our way to Sickbay.
I've finished the neurographic scan. I don't see anything that might cause hallucinations or a psychogenic reaction.
Is there any indication of temporal displacement?

No. Usually a temporal shift would leave some kind of trypamine residue in the cerebral cortex. But the scan didn't find any. Personally, I think you just enjoy waking everyone up in the middle of the night.
Actually, I just like running around the ship in my bare feet.
The bio-spectral test results, Doctor.
Your blood gas analysis is consistent with someone who's been breathing the ship's air for weeks.
If you'd been somewhere else, there would be some indication of a change in your oxygen isotope ratios. Thanks, Alissa.
Deanna... would you excuse us?
Of course.
Jean-Luc... I scanned for any evidence of Irumodic Syndrome, as you suggested. There wasn't any. But I did detect a small structural defect in your parietal lobe.
A defect... that you've never noticed before?
It's the kind of thing that would only show up on a level four neurographic scan. It could leave you susceptible to several neurological disorders... including Irumodic Syndrome.

Now, it's possible you could have that defect for the rest of your life without developing a problem... ... but even if you do... many people lead perfectly normal lives for a long time after the onset of Irumodic Syndrome.
Then why do you look like you've just signed my death sentence?
Sorry. I guess... this has caught me off guard.
Well, let's not worry about it. Something tells me you're going to have to put up with me for a very long time.
It won't be easy, but I'll manage.
Did Worf find anything?
No, sir. His security scans came up negative.
They're checking the sensor logs... but there's still no indication that you left the ship.
It wasn't a dream... something did happen.
Worf to Captain.
Go ahead, Lieutenant.
Sir -- there is an incoming transmission from Admiral Nakamura. It is a priority one message.
Beverly?
Mister Worf, route it through to Doctor Crusher's office.
Captain.
Admiral.

I'm initiating a fleetwide Yellow Alert. Starfleet intelligence has picked up some disturbing reports from the Romulan Empire. It appears that at least thirty Warbirds have been pulled from other assignments and are heading for the Neutral Zone.
Is there any indication why they would make such a blatantly aggressive move?

Our operatives on Romulus have indicated that there appears to be something happening in the Neutral Zone -- specifically, in the Devron System. Our own long range scans have picked up some kind of spatial anomaly in the area, but we can't tell what it is.
What are our orders?
This is a delicate situation. I'm deploying fifteen starships along our side of the Neutral Zone. I want you to go there as well -- see if you can find out what's going on in the Devron System.
Am I authorized to enter the Zone?
Not yet. Wait and see what the Romulans do. You can conduct long-range scans, send probes if necessary... but don't cross the border unless they do.
Understood.
Captain... what's wrong?
This isn't my time. I belong somewhere else...
What?
I mean... I... I wasn't here a moment ago...
What do you mean? You've been right here with me...
No, no... I was somewhere else... a long time ago... I was talking to someone... Beverly... Beverly was there...
It's okay, Captain... everything's going to be all right.
I'm not senile. It did happen. I was here, with you... and then I was in another place... It was... it was back on the Enterprise!
At least, I think it was... it seemed like Sickbay... but maybe it was a hospital... or...
Captain, I think we should go back to the house... call a doctor...
No. I know what you're thinking. It's the Irumodic Syndrome -- it's beginning to -- to affect the old man's mind. Well, it's not that. And I wasn't daydreaming, either.
All right... all right... what do you want do about it?
I want to see Data.
Data... Why?
I think he can help...
Help -- how?
I don't know! I don't know, but I want to see him!
Okay... we'll go see Data. Is he still at Cambridge?
Yes... yes... I think he's...
Do you see them?
See... who?
They're everywhere... laughing at me... why are they laughing?
Come on, Captain... let's go see Data.
Yes... Data... yes...
I know how it sounds... but it happened. It was real. I was back on the Enterprise.
How do you like your tea?
Tea? Earl Grey. Hot.
Of course it's hot. What do ya want in it?
Nothing...
This is quite a place you have here, Data. I see they treat Professors pretty well at Cambridge...
Holding the Lucasian Chair does have its perquisites. This house originally belonged to Sir Isaac Newton when he held the position. It has become the traditional residence.
If you're really his friend, you'll get him to take that grey out of his hair. He looks like a bloody skunk.
She can be trying at times. But she does make me laugh.
What is it with your hair, anyway?
I have found that a touch of gray adds an air of... distinction.
Is this Earl Grey? I'd swear it was breakfast tea.
Captain, when was the last time you saw a physician about your Irumodic Syndrome?
A week ago. I was prescribed peridaxon.
And yes, I know it's not a cure... nothing can stop the deterioration of my... my synaptic pathways... You think I'm senile... that this is all some... delusion.
No one said anything like that.
In all honesty, Captain, it's a thought that has occurred to me. However, there is nothing to disprove what you are saying, either. So it's possible something is happening to you.

The first thing we should do is give you a complete series of neurographic scans. We can use the equipment at the bio-metrics lab here on campus. Jessel, ask Professor Rippert to take over my lecture for tomorrow and possibly for the rest of the week.
That's the Data I remember! I knew I could count on you!
Commanding officer... Enterprise... arriving.
To Captain Jean-Luc Picard, Stardate 41148...
... You are hereby requested and required to take command...
... to take command of the USS Enterprise as of this date. Signed Rear Admiral Norah Satie, Starfleet Command.
Red Alert! All hands to Battle Stations!
You heard him -- move!

Personal Log: Stardate 41153.7. Recorded under security lockout Omega three-two-seven. I have decided not to inform this crew of my experiences. If it's true that I've travelled to the past, I cannot risk giving them foreknowledge of what's to come.
Report.
We've completed a full subspace scan of the ship and surrounding space. We detected no unusual readings or anomalies.
With all due respect, sir... it would help if we knew what we were looking for.
Noted. Counselor, do you sense anything unusual aboard the Enterprise... an alien presence that doesn't belong here... perhaps operating on a level of intelligence far superior to our own?
No, sir. I'm only aware of the crew... and the families aboard the ship.
Mister Worf, I want you to initiate a Level Two Security Alert on all decks until further notice.
Sir, with all due respect... I'm the Security Chief on this ship. Unless you're planning to make a change...
No... no, of course not. Security Alert Two, Lieutenant.
Aye, sir.
Captain Picard to the Bridge, Please.
On my way, Chief.
Sir, Starfleet has just issued an alert. It appears that a number of vessels are moving toward the Neutral Zone between Romulan and Federation space.
What kind of vessels?
Freighters, transports... all civilian. None of them Federation ships.
It says a large spatial anomaly has appeared in the Neutral Zone... In the Devron System.
Perhaps it is a Romulan trick -- to lure ships into the Neutral Zone as an excuse for a military strike.
Starfleet's cancelling our mission to Farpoint Station and ordering us to the Neutral Zone as soon as we can leave spacedock.
No... no, we'll proceed to Farpoint.
Sir?
You heard me.
But Captain -- the security of the Federation may be at stake!
Man your station, Mister Worf.
Captain, perhaps if we understood your thinking, if you could explain --
I don't intend to explain anything... ... to anyone. We will proceed to Farpoint Station, as originally planned.
Now, if I'm not mistaken, Chief, we're having some problems with the warp plasma inducers.
That's right, sir.
I think I know a way to get them back on-line. You're with me. We'll be in Main Engineering.
I do not understand. The Romulans may be planning an attack, and he does not seem to care. Are you certain this is the same man who commanded the Stargazer?
As far as I know.
What are you going to do?
I'm going to do what I'm told.... prepare to go to Farpoint.
Mister O'Brien, use these specifications to bypass the secondary plasma inducer.
You have to realize, sir... this isn't exactly my area of expertise. The Chief Engineer should be making these modifications.
But the Chief Engineer isn't on board yet. Mister O'Brien... trust me. I know you can do this.
All those years you spent as a child... building model starship engines... were well worth it.
How'd you know that, sir?
From... your Starfleet records.
Yes, sir. I'll get right to the modifications.
Fletcher -- tell Munoz and Lee to get up here right away. We have to realign the entire power grid. We're all going to be burning the midnight oil on this one.
That would be inadvisable.
Excuse me?
If you attempt to ignite a petroleum product on this ship at zero-hundred hours -- it will activate the fire suppression system, which will seal off this entire compartment.
Sir... that was just an expression.
An expression of what?
A figure of speech... I was trying to tell him that... we were going to be working late...
Ah. Then "to burn the midnight oil" implies late work?
That's right.
I am curious. What is the etymology of that idiom? How did it come to be used in contemporary language?
I... don't know, sir...
Commander Data, welcome aboard -- it's good to see you.
It is... good to see you, too, sir.
I could use your help with the infusor array.
Certainly.
As you can see, we're having difficulty with the plasma conduits...
This will require a completely new field induction subprocessor. It appears that we will be required to... ignite the midnight petroleum, sir.
Jean-Luc... what's going on?
It happened again.
A time shift?
Yes...
What happened?
It's still a little vague, but I can remember more this time. I think the more I shift between time periods, the more memory I retain...
First, I was in what appeared to be the future... years from now. Then I was in the past again... right before our first mission...
What is it?

I just scanned his temporal lobe and compared it to the scan I performed just a few minutes ago. There's a thirteen percent increase of acetylcholine in his hippocampus. Within a matter of minutes, you accumulated over two days worth of memories.
Counselor, do you remember the first day I came aboard the Enterprise?
Yes.
What happened after the welcoming ceremony?
There was a reception in Ten Forward... I introduced you to Worf and the other senior officers...
Do you have any memory of me calling for a Red Alert in spacedock? Do you remember Starfleet diverting us from Farpoint to the Neutral Zone to investigate a spatial anomaly?
No...
It would appear that there is a discontinuity between the time periods you have described. Events in one time period would seem to have no effect on the other two.
And yet in both the past and the present -- there's a report of the same anomaly in the Devron System. It's hard to believe that's a coincidence.
For all I know, there may be one in the future, too.
Maybe the anomaly is some kind of... temporal disruption.
But how is all this related to your time shifting?

These are good questions. And I suspect I might find some answers when I return to the past... but for now we're facing a potentially dangerous threat from the Romulans. All departments should submit combat readiness reports by oh eight hundred hours tomorrow. Dismissed.
Looks like it's going to be a late night... want to get some dinner first?
Actually, I... I mean... we have plans.
Oh... I see. Well then... see you tomorrow morning.
Goodnight, sir.
Worf...
... and I want continuous subspace sweeps. We might detect a temporal disturbance.
Aye sir.
Wil... this time shifting... when it happens, I experience a moment of disorientation. If this should happen during a crisis, I want you to be ready to take command immediately.
Number One?
Sorry, Captain. Be prepared to take command. Aye sir.
Speaking of disorientation... are you all right?
Just a little distracted. I'm fine.
You have the Bridge. I'll be in my Ready Room.
Come.
Milk, warm -- dash of nutmeg.
What's this?
A prescription. A glass of warm milk and eight hours uninterrupted sleep.
Beverly...
Doctor's orders. You're exhausted. I don't know if you've slept in the past or the future... but I know you haven't slept in the present. Get some rest, or I'll have you relieved and sedated.
Yes, sir.
What's wrong?
Beverly.
As a physician, it's often my job to give people unpleasant news... to tell them that they need surgery or that they can't have children... Or that they might be facing a difficult illness...
You said yourself it's only a possibility.
But you've been to the future... you know it's going to happen.
I prefer to think of the future as something that is not written in stone. A lot of things can happen in twenty-five years.
A lot of things can happen.
Sir? Wake up... sir?
Yes... yes, what is it? Have we reached the Neutral Zone?

scene: 40   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

scene: 40   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

quote: Sir...
scene: 40   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

scene: 40   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

scene: 40   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

scene: 40   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

scene: 40   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

scene: 40   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

scene: 40   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

quote: I think it's time to call in some old favors... Contact Admiral Riker at Starbase Two-four-seven.
scene: 40   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

quote: Jean-Luc, you know I'd like to help... but frankly, what you're asking for is impossible. The Klingons have closed their borders to all Federation starships.

scene: 42   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

quote: I saw a report from Starfleet Intelligence on that sector this morning. There's no activity... there's nothing unusual happening in the Devron System.
scene: 42   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

scene: 42   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

scene: 42   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

scene: 42   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

quote: Right. Look, I've got the Yorktown out near the border... I'll have them run some long range scans of the Devron System... if they find anything, I'll let you know.

quote: That's not good enough.

scene: 42   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

scene: 42   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

quote: Yes. There was an outbreak of Terrellian Plague on Romulus. The Klingons have been allowing Federation medical ships to cross the border.
scene: 42   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

quote: Yes... yes...
scene: 42   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

quote: So now all we need is a medical ship.
scene: 42   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

quote: I think I can arrange that. Find the USS Pasteur. I have some pull with the Captain. At least, I used to...
scene: 42   INT. DATA'S LIBRARY - FUTURE - LATE AFTERNOON

quote: Well... this is a page out of the past. I never thought I'd see any one of you on a starship again. Data, Geordi...
Let's just... choose one.
Well. Did you get my message?
Yes. Jean-Luc... going into Klingon territory -- it's insane. But I never could say no to you.
Ah. So that's why you married me.
Now... the first order of business is to get clearance to cross the Klingon border.
What about Worf? Isn't he still on the Klingon High Council?
I'm not sure. Information on the Klingon political structure is hard to come by these days. However, at last report Worf was governor of H'atoria, a small Klingon colony near the border.
Worf... yes, that's it... that's the answer. Worf. He'll help us. Let's make it so.
Captain Picard?
Yes?
Yes?
Captain, McKinley Station is signalling. They want to know when we'll be docking.
Tell McKinley that we've been called away on a priority mission. We won't be docking.
Aye, sir.
Kept the name, eh?
I've prepared quarters for you on Deck Five if you'd like some rest.
I'm fine. I don't need any rest.
Nell, please escort the Ambassador to his quarters--
I can find my way around a starship!
You're all treating me like an invalid, but I assure you I've got a few years left. I don't need to be led around and I don't want to be patronized.
You're right. I'm sorry.
I'll go have a rest.
How long since he's had a neurological scan?
I'm not sure, but don't waste your time suggesting it. He says he's not taking "any more damn tests."
Do you believe he's moving through time?
I don't know if I do, either... but -- he's Jean-Luc Picard. And if he wants to go on one more mission, that's what we're going to do.
Ensign Chilton, set course for H'atoria.
We'll find the anomaly... I know we will...
Report.
We're nearing the coordinates you gave me, sir.
Is there anything unusual in the vicinity?
How would you define unusual, sir? Every region of space has unique properties that cannot be found anywhere else.
There should be a... "barrier" of some sort nearby. A large plasma field... highly disruptive.
Nothing, sir.
It's the right time... right place... he should be here...
Who, sir?
Q! We're here! This has gone on long enough! What sort of game are you playing?
Counselor, do you sense an alien presence?
No, sir.
What is a... "Q"?
It's a letter of the alphabet, as far as I know.
This is not the way it's supposed to happen... Maintain position here. I'll be in my Ready Room.
Mon Capitan... I thought you'd never get here.
Q... I thought so. What's going on?
It's Judge Q to you. And isn't it obvious what's going on?
The last time I stood in this courtroom was seven years ago...
"Seven years ago... " How little you mortals understand time. Must you be so linear, Jean-Luc?
You accused me of being the representative of a barbarous species...
I believe my exact words were "a dangerous, savage, child-race."
But we demonstrated that mankind has become peaceful and benevolent. You agreed, and let us go on our way. Why do I find myself back in this courtroom?
You'd like me to connect the dots for you. Lead you from A... to B... to C... so your puny mind can comprehend.
How boring. They would be so much more entertained if you tried to figure this out...
I'll answer any ten questions that call for a "yes" or a "no." Well?
Are you putting mankind on trial again?
No.
Is there any connection at all between the trial seven years ago... and whatever's going on now?
Hmmmmm... I would have to say... yes.
The spatial anomaly in the Neutral Zone -- is it related to what's happening?
Oh, most definitely yes.
Is it part of a Romulan plot? A ploy to start a war?
No... and no. Five down.
That's only four --
"Is it a Romulan plot?" "Is it a ploy to start a war?" Those are separate questions.
Did you create the anomaly?
No, no, no. You're going to be so surprised when you realize where it came from -- if you ever figure it out.
Are you responsible for my shifting through time?
I'll answer that if you promise you won't tell anyone. Yes.
Why?
Oh, I'm sorry. That's not a "yes or no" question. You forfeit the rest of your questions.
I expected as much. You're such a limited creature... a perfect example of why we've made our decision.
The trial never ended, Captain. We never reached a verdict. But, now we have: you're guilty.
Guilty of what?
Of being inferior.
Seven years ago I said we'd be watching you. And we have been. Hoping your ape-like race would demonstrate some growth... give some indication that your minds have room for expansion.

And what have we seen instead? You spending time worrying about Commander Riker's career... listening to Counselor Troi's pedantic psychobabble... indulging Data in his witless exploration of humanity...
We have journeyed to countless new worlds... made contact with new species... expanded man's understanding of the universe...
In your own paltry, limited way. You have no idea how far you still have to go.
We are what we are, Q -- and we're doing the best we can. It's not for you to set the standard by which we're judged.
Oh, but it is. And we have. Time may be eternal -- but our patience is not.
Having rendered a verdict... have you decided upon a sentence?
Indeed. It's time to put an end to your trek through the stars... to make room for other, more worthy species.
We're to be denied travel through space?
Q... even you could not be capable of such an act --
I? There you go again, blaming me for everything. Well, this time I'm not your enemy. I am not the one who causes the annihilation of mankind. You are.
Me...
That's right. You're doing it right now... you've already done it... and you will do it yet again.
What sort of meaningless doubletalk is that?

He doesn't understand. I have only myself to blame, I suppose. I believed in you... I thought you had potential... but apparently I was wrong. May whatever God you believe in have mercy on your soul. This court stands adjourned.
Commander, assemble the Senior Staff and go to Red Alert. We have a bigger problem than we thought.
I don't believe him. This has to be another one of Q's games. He's probably listening to us right now, getting a big laugh out of watching us jump through his hoops.
I think that this time, we have no choice but to take him at his word... which means that in some fashion, I will cause the destruction of humanity.
But didn't Q say you already had caused it?
And that you were causing it now...
Given the fact that there is an apparent discontinuity between the three time periods the Captain is visiting, Q's statement may be accurate, if confusing.
So what should I do -- just lock myself in a room in all three time periods?
No. Maybe not acting is what causes the destruction of mankind. What if you were needed on the Bridge at a key moment, and weren't there?
We can't start second-guessing ourselves. I think we have to proceed normally... deal with each situation as it occurs...
Agreed. I've been thinking about my conversation with Q. He admitted that he was responsible for my shifting through time...
It occurred to me... that perhaps Q is giving me a chance to save mankind somehow.
What makes you say that?
Q has always shown a certain... fascination with humanity... and specifically with me. I think he has more than a casual interest in what happens to me.
That is true. Q's interest in you is very similar to that of a master and a beloved pet.
That was only an analogy, Captain.

If I weren't traveling through time... I would never have realized that the anomaly in the Neutral Zone appeared there in the past as well. Assuming that's an important piece of a larger puzzle, my ability to shift through time may be the key to understanding what's going on.
Bridge to Captain Picard.
Go ahead.
We're approaching the Neutral Zone, Captain.
On our way.
All stop. Initiate a long range scan.
There are four Warbirds holding position on the Romulan side of the Neutral Zone, Captain.
The Federation Starships Concord and Bozeman are holding position on our side.
Face-off. The question is, who's going to move first?
We are. Mister Worf, hail the Romulan flagship.
The Warbird Terix is responding.
On screen.
Captain Picard.
Hello, Worf. It's been a long time.
Doctor... it is good to see you again.
Did you have a chance to read our request?
Yes. But you must realize... I am no longer a member of the High Council.
You are the Governor of the H'atoria Colony.
It is merely a ceremonial position given me when the house of Mogh was forced from power.
Worf, surely you still have some influence. We must get into the Neutral Zone.
Can't you at least grant us permission to cross the border?

I must refuse. It is for your own safety -- the Neutral Zone is extremely volatile. If Admiral Riker had given you a starship with a cloak, you would have been safe. I cannot believe he refused to help you.
I don't care what kind of ship we're in -- the important thing is to get to the Devron System --
I am sorry, but my first duty is to the Empire. I must adhere to regulations.

Maybe I'm just an old man who doesn't understand... but the Worf I knew cared more about things like loyalty and honor than he did rules and regulations. But then, that was a long time ago. Maybe you're not the Worf I knew.
Dor-sHo GHA!
You have always used your knowledge of Klingon honor and tradition to get what you want from me.
That's because it always works. Your problem, Worf, is that you really do have a sense of honor... you really do care about things like loyalty and trust. Don't blame me because I know you too well.
Very well. You may cross the border. But only if I come with you. I am familiar with the Neutral Zone.
Terms accepted.
Inform Transporter Room Two to beam the Governor aboard.
I just want to make one thing clear, Jean-Luc. If we run into any serious opposition, I'm taking us back to Federation territory. We aren't well armed and we wouldn't last long in a fight.
Governor Worf is aboard, Captain.
All right. Ensign, set course for the Devron System. Warp thirteen.
Once more, for old time's sake?
Engage.
Engage to where, sir?
Set course for the Devron System, and engage at warp nine.
The Devron System is inside the Neutral Zone, sir.
I'm aware of that, Lieutenant. Carry out my orders, Chief.
Aye, sir.
Captain... may I have a word with you in private?
Of course. Lieutenant, contact Farpoint Station. I want to talk to Commander Riker.
Aye, sir.
Captain, I just want to voice my concerns about the way the crew is responding to your... unexpected orders.
They don't trust me... they think I'm behaving erratically.
Some do... others are confused... it takes some time for a new crew to get to know their Captain, and for him to know them.
I understand that. But I know what this crew is capable of, even if they don't.
I'm happy to hear you say that. It may do them good to hear it, as well... It would also help if they knew what was going on.
I know it's difficult operating in the dark, Counselor. But for now, I think it's the only choice.
Perhaps if you could at least indicate why --
Yar to Captain Picard. I have Commander Riker for you, sir.
Put him through in here.
Commander. I just wanted to let you know we'll be delayed in picking you up at Farpoint Station.
I see. May I ask how long?
I'm not sure. I'll keep you updated. Please inform Doctor Crusher and Lieutenant La Forge of our delay.
Understood.
Is there anything else, Counselor?
Actually... there is, sir. I've been debating whether or not to mention it... but perhaps... It's about Commander Riker.
What about him?
Well... I think you should know that we... have had a prior relationship.
I see. Do you anticipate this interfering with your duties?
No, sir. It was several years ago. And it's well behind us both. But I thought you should know...
I appreciate your telling me... but I'm sure the two of you will find a way to... deal with the situation.
Tea. Earl Grey. Hot.
That beverage has not been programmed into the replication system.
So Captain... how long shall we stare at each other across the Neutral Zone?
There is another alternative, Tomolak. We're both here for the same reason. We could each send one ship into the Neutral Zone to investigate the anomaly in the Devron System.
Has Starfleet Command approved this arrangement?
No.
I like it already. Agreed. One ship from each side... but I warn you -- if another Federation starship tries to enter the Zone...
You needn't make threats. I think we're all aware of the consequences.
Very well. I'll see you in the Devron system.
Set course for the Devron system. Warp five. Engage.
Sensors are picking up a large subspace anomaly directly ahead.
All stop. On screen.
Full scan, Mister Data.
Aye, sir.
We are approaching the Devron system, Captain. Sensors are picking up a large subspace anomaly directly ahead.
All stop. Put it onscreen.
It's bigger in the past...
Sir?
Nothing. Full scan, Mister Data.
Aye, sir.
On screen! On screen! Let's see it!
As you can see, sir -- there's nothing there.
Still nothing, Captain. I've conducted a full sensor sweep out to one light year from the Pasteur. No temporal anomalies, no particle fluctuations... nothing.
Have you scanned the entire subspace bandwidth?
Yes. The subspace barrier is a little thin in this region of space, but that's not unusual.
I don't understand. I've already seen it in the other two -- the other two time periods. Why isn't it here?
Captain. I have been monitoring Klingon communication channels... several warships have been dispatched to this sector to search for a... renegade Federation vessel.
You're not thinking about leaving?
Jean-Luc, there's nothing here...
There should be -- there has to be!
Data, there must be some other way to scan for temporal disturbances... something that's not covered in a normal sensor sweep.
There are several methods of detecting temporal disturbances, but we're limited by the equipment on the Pasteur. This ship is designed primarily for medical emergencies.
Jean-Luc, we've done all we can... we should head back to Federation territory.
However, it may be possible to modify the main deflector to emit an inverse tachyon pulse, which could scan beyond the subspace barrier.
Very good! Make it so!
Wait a minute... Data, how long would this take?
To make the modifications and search the entire Devron System will take approximately fourteen hours.
All right. Data, begin modifying the tachyon pulse. Ensign Chilton, lay in a course back to the Federation. If we haven't found anything in six hours, we're heading back at maximum warp.
Aye, sir.
Six hours may not be enough. We have to stay here until we find it -- no matter how long it takes!
Carry out my orders. May I see you for a moment?
Beverly, I can't believe you're not willing to stay here until --
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: Don't you ever question my orders on the Bridge of my ship again!
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: I'm just trying to... there are larger concerns here... don't you understand that --
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: I understand that you would never have tolerated that kind of behavior back on the Enterprise -- and I won't here. I don't care if you're my ex-Captain or my ex-husband.
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: You're right... I was out of line... it won't happen again... But, you have to understand... the stakes here are enormous. Q has said all of humanity will be destroyed...
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: I know. And that's why I'm willing to stay here a while longer and keep looking. But I also want you to consider the possibility that none of what you're saying is real.
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: What... ?
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: Jean-Luc, I care for you too much not to tell you the truth. You have advanced Irumodic Syndrome. I have to consider the possibility that all of this is in your mind. I'll stay here six hours... and then we're heading home.
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: And I want you to remember, if it were anyone but you... we wouldn't be here at all.
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: Eh? What was that she said, sonny? I couldn't quite hear her...
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: Q... what's going on here? Where's the anomaly?
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: Where's your mommy? I don't know...
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: Stop this foolishness and answer me!
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: There is an answer, Jean-Luc. But I can't hand it to you. Although you do have help...
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: What help?
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: You aren't alone, you know... what you were... and what you will become... are always with you.
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: My time shifting... the answer does lie there... Just tell me one thing... this anomaly we're looking for... is that what destroys humanity?
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: You're forgetting, Jean-Luc. You destroy humanity.
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: By doing what? When? How are you --
scene: 72   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - READY ROOM - FUTURE

quote: Report, Mister Data.
The anomaly is two hundred million kilometers in diameter. It is a highly focused temporal energy source which is emitting approximately the same energy output as ten G-type stars.
What is the source of that energy?
I am uncertain. Sensors have been unable to penetrate the anomaly.
What if we modified the main deflector to emit an... inverse tachyon pulse. That might scan beyond the subspace barrier... give us an idea what the interior of this thing looks like.
That is a most intriguing idea, Captain. I do not believe a tachyon beam was ever put to such use. I had no idea you were so versed in the intricacies of temporal theory.
I have some friends who are quite well versed in the matter. Make it so.
Aye, sir.
I believe we can make the necessary modifications in Main Engineering.
We can get more power if we reroute the primary EPS taps to the deflector array...
Agreed.
Initiating tachyon pulse...
Okay... the pulse is holding steady... we're starting to receive data from the scan...
It will take the computer some time to give us a complete picture of the anomaly's interior. I suggest we --
Whoa...
What is wrong?
I'm not sure... oh... it's like somebody put an ice pick through my temples... My VISOR's picking up all kinds of electromagnetic distortions.
Data to Sickbay. Medical emergency in Main Engineering.
Look at his eyes... you can see the difference yourself.
Yes... I can see the iris...
This is amazing. The DNA in his optic nerves is being regenerated...
It's as if he were growing new eyes.
I guess that's why I started to feel pain... my optical cortex was falling out of alignment with my VISOR.
How is this possible?
It shouldn't be possible at all. There's no medical explanation for the spontaneous regeneration of an organ.
Doctor... we've just gotten reports from two crewmembers who say they have injuries... which are healing themselves.
I believe I may have a partial explanation, Captain.
I have completed my analysis of the anomaly. It appears to be a multi-phasic temporal convergence in the space-time continuum.
In English please.
It is, in essence, an eruption of... anti-time.
Anti-time?
A relatively new concept in temporal mechanics. The relationship of anti-time to normal time is analogous to the relationship of anti-matter to normal matter.
So if time and anti-time were to collide...
They would annihilate each other... creating a rupture in space. I believe this is what has happened in the Devron System.
The rupture may be sending out waves of temporal energy which are disrupting the normal flow of time.
Then it's possible the DNA molecules in Geordi's optic nerves aren't regenerating themselves... They might be reverting to their original state.
You mean his eyes are getting... younger?
For all intents and purposes, yes.
So the temporal anomaly has certain... rejuvenating effects. It certainly doesn't sound like the destruction of humanity. Data, what could have caused this collision between time and anti-time?
Anti-time, sir?
I believe that if we modify the deflector to send out an inverse tachyon pulse, you'll find that the anomaly is a rupture between time and anti-time.
That is a fascinating hypothesis... how did you formulate --
It would take too long to explain. Begin the modifications and send out the pulse. Once you've done that, start working on a theory as to what could have caused this rupture.
Aye, sir.
Mister O'Brien... how big is the anomaly?
Approximately four hundred million kilometers in diameter, sir.
I still don't understand why it's larger here...
Captain... there are five Terrellian transport ships holding position in the Devron system.
We're being hailed by the lead ship.
On screen.
Enterprise, you are a welcome sight. We've been receiving threats from the Romulan Empire ever since we entered the Neutral Zone. I'm glad to see you're here to protect us.
Why have you come here?
We heard about the Light... from a merchant ship who told us about the power it has to heal illness... to rejuvenate the elderly... and we had to come here.
We can't really be certain that the... Light... has this power. And there may be dangers, side effects we're not aware of...
I have five ships full of sick and dying people, Captain. If there's even a chance it's true, I can't turn back now.
It would be safer for all concerned if you left the Neutral Zone... and let us investigate the phenomenon more fully.
No. I've come too far.
I warn you that if the Romulans should decide to intervene, I may not be able to protect you.
I understand. We'll take that risk. Good luck, Captain.
You have the Bridge, Lieutenant. I'll be in my Ready Room.
Aye, sir.
What's going on?
scene: 82   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - BRIDGE - FUTURE - CONTINUOUS

quote: We're under attack.
scene: 82   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - BRIDGE - FUTURE - CONTINUOUS

quote: Shield strength down to fifty-two percent. Minor damage to the port nacelle.
scene: 82   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - BRIDGE - FUTURE - CONTINUOUS

quote: Two Klingon attack cruisers have decloaked to port and starboard.
scene: 82   INT. MEDICAL SHIP - BRIDGE - FUTURE - CONTINUOUS

quote: Warp speed -- get us out of here!
Warp power is off-line, sir.
Heading one-four-eight, mark two-one-five. Full impulse.
Impulse power is fluctuating... shields down to thirty percent.
Weapons status?
These phasers are no match for their shields.
Geordi, we need warp power -- now.
Sorry, Captain, they're just too much for us. I can't keep the phase inducers on-line --
Shields down to nine percent. One more hit and they'll collapse.
Open a channel. This is Captain Beverly Picard. We're a medical ship on a mission of mercy! Break off your --
Worf, signal our surrender.
Tos Vah'cha Worf, do'lo jegh! (This is Governor Worf, we surrender!)
Our shields have collapsed. We're defenseless.
Captain, there's another ship de-cloaking -- bearing two-one-five mark three-one-oh... It's the Enterprise!
They're hailing us.
I had a feeling you weren't going to listen to me. Stand by while I try to get the Klingons' attention...
The Enterprise is drawing their fire.
Damage report.
Our warp core's badly damaged... there's a breach in progress.
Warp core breach... that may be it. We have to stop it!
The Klingon ship is disengaging. Admiral Riker is hailing us.
Our sensors indicate your ship has a warp core breach in progress. Prepare for emergency beam-out.
All the Pasteur crew is safely aboard, Admiral.
Raise shields. Where are the Klingons?
They're still moving off, sir -- half a light year away.
They'll be back...
As I said -- I figured you weren't going to take no for answer.
But I thought you would have more sense. I can't believe you let a defenseless ship cross into hostile territory without an escort.
If you had not turned down the Captain when he came to you for help, none of this would have happened. Unlike you, I still have a sense of loyalty and honor...
We don't have time for this. The Pasteur's core is going to breach.
Move us away. Full impulse.
All right. Let's get out of here.
No... we can't... we have to save humanity...
Engage cloak.
Our cloak isn't functioning. We took a direct hit to the starboard plasma coil. Engineering reports seven hours until we can cloak again.
We'll have to do this the old-fashioned way. Lay in a course back to the Federation. Warp thirteen.
Wil, don't leave! We have to stay here -- find the cause of the temporal anomaly...
Captain, we can't stay...
We have to! Everything depends on this! We can't leave now -- please listen to me!
Jean-Luc. I'll be right back, Alissa.
Alissa lost the baby.

I think it's the same thing that happened to Geordi. Somehow, the temporal energy from the anomaly caused the fetal tissue to revert to an earlier stage of development. It was as if the unborn child began to... grow younger... until finally the DNA itself began to break down.
How is she?
Physically, she's fine. For now. But if this temporal reversion continues, I don't think any of us are going to be fine for much longer.
So this is affecting the entire crew...
Our cellular structures appear to be coalescing... reverting to earlier structures.
In some cases, this has caused old injuries to be healed... but that's only a temporary effect. Eventually, this could kill us all.

We also have to find out how widespread this effect is. Send an inquiry to Starbase Twenty-three -- they're the nearest outpost -- have them begin checking their personnel for any signs of temporal reversion.
Aye, sir.
Mister Data, how long until we've completed the tachyon scan?
Approximately one hour, forty-five minutes.
Good. Once it's completed, I want you to find a way to dissipate the anomaly without making things worse. Give me a risk analysis on whatever solution you come up with.
Aye, sir.
Dismissed.
That's a pretty big decision, Jean-Luc...
Tinkering with an anomaly you know nothing about... trying to collapse it... isn't that risky?
Why? Will that cause the destruction of mankind?
Maybe... On the other hand, maybe leaving it alone would be the wrong thing to do...
It's a big decision, all right... Perhaps it would help to get a different perspective...
Welcome home.
Home?

Don't you recognize your old stomping grounds? This is Earth -- France. About... oh... three and a half billion years ago. Give or take an eon or two. Smells awful, doesn't it... all that sulfur and volcanic ash... I really must speak to the maid.
Is there a point to all this?
Look --
The anomaly is here, at Earth... ?
At this point in history, the anomaly has filled this entire quadrant of your galaxy.
The further back in time... the larger the anomaly.
(suddenly sees something) oh, oh -- come here, there's something I want to show you!
See this? This is you.
I'm serious. Right here, life is about to form on this planet for the very first time. A group of amino acids is about to combine and form the first protein.
The building blocks of what you call "life".

Strange, isn't it, Jean-Luc? Everything you know... your entire civilization... it all begins right here in this little pond of goo. It's appropriate somehow, isn't it? Too bad you didn't bring a microscope -- this is quite fascinating.
Here they go... the amino acids are moving closer... closer... closer... Ohhhh! Nothing happened! You see what you've done?
You mean I caused the anomaly... and the anomaly... in some way... disrupted the beginning of life on Earth.
Congratulations.

Captain, I've just spoken to Doctor Selar... she said that twenty-three children on board have contracted some kind of illness. Their tissues appear to be... reverting to an earlier stage of development. She thinks it has something to do with the anomaly.
Inform Starfleet Command that we believe the anomaly has toxic effects. Tell them I'm ordering the Terrellian ships back to Federation territory, but that we're staying here.
We are?
Yes. We have to find a way to collapse this anomaly. Counselor, prepare to evacuate all civilians and non-essential personnel to the Terrellians ships.
Aye, sir.
Data, O'Brien, you're with me.
Let's concentrate on how this anomaly was initially formed. Speculation?
Temporal ruptures in the spacetime continuum are rarely a naturally occurring phenomenon. It is therefore most likely that this anomaly was caused by an outside catalyst.
Like a warp core explosion...
I think I can rule out a warp core explosion.
Our tachyon pulse has been unable to penetrate the anomaly completely. If we had information about the center of the phenomenon, we might have a basis for speculation.
Can you find a way to scan the interior?
I've tried everything I know of... there's just too much interference. There's nothing on board that'll do the job.
Do you know what could?

In theory, a tomographic imaging scanner capable of multiphasic resolution would be able to penetrate this much interference. The Daystrom Institute has been working on such a device, but it is still only theoretical.
Data... do we have a tomographic imaging scanner on board?
Yes, sir.
Can you use it to scan the interior of the anomaly?
Possibly.
(continuing, off console) There is a great deal of interference... but I am getting some readings. This is very unusual...
What is it?

It appears that our tachyon pulse is converging with two other tachyon pulses at the center of the anomaly. The other two pulses have the exact same amplitude modulation as our own pulse. It is as if all three originated from the Enterprise.
Three pulses... from three time periods... all converging at one point in space.
Captain, what are you suggesting?
Computer, where's Admiral Riker?
Admiral Riker is in Ten Forward.
The ship has held up pretty well over the years.
They were going to decommission her about five years ago... but one nice thing about being an Admiral is getting to choose your own ship.
Wil... how long is this thing between you and Worf going to go on?
It's been going on for twenty years now... doesn't look like it's going to end any time soon.
I suspect the last thing Counselor Troi would have wanted is for the two of you to be alienated.
I agree. It's time to put this behind you.
I tried -- at Deanna's funeral. He wouldn't talk to me.
Might have been tough for him then... he took her death pretty hard.
Yeah, well... he wasn't the only one.
I know. But in his mind... you were the reason he and Deanna never got together.
I didn't do anything to stand in his way --
Didn't you, Wil?
Did I?
I just... never could admit it was over. I kept thinking one day we'd get together again... and then... she was gone. You think you've got all the time in the world, until...
Yeah.
Ensign. How... do I get to Ten Forward?
Two decks up, sir. Section zero zero five.
Thank you.
Oh, my god.
Wil! I know what's happening... I know what causes the anomaly... we have to go back!
Jean-Luc... the only place you're going back to is bed.
Damnit Wil, I know what's happening. We're causing the anomaly... with a... with the tachyon pulse... it happened in all three time periods. We do it in all three time periods!
Jean-Luc, you better come with me.

Leave me alone! I'm not crazy. The tachyon pulses... they -- they were used in the same spot -- in all three time periods... don't you see? When the tachyon pulse used the -- I mean, when the Pasteur used the tachyon pulse, we set the -- you know -- we... started everything... we set it in motion.
It's like... the chicken and the egg! You think it started back then... but it didn't... it started here in the future... that's why it gets larger in the past...
I think I understand what the Captain is saying. If I'm not mistaken, he is describing a paradox.
Yes! Yes, exactly!
Intriguing... it is possible we could've created the very anomaly we have been looking for.

Let us assume for the moment, that the Captain has indeed been travelling through time. Let us also assume he has initiated an inverse tachyon pulse at the same coordinates in space in all three time periods. In that case, it is possible that the convergence of three tachyon pulses could've ruptured the subspace barrier and caused an anti-time reaction.
I see where you're going. And because anti-time operates in the opposite way normal time does, the effects would run backwards through the spacetime continuum.
Yes! That's why the anomaly was larger in the past. It was growing as it travelled backward through time.
All right... let's say for the moment, you're right. What do we do about it?
Go back. Go back to the Devron System.
He may be right. If we return to the Devron System now, we might see the initial formation of the anomaly.
Riker to Bridge. Set course for the Devron System. Maximum warp.
Aye, sir.
Worf... we could use a hand.
Entering the Devron System, sir.
All stop.
Sensors are picking up a small temporal anomaly off the port bow.
On screen.
I was right...
It's an anti-time eruption. It seems to have formed in the last six hours.
We've got to stop it here... so it won't be able to travel back through time...
All right, Data -- we need a solution and we need it fast.
The anomaly is being sustained by the continuing tachyon pulses from the other two time periods. I suggest they be shut down.
The next time I'm there, that's the first thing I'll do.
Isn't there more we can do here... seal the rupture somehow?
I am investigating the options.
Data, disengage the tachyon pulse.
Sir?
Just do it. The convergence of tachyon pulses from the three time periods is what causes the anomaly.
Aye, sir.
Report. Is there any change in the anomaly?
No, sir.
Disengage the tachyon pulse.
We haven't finished the scan, sir.
I know that. But it's imperative that you disengage it immediately.
Aye, sir. Disengaging.
Why isn't the anomaly affected?
Why would it be, sir?
I've shut off the tachyon pulses in the other time periods -- but the anomaly didn't change.
It remains unaffected here as well.
What do we do?
The only way to stop this thing is to repair the rupture at the focal point where time and anti-time are converging.
How do we do that?
It would require taking the ship into the anomaly itself. Once inside, we may be able to use our engines to create a static warp shell.
Yeah, yeah... and the shell would act like an artificial subspace barrier -- separating time and anti-time...
Collapsing the anomaly and restoring the normal flow of time. But this would have to be done in the other two time periods, as well.
That could be a problem... the anomaly's so much larger in the other time periods...
