quote: Riker to senior staff. Please report to the observation lounge. Mission briefing in ten minutes.
scene: 1    INT. GEORDI'S QUARTERS - ANGLE ON DOOR

quote: Okay, we have to get her out from under there. I'll scare her -- you grab her when she comes out.
scene: 1    INT. GEORDI'S QUARTERS - ANGLE ON DOOR

quote: I do not think it would be wise to startle her --
scene: 1    INT. GEORDI'S QUARTERS - ANGLE ON DOOR

quote: Now!
scene: 1    INT. GEORDI'S QUARTERS - ANGLE ON DOOR

quote: Uh-oh...
scene: 1    INT. GEORDI'S QUARTERS - ANGLE ON DOOR

quote: Training. Definitely.
scene: 1    INT. GEORDI'S QUARTERS - ANGLE ON DOOR

quote: Captain's Log, Stardate 47310.2. We are investigating the disappearance of the Medical Transport Fleming somewhere in the Hekaras Corridor. Our search is complicated by the unique properties of this particular region of space.
The Fleming's last contact with Starfleet was four days ago. They didn't report anything out of the ordinary when they entered the Corridor...
The unusually intense tetryon fields in this sector pose a severe navigational hazard to warpdriven vessels...
The Hekaras Corridor is the only route through the area which is free of tetryon fields. Ships travelling at warp must use the Corridor to ensure safe passage through the region.
How long will it take to complete a level-one search?
At least two days, sir. The Corridor is over twelve lightyears long, and the surrounding tetryon interference will limit our sensor range.
Could we send out reconnaissance probes to supplement the sensors?

They won't be very effective. The interference will make it difficult to maintain contact with the probes; the best we can do is to try increasing the sensor efficiency. We're installing multi-phase buffers on all the sensor modules. It should help a little.
Hekaras Two is inhabited, isn't it? Maybe they've had contact with the Fleming.
They haven't. I've already spoken with the Hekaran government.
According to them, only one ship has passed through their system in the last week... and that was a Ferengi trader.
The Fleming was carrying a supply of bio-mimetic gel... it's rare and quite valuable. Do you think it's possible the Ferengi could have hijacked it?
I wouldn't put it past them. We should be prepared for that contingency.
Agreed.
All right then. Mister Worf, initiate your search pattern. Let's head in.
Geordi, we have experienced a slight drop in sensor efficiency. Commander Riker would like us to examine the phase buffers.
No problem, Data... I'll be with you in a minute...
All right, Hansen, transfer EPS conduit thirteen through the stabilizer matrix.
Aye, sir.
Geordi, is there a problem with the engines?
No, not really...
Then why are you stabilizing the EPS conduit?
I'm just trying to get a slightly higher power conversion level...
That would not affect the engines in any way.
I know. That's not the point.
Then... what is "the point?"
I just... want the best conversion level I can get.
Why?

It's the Intrepid. Their Chief Engineer is Commander Donald Kaplan. We went through the Academy together. And... I kind of like to make sure our power conversion level is... a little higher than theirs.
I understand. You are in competition with Mister Kaplan.
No, it's not really a competition... This is the flagship. It just seems to me -- we should be better than the rest.
That does sound like a competitive position.
It's more a matter of personal pride. I mean... these are my engines.
But you are trying to outperform the Intrepid.
Well... yeah.
Computer. How much have the conversion levels increased?
Levels are unchanged.
All right, we'll deal with of this later...
Let's take a look at those sensors.
Okay -- how's that?
The phase buffer is functioning within normal parameters. Sensor efficiency has increased six-point-seven percent.
Only six-point-seven? One of the stages must still be out of alignment... Let's check out junction A-nine.
Geordi, I have taken your suggestion regarding Spot.
What suggestion?
I have begun to train her. I am currently testing several techniques.
Really...
I began with simple conditioned response exercises and followed with various environmental enhancements. Next I intend to explore bio-conditioning devices.
Devices?
Such as sensor nets for behavior modification... or bio-feedback motivators... Unfortunately, I have been largely unsuccessful...
How about a phaser? A low stun setting at the right moment might do the trick...
Geordi. I will not stun my cat.
I was just kidding...
This isn't it, either.
There is clearly a misalignment somewhere in this system.
That's for sure... There's one more possibility... let's take a look at junction C-twelve...
I am somewhat concerned that my training efforts will ultimately fail...
Well, maybe you're just going about it the wrong way.
I have consulted numerous animal behavior manuals; several of them claim that cats are inherently untrainable.
I don't believe that. My sister didn't know a thing about animals and she was able to train her cat. How complicated could it be?
What did she train her cat to do?
Well... her cat would jump into her arms on command.
That is interesting. Perhaps I could modify your sister's technique to keep Spot off my console. Do you know how she was able to train her cat?
Well, as I recall, she had to walk around for about two months with a piece of tuna in her blouse...
I was right... this buffer is out of alignment... All right... how's that?
The phase alignment is stabilizing...
However, sensor efficiency has only increased an additional one-point-three percent.
Well, that's not much, but every little bit helps.
Riker to Data.
Data here.
We're picking up a ship ahead on long range sensors. If you and Geordi are through down there, we'd like to have you on the Bridge.
We've squeezed as much out of these systems as we're going to get.
Acknowledged, sir. We are on our way.
We are within visual range, sir.
On screen.
This is the same Ferengi ship that entered the Corridor a week ago.
Captain, there are no emissions from their plasma vents. Their warp drive must be completely inactive.
That is correct, sir. Their impulse systems appear to be down as well... power generation is at extremely low levels.
What about life signs?
Life support is also functioning, at low levels. There are approximately four-hundred fifty Ferengi on board. That is a standard complement for a vessel of this class.
Mister Worf, open a hailing frequency.
No response on any channel, sir.
I'm not reading any subspace emissions from their ship at all, sir. It looks like every one of their field coils has been overloaded.
That would explain why they didn't respond to our hails...
It would also explain the failure of their warp drive.

Sir, the Feregni sensors are still functioning. I could modify one of our deflector emitters to transmit old-style delta waves... if I modulate that with a com signal, the Ferengi should be able to pick it up.
Make it so.
Well, if they did hijack the Fleming, they certainly didn't get very far with the cargo.
Mister Worf, have tractor beams standing by... we may have to take them under tow... Helm, bring us within tractor range...
Captain, I am picking up power emissions from the Ferengi ship... They are locking weapons!
Raise shields --
Ready phasers. Prepare to return fire.
Target their weapons array only.
Phasers locked.
Fire.
Direct hit. Their weapon systems are down.
Damage report.
We sustained minimal damage on decks five and seven, sir.
Sir, the Ferengi ship's power has stabilized... they appear to have impulse capability.
They were just playing dead... conserving power until we got in close enough.
But why attack us in the first place?
Somehow I don't think they're going to let us beam over and ask them...
Mister La Forge, how are you coming with that com link?
Almost ready, sir...
We can give it a try.
Open a channel.
This is Captain Jean-Luc Picard of the Enterprise. Please explain your attack on my ship.
Our attack? We were defending ourselves. Do you deny that you are responsible for disabling my vessel?
Your ship was adrift and your communications inoperative. We were attempting to ascertain your status.

You were attempting to move in for the kill. Do not toy with me, Picard... we are obviously at your mercy. But know this: when the Ferengi Council learns of your actions, they will consider this an act of war.
Daimon, there has clearly been a misunderstanding here. I believe it would be in everyone's best interests if you came aboard and we discussed the situation.
I see no reason to trust you, hewman.
Then I suppose we'll be on our way... If you wish, I'll relay your position to your government... in case you're unable to complete repairs... and remain stranded here.
Perhaps it would be better to discuss the situation...

We detected what appeared to be a Federation signal buoy. When we approached it, it emitted a massive verteron pulse... our warp drive, our sensors, our communications systems were all disabled. We assumed we were the victims of a new Federation weapon.
Daimon Prak. The Federation established this Corridor to ensure a safe route through the sector. We have nothing to gain from mining it.
Whatever happened to your ship may not be an isolated incident. A Federation Medical transport was recently lost in the Corridor.
We passed a Federation ship several days ago. It did not appear to be in any distress.
Can you give us an idea of their heading?
It's possible that information was recorded in our sensor logs, Commander. Unfortunately, my entire crew is occupied with our repairs. I don't know if there will be time to search our records.
Perhaps if we assigned an engineering team to assist with the repair efforts... would that give you time to retrieve your logs?
I believe it would, Captain.
Spot -- down.
Spot -- down.
Spot -- down.
This is up. Up is no.
This is down. Down is good.
Come in.
Data. I had another idea that might help boost our power conversion levels. Could you give me a hand?
I would be happy to.
Don't tell me you're training her to use the console.
As part of her training program, I am teaching Spot to jump down from the desk on my command.
How's it going?
I have not been entirely successful...
Feline supplement two-hundred twenty-one.
That cat has definitely got a mind of her own, Data. Maybe she's just not trainable.
I suppose I must accept that possibility. It may be that Spot lacks the intelligence necessary to learn the appropriate responses to my commands.
Maybe. But I think your training is coming along quite nicely.
Come on, Data, let's go.
Okay, Data, keep the EPS flow constant while I re-modulate the power taps.
This procedure could only boost the conversion level by -- point-eight percent.
That's all right... it might be enough.
Enough?
Commander Kaplan just sent me this on subspace.
"La Forge. I've got Intrepid's power conversion level up to ninety-seven-point-one percent. Maybe you should try cleaning your plasma grid once in a while."
Can you believe the nerve of this guy... ?
We perform maintenance on the plasma grid at regular intervals.
Of course we do -- he's just trying to get me angry.
That should do it... Computer, what is the current power conversion level?
Power conversion level is ninety-seven-point-two percent.
Too bad, Mister Kaplan...
Captain's Log, Stardate, 47311.4. Based on the Ferengi sensor logs, we have traced the Fleming's most likely course. It now appears that the vessel may have come to an unfortunate end.
What's the origin of this debris field?
Unknown, sir. It does not appear on any Federation charts of the Corridor.
Could it be what's left of the Fleming?

It is a possibility. The debris consists primarily of duranium and poly-composite fragments which suggests it could be from a ship. Furthermore, the field contains sufficient mass to account for the Fleming.
All right... let's take a closer look. Perhaps we can find something to give us a positive identification.
Helm, plot a course through the debris field. Ahead slow.
Captain, I am picking up a small, metallic object, approximately three-point-five meters in diameter...
It could be a ship's log recorder... or a probe casing.
I do not believe so... it is emitting an unusual signal ... Sir, it is beginning to generate a verteron field.
Shields up! Full reverse, now!
Damage report.
Warp engines are off-line... shields are down... all subspace systems are inoperative...
Just like the Ferengi ship.
Captain, there is an unidentified vessel heading toward us... two life forms aboard...
On screen.
They are initiating their Transporter systems...
Can you get any power to the shields?
No sir.
All decks... security alert!
We are being boarded...
La Forge to Bridge... we've got intruders in Main Engineering...
We need a security team down here...
It's on the way...
What do you want?
We're trying to make you listen...
You are killing us.
You've made a very serious accusation. I want you to explain it.
Captain, according to our research, warp fields are causing a dangerous reaction in this region of space.
Our planet is already being affected. We have measured large gravitational shifts throughout our system.
If something isn't done, our planet will become uninhabitable.
Captain, I've heard this theory before. Their research was evaluated by the Federation Science Council a few years ago. Their claims just didn't hold up.
That research was only preliminary. Our original analysis was incomplete...
Doctor, if you wanted us to review your research, you could have placed a request through the Science Council.
Their resources are limited. It would have taken over a year before they dispatched a science ship to come and evaluate our work.
We were not willing to wait any longer. We knew that if we disabled enough ships, Starfleet would come. Then at least we would be able to present our case...
That's how you rationalize these attacks?
Neither you nor the Ferengi suffered any casualties, Commander. The actual damage to your vessels was negligible.
We dispersed verteron probes in the Corridor only to disable warpdriven ships... nothing more.
You can call it whatever you like. The fact remains that you deliberately disguised your probes. You made them look like signal markers... You hid them in debris fields... You mined the Corridor.
Mister La Forge, how long do you estimate it will take to restore the engines?
Their verteron pulse overloaded our field coils, sir... it'll take at least thirty-six hours to get underway.
I know precisely how our pulse affected your field coils. With my help, your ship could be operational in ten hours... Provided you agree to review our research.

Because of the seriousness of your claims, I'm willing to listen to your case. But make no mistake. Our priority here is the recovery of the Fleming. I expect you to help us restore our systems and deactivate all your remaining probes in the Corridor... If you do not, I will put you both in the brig and take you to the nearest Starbase where you'll face charges for what you've done.
My sister and I have no wish to impede your rescue efforts --
Rabal, don't. The probes are the only leverage we have. If we --
Serova. We will do as you ask, Captain, but please... re-examine our data.
We will, Doctor. Part of our job is to maintain an open mind... even under these circumstances. Mister La Forge, take them to Engineering and get the core back on-line.
Yes, sir.
Mister Data, begin a review of their research. I'd like your report as soon as possible.
There... shields have been restored. You'll be able to reengage your engines in... approximately eight hours.
You know, even after we get the engines on-line, it's going to take a week to recalibrate them properly...
I'm sorry you've been inconvenienced.
But that's all it is -- an inconvenience. Our concerns are far more important than the condition of your engines.
What if the Fleming had been transporting perishable supplies... or was on an emergency mission? Your little plan might have cost a lot of lives.
That didn't happen, Commander. And saving lives is precisely what we're trying to do.
Well, you have an interesting way of going about it.
There's no point talking to you. You've already decided not to listen.
Commander... I know my sister can be somewhat -- aggravating...
I'd have to agree with that...
But please try to understand... she believes profoundly in this cause. She has sworn to dedicate her life to exposing the dangers of warp drive.
Warp drive has been around for three centuries. It's a proven technology...
You sound like I did... about four years ago...
You mean you didn't believe her, either?
No. What I didn't realize... was how brilliant my sister is. It took two years of study for me even to grasp the principles behind her theoretical models... they're that sophisticated.
Well, our Commander Data is no slouch. If there's anything there, he'll find it.
I hope so. Because once we persuade Starfleet to stop warp travel through the Corridor... we will have to convince our own people to give up warp drive completely.
Hekaras Two is the only inhabited world in this region. Without warp drive, you'd be completely isolated from the rest of the Federation. Are you really willing to take that step?
Yes. And if you were in my position, I hope you'd be willing to do the same.
According to Serova and Rabal's theory, there are regions of potential subspace instability within the Corridor...
They believe that if these regions continue to be exposed to warp field energy, they will rupture -- subspace will extrude into normal space, forming a rift.
I see. It's like pacing up and down on a carpet... eventually, you wear a hole in it.
The analogy is essentially correct.
Can their theory be proven?
At this time, there is insufficient evidence to do so...

In order to determine whether or not a rift would form, we would have to expose a region of the Corridor to warp field energy approximately one-million times greater than that normally generated by a starship.
Commander, we believe the warp field effect is cumulative. Each starship that passes through the Corridor at warp brings us one step closer to forming a rift.
I agree that is a possibility. Captain, I suggest we ask the Federation Science Council to send a research vessel to this area. A more detailed investigation would resolve many of our questions.
That's your response? More research? More delays? I suppose I shouldn't have expected anything different.
Bridge to Captain Picard.
Go ahead.
Sir, we've located the Fleming on long-range sensors, approximately zero-point-three light years away.
What's their condition?
The vessel appears to be intact. They have shields, but it looks like their subspace systems are out.
All right. We'll get underway as soon as the engines are back on-line.
Aye, sir.
I'd like you all to put together a research proposal for the Science Council. I'll give it my full recommendation.
Yes, sir.
Captain, I appreciate the opportunity you're giving us. It's a beginning that we --
Not "we". You can do whatever you want, Rabal. I'll have no part of this. It's just another delay.
The engines are back on-line, sir. All systems are ready.
Very good.
Helm, lay in a course for the Fleming.
Aye, sir.
It looks like they're in pretty good condition. According to our sensors, they've got their shields back up to full strength.
(interrupts, off console) Captain, the Hekaran ship is moving off....
There is one life form on board. It is Serova.
What's going on, Doctor?
I don't know... May I speak to her, Captain?
Mister Worf, open a channel.
Serova, what are you trying to do?
They wanted proof. I'm going to give it to them. I'm sorry...
Captain, the Hekaran ship's engines are beginning to overload...
I believe Serova is attempting to create a warp core breach...
No...
Shields at maximum... Full reverse...
Report!
We have cleared the shock wave, sir... but tetryon flux in the area is increasing rapidly...
It's incredible...
Mister Data, what's your analysis?

The effect is approximately zero-point-one light years in diameter, and is emitting extremely high levels of tetryon radiation... It appears to be what Rabal and Serova predicted, sir -- a subspace rift.
She was right...
Can you get a fix on the Fleming? Is it still in one piece?
Scanning... The Fleming is near its previous coordinates... it appears to be intact.... but it is now within the rift.
Doctor, is it possible for a ship to survive in there?
Doctor...
I'm sorry about your loss... but we need your help now.
Of course, Captain...
Does the rift pose any danger to the Fleming?
I... I don't know...
What was that?
Some kind of high energy distortion wave... it looks like they're being generated from within the rift.
As long as we maintain our current position, our shields should provide sufficient protection.
What about the Fleming? How long can they survive in there?
The waves are even more intense within the rift. I estimate their shields will fail within twelve hours.
Can we risk going in there to get them out?

Not at warp, sir. According to these readings, the rift is in a state of accelerating instability -- which would make it extremely sensitive to warp field energy. If we go in at warp, we might make it expand even further.
I don't think we have a choice. It would take weeks to reach them at impulse.
Then I want some better options. Data, Geordi... take Doctor Rabal and begin an analysis of the rift. We need a way to get the Fleming out of there.
Science Officer's log, Stardate 47312.1. Our new sensor readings have greatly improved our understanding of the rift. However, we have been unable to find any way to counteract it.
Everything here supports Serova's theories... I don't see any way to close the rift or even reduce its size.
Doctor, is it possible there are areas inside the rift which are stable... where we could safely use our warp engines?
Perhaps... Computer, scan the rift for regions of low instability...
There's no area stable enough to withstand a warp pulse...
There's something strange here... Computer. Display grid delta-seventeen... enhance and magnify.
What do you make of that?
It's a subspace instability -- outside the rift.
That should not be possible.
Commander, I'm going to begin a field-enhanced scan of this sector. I'd like to take a closer look at this.
In the meantime, we'll have to tell the Captain that we don't know how to get to the Fleming.
I am not certain that is true. I may have an idea.
I suggest we coast into the rift.
Coast?

We can initiate a brief, high-intensity warp pulse from our current position. We should be able to attain sufficient velocity to enter the rift, beam the crew off the Fleming and exit -- without using our warp engines.
All right. Let's say we initiate a full power warp pulse... how much time will we have before we drop out of warp?
If we field-saturate the nacelles, we should be able to sustain warp speed for approximately two minutes.
That's not much time... and it could get pretty rough in there.
Our timing will be critical.
Mister Data, begin your calculations. We'll go in as soon as you're ready.
Aye, sir.
I believe the maximum saturation level should be eighteen-point-three percent.
All right... With these parameters, we should be able to maintain warp speed for... two minutes and eight seconds. I don't think we can get any more than that.
I agree. But based on the size of the rift, it should give us sufficient time to complete our rescue. Computer. Begin nacelle field saturation.
How did we miss it?
What do you mean?
How did we miss the connection -- between warp drive and the formation of the rift?
Between the two of us we've logged thousands of hours on these engines. We're supposed to be warp field experts. But this time we certainly were wrong.
Technically, Geordi, we were not wrong. Serova's theories rested on assumptions which were unprovable.
Seems to me she managed to prove them pretty conclusively...
But only by using methods which a reputable scientist would never employ.
Yeah... she was willing to die to make her point. We should have listened to her more closely.
We reviewed Serova's research to the best of our ability, and we were prepared to continue studying the problem. But that was not satisfactory.
I can remember times when I've been a little stubborn... trying to get people to believe me when I didn't have enough proof...
I do not believe that you would have resorted to such extremes.
But she had to... to make us listen. Why? Why was I so resistant?
Perhaps because the aggressive methods she chose created an adversarial situation.
Or maybe I was taking the whole thing personally.
I do not understand...
Maybe it was all a little threatening to me... the thought that warp engines might be doing some kind of damage.
I've always looked at this warp core as something... beautiful... It never occurred to me that it might be -- destructive.
It's going to take another half hour for the nacelles to saturate. Would you call me when they're ready? There's someone I should talk to.
Commander.
scene: 45A  INT. TEN FORWARD - ANGLE ON DOOR

quote: May I join you?
scene: 45A  INT. TEN FORWARD - ANGLE ON DOOR

quote: I wanted to say... I'm sorry about your sister.
scene: 45A  INT. TEN FORWARD - ANGLE ON DOOR

quote: Thank you. I'm trying to tell myself that she died for what she believed in... but somehow that's not much comfort.
scene: 45A  INT. TEN FORWARD - ANGLE ON DOOR

quote: I wish things could've happened differently. I should have taken a closer look at your research... it's possible there was something I missed...
scene: 45A  INT. TEN FORWARD - ANGLE ON DOOR

quote: No. You didn't miss anything. The problem was time. It would've taken time to do the proper research... and Serova wasn't willing to wait.
scene: 45A  INT. TEN FORWARD - ANGLE ON DOOR

quote: I guess the question now is... where do we go from here?
scene: 45A  INT. TEN FORWARD - ANGLE ON DOOR

quote: I don't think we can look at space travel the same way anymore... we're going to have to change.
scene: 45A  INT. TEN FORWARD - ANGLE ON DOOR

quote: I've been in Starfleet for a long time. We depend on warp drive... I don't know how easy it'll be to change.
scene: 45A  INT. TEN FORWARD - ANGLE ON DOOR

quote: It won't be easy at all.
scene: 45A  INT. TEN FORWARD - ANGLE ON DOOR

quote: Captain, warp pulse calculations are complete. We will be firing the engines at maximum intensity for six-point-three seconds before disengaging.
Damage control parties are standing-by on all decks.
Our course to the Fleming is plotted and laid in, sir.
Mister La Forge... whenever you're ready...
Aye-aye, sir. Initiating warp pulse... now.
Engines disengaged... We are entering the rift...
Hull stress is increasing... eighteen percent of maximum tolerance and rising...
How long until we reach the Fleming?
One minute, twenty-two seconds...
All transporter rooms are standing by.
Captain, I am picking up power emissions from the Fleming... they may be attempting to initiate their warp drive.
They must have been able to repair their engines...
Captain, if they activate their engines --
I know, Data. Can we establish communications?
No, sir... subspace interference is too high...
How long until we reach transporter range?
Fifty-three seconds...
I don't think we're going to make it...
Sir, they are activating their warp drive...
Report!
Damage on decks six and fourteen... our structural integrity field is holding.
What about the Fleming?
They are badly damaged, sir... their life support systems are failing.
All transporter rooms, prepare for emergency evacuation procedures...
(interrupting, off console) Captain, when the Fleming activated its warp drive, the rift expanded by two-point-three percent... We no longer have sufficient momentum to escape.
Captain, distortion wave intensity has increased by a factor of ten.
We are within transporter range of the Fleming, sir. Commencing evacuation procedures...
Distortion waves are now occurring every fifty-nine seconds... Hull stress is nearing maximum tolerance...
Data, what if we forced an EPS discharge through the impulse reactor... would that be enough to blast us out of here?
I do not believe so, sir... and the resulting explosion would most likely destroy the saucer section in the process...
Captain...
We might be able to get out of here without using the warp engines.
How, Geordi?
When's the last time you went surfing, Commander?
A couple of months ago, on Risa... I nearly killed myself on the break at Kattala beach.
Feel like catching another wave?
A distortion wave...
Exactly, sir. If can phase-match our deflector shield to the EM variants of the distortion wave, when the next one hits, we'll be pulled along with it...
We could ride it out of the rift and break away once we're clear. Assuming we survive the ride.
Is everyone off the Fleming?
The last of the crew has been beamed aboard, sir.
All right, Mister La Forge. Get us out of here.
Yes, sir... I'm phase matching the deflector shield now...
The next distortion wave will impact in fourteen seconds...
Matching phases... Prepare to engage shield emitters on my mark...
Ten seconds...
Ready...
Engage shield emitters... full power...
Distortion wave impact... now.
We were unable to maintain contact with the distortion wave, sir... we are still within the rift.
What went wrong, Mister La Forge?
The speed differential between us and the wave was too high, sir... the shock of the impact threw us off.
Another distortion wave is approaching... impact in twenty-six seconds.
Our hull stress is already critical... we can't handle many more jolts like that one...
Captain, I suggest we take the ship to full impulse. If we can attain sufficient speed, it will lessen the shock when the wave hits.
Helm, full impulse. Head us out of the rift. ) Shield emitters, stand-by.
We're ready, sir.
Distortion wave impact in five seconds...
Engage emitters... now.
We are in the distortion wave... hull stresses exceeding tolerance...
Structural integrity fields failing on decks ten through sixteen..
We are within the distortion wave... hull stresses exceeding tolerance...
Structural integrity fields failing on decks ten through sixteen... switching to backups...
Captain, we're separating from the distortion wave... I'm attempting to compensate...
How much longer until we clear the rift?
Approximately twelve seconds... Hull stress is now one-hundred twenty percent above maximum...
Structural breach is imminent...
We have cleared the rift. Hull stresses have returned to normal.
Cancel red alert.
Captain's Log, Stardate 47314.5. We have been continuing our research, while the Federation Council studies our reports on the subspace rift.
It now appears certain that what we've seen here will have repercussions for many years to come.
Our scans have shown a lot of subspace instabilities all through the sector. If they're exposed to enough warp energy, they might eventually create other rifts.
Based on current warp drive patterns in the sector, we've projected where subspace rifts will be most likely to form in the next forty years. This is the way things are now...
This is how they'll look in ten years...
Thank you, gentlemen.
We've received new directives from the Federation Council on this matter...

Until we can find a way to counteract the warp field effect, the Council feels our best course is to slow the damage as much as possible... Therefore, areas of space found susceptible to warp fields will be restricted to essential travel only... And effective immediately, all Federation vessels will be limited to a speed of warp five, except in cases of extreme emergency.
Sir, the Klingons will observe these restrictions, but the Romulans will not.
And what about the Ferengi... and the Cardassians for that matter?
The Federation is sharing our data with all known warp-capable species.
All we can hope is that they realize it's in their best interests to take similar action.
Putting limits on warp speed is only going to prevent other rifts from forming. What are we going to do about this one?
Unfortunately, right now there's not much we can do.
My planet is not in immediate danger, but the gravitational shifts are already beginning to affect its orbit. Our climate is changing.
Starfleet is setting up a weather control network for Hekaras Two. It's only a temporary solution, but it should suffice for now.
We were lucky the rift formed as far away from the planet as it did. At least we have a little time to consider our options.
If there are no further questions, you're dismissed.
We should have the thermal stabilizers ready for the Hekarans in another day, sir.
Very well.
But now I can't help but wonder if all the while I was really helping to destroy the very thing I hold dear.
It's not going to turn out that way, sir. We still have time to make it better.
Good morning, Commander.
Data. Interesting night?
I found it extremely interesting. The lateral sensor array performed three separate spectral analyses of the Alwanir Nebula on three distinct frequencies.
Sorry I missed it.

(missing the ironic tone) I will have the reports sent to you. We are still on course for the Gariman system, our speed is warp six and our ETA is thirteen hundred hours. Sickbay reported one minor injury in the exobiology department at zero four twenty hours.
Very well.
Isn't Worf supposed to relieve Ensign Torigan?
Yes, sir. I was not informed of any change in the duty roster.
He's never late. Riker to Lieutenant Worf.
Computer, locate Lieutenant Worf.
Lieutenant Worf is in his quarters.
Something's wrong. Data, you have the Bridge. Security, meet me on deck seven, section twenty-five baker.
Computer, override the security lock on this door. Authorization: Riker alpha six zero.
TORVA LUK DO SHELL!
Worf? What the hell are you doing?
He had no explanation at all?
Not a word. He just got dressed and then reported for duty as if nothing had happened. Captain, this isn't the first... problem I've had with Worf lately.
Oh?

Until now, it wasn't anything serious so I didn't bring it to your attention. But, to be blunt, he's been getting... sloppy. His duty reports have been incomplete, he's fallen behind in maintenance checks, he just seems... distracted.
Where's Worf now?
I confined him to quarters.
You have the Bridge, Number One.
Aye, sir.
Enter.
Captain.
On your feet, Lieutenant.
Sir.

Mister Worf, your personal affairs are strictly your concern unless they interfere with the operation of this ship. You've crossed that line. Now as your Captain, I want to know exactly what's going on.
It is... difficult to explain.
Try.
Ever since I returned from the Carraya system I have felt... empty...
Does this have something to do with the Klingons you... rescued from Carraya Four?
They were young... they knew nothing of their heritage. So while I was there, I tried to... teach them... teach them about their people, their culture.

I told them our ancient stories... instructed them in our customs... explained our beliefs. And then I told them about Kahless... how he united our people long ago... how he gave us honor and strength... and how he promised to return one day and lead us again. It took time... but I saw them begin to discover the warriors within themselves... to believe in Kahless and his teachings... and to become truly Klingon. It was ... unlike anything I had experienced before.
Is that what you were doing here? Trying to recapture those feelings?
I was trying to summon a vision of Kahless.
You might have tried using the Holodeck instead of setting your quarters on fire.
Using the Holodeck would not be appropriate... everything had to be real if Kahless were to appear. But all this was for nothing... he did not come to me.
I gave Toq and the others a belief in Sto-Vo-Kor: the life which lies beyond this life... where Kahless awaits us.
When I saw the power of their belief... I began to question the strength of my own. And I found it... wanting.
Have you lost your... faith in Sto-Vo-Kor?
To lose something, one must first possess it... I am not sure I ever had a true belief.
But I should not have allowed it to interfere with my duties. My behavior has been --

Inexcusable. But understandable. You are the only Klingon in Starfleet... and one of the few raised by human parents. Perhaps the problem is that you have only studied the beliefs of your people... only looked at them from the outside.

It may be that what you seek cannot be found on the Enterprise. You may need to immerse yourself in Klingon beliefs before you can discover whether they hold any truths for you. Is there anything you could do... any place you could go... to explore your faith more fully?
Boreth. The Followers of Kahless wait there for his return. To Klingons, there is no more sacred place.
Boreth is twelve days from here by shuttle. As of this moment, you are on leave.
Thank you, Captain.
I hope you find what you're looking for, Mister Worf. Because the next time you set foot on this ship I expect you to carry out your duties like a Starfleet officer.
Aye, sir.
Torva... Luk...
... Do Shell...
Kahless! I see Kahless!
He is standing before me... holding a sword... he wants something... me, he wants me! He wants me to go with him!
It is a powerful vision you have had, Divok. Kahless has asked you to join him in Sto-Vo-Kor. You are only nineteen and yet your place among the honored dead is already secure
Take him back to his chamber. Let him sleep.
You are leaving us.
It has been ten days, Koroth. But I have had no visions... I have received no insight. There is nothing for me here.
What is the story of The Promise, Worf?
When Kahless united the people and gave them the laws of honor, he saw that his work was done. So one night he gathered his belongings and went to the edge of the city to say good-bye.
(picking up the thread of the story) The people wept... they did not want him to go.

And Kahless said, "You are Klingons. You need no one but yourselves. I will go now... to Sto-Vo-Kor. But I promise one day I will return." Then Kahless pointed to a star in the sky and said, "Look for me there... on that point of light."

So here we are... on a world circling that distant point of light. It has been over fifteen centuries since he made that promise... and still we wait. What are ten days in the life of one Klingon compared to that? Is the son of Mogh really so easily discouraged?

You came to us seeking answers... but this is a place of questions. Open your heart to Kahless... ask him your questions... let him speak to you with your mind unclouded by doubt or hesitation. Only then can you find what you are looking for. If you cannot do that... then perhaps you should return to your starship.
I will open my heart, Kahless. I will...
Torva... Luk... Do... Shell...
scene: 18   INT. LAVA CAVES - SEVERAL HOURS LATER

quote: I see Kahless.
scene: 18   INT. LAVA CAVES - SEVERAL HOURS LATER

quote: You are... real?
scene: 18   INT. LAVA CAVES - SEVERAL HOURS LATER

quote: (in a strong, clear voice) I am Kahless... and I have returned.
scene: 18   INT. LAVA CAVES - SEVERAL HOURS LATER

quote: What are you doing?
Who are you?
It is Kahless!
I have returned.
You doubt me.
Who here knows the story of how this sword was forged?
No one knows. It is not written in the sacred texts.

I went into the mountains... all the way to the Kri'stak Volcano. I cut off a lock of my hair and thrust it into the river of molten rock which poured from the summit. The hair began to burn, but then I plunged it into the lake of Lusor and twisted it into a sword. And after I used it to kill the tyrant Molor I gave it a name: bat'leth, the sword of honor.
You know... The story of the sword is known only to the High Clerics... it was never written down, so that if he returned, we could be sure it was Kahless.

I have returned because there is a great need in my people... they fight among themselves in petty wars and corrupt the glory of the Klingon spirit. They have lost their way. But it is not too late. I have returned and I will lead my people again!
Vorcha-doh-baghk, Kahless! (All hail Kahless)
Vorcha-doh-baghk, Kahless!
What is it you are doing?
I was getting my tricorder.
Tri-Corder? Is it a weapon?
No. It is a tool. I was going to use it to see if you were...
To see if I were real. Proceed. Use your Tri-Corder.
Well?
You are... Klingon.
What else could I be?
There are many possibilities... a shape shifter, a holographic projection...
... So, you are a skeptic, Worf. I like that....
How do you know my name?
We have met before. I appeared to you in a vision... in the caves of No'Mat... you were a child then... and I told you... ... that you would do something... no Klingon had ever done before....
Yes...
Was I ... correct?...
I... am the first Klingon to serve in Starfleet.
"Star-Fleet"... there are still many things you will have to explain to me.
You have a question.
Why did you appear when I was in the cave? Why not appear to Koroth, or Torin?
Perhaps it is because you have the heart of a true warrior. (beat, studies him for a moment) You still do not believe it is me, do you Worf?...
I... want to believe.
That is a ... beginning... .

Captain's Log: Stardate 46852.2. Our mission to Endora Seven has been cancelled on orders from Starfleet Command. The Enterprise is to proceed directly to the planet Boreth, to take aboard a very unusual guest.
Kahless? Hasn't he been dead for over a thousand years?
One thousand five hundred and forty-seven years to be exact.
Do the Klingons actually believe that this is the real Kahless?
It would seem that at least Gowron believes it. He personally contacted the Federation Council and asked that a starship be sent to bring Kahless back to the Home World.
Why wouldn't he send a Klingon ship?
Gowron would only say that there were certain... security concerns which prompted him to make this request. As the nearest starship to Boreth, the task is ours.
Have we heard from Worf?
No. All communication with Boreth has been cut-off since yesterday.
Set course for Boreth, Number One. Warp six.
Aye, sir.
Gowron is the Leader of the Council... he commands the entire Defense Force... if he chooses to oppose you...

Do not worry. We stand on the threshold of a new era for our people... Klingons from all over the Empire... will flock to my banner... And yet something still weighs heavy on the brow of the son of Mogh...
Are you contemplating yet another question for me? After three days, I am beginning to wonder if you know how to do anything else.
Questions are the beginning of wisdom... it is the mark of a true warrior.

But do not forget that a leader need not answer questions from those he leads... it is enough that he says to do a thing... and they will do it. If he says to run, they run... if he says to fight, they fight... if he says to die... ... they die.
Yes. If the... commander is worthy of their trust.
E'Gok!
What is wrong? Is there only anger and bloodlust in your souls? Is that all that is left in the Klingon heart?

We do not fight merely to spill blood, but to enrich the spirit. Look at us... two warriors locked in battle, fighting for honor. How can you keep from ... singing... out for all to hear, ... "We are Klingons!"...
... Yes! Let it out!... Let the joy in your heart be heard!
We are Klingons!
We are Klingons!
Welcome aboard the Enterprise. I'm Captain Jean-Luc Picard.
This is the... "human" you told me about?
Yes.
You must be a mighty warrior to command such respect.
Thank you.
And you do me a great honor by giving me one of your women.
They have... different ways.
Ah. Then she is not a gift.
No.
It is as I said... we should be on a Klingon warship. This is not the place for us.
Their customs may be different, but Worf tells me they are not dishonorable... and I am eager to see the weapons on this "Star-Ship."
I would be happy to arrange a tour of the entire ship for you, once you've settled in. Perhaps Commander Riker could begin by showing you your quarters.
That is acceptable.
Then, if you'll follow me...
Did you take any other tricorder readings... a neuro-physiology scan or an anatomical profile?
No.

Then it's going to be hard to eliminate any possibility at this point. He could be a coalescent being taking Klingon form... a bioreplicant... or even a Klingon surgically altered to resemble Kahless...
I felt no deception or malice from him... just an over-whelming sense of confidence... almost arrogance.
Worf, what are his plans when he returns to the Home World?
He wants to restore the glory of the Empire by purging it of dishonor and corruption.
I don't think Gowron's going to like the sound of that.
That might have something to do with why he wanted a Federation ship to bring Kahless. Gowron may not want to be seen embracing this... Messiah before he knows what Kahless wants.
Perhaps this Kahless is a... stalking horse for someone else... someone who intends to seize control from Gowron.
It is not an... empirical matter. It is a matter of... faith.
Faith. Then you do believe Kahless may have... supernatural attributes?
As an android, I am unable to accept something which cannot be proven through rational means. I would appreciate hearing your insight on this matter.
Perhaps some other time, Commander. I do not believe I could provide much... insight at the moment.
Like the Duras sisters...
Or the B'nok faction.
There is another possibility. It could be the real Kahless. He may have actually returned... as he promised.
The appearance of Kahless in the lava cave is consistent with the stories found in the Klingon sacred texts.
No offense, Worf... but I have trouble believing that the man I just escorted to deck eight is... supernatural.
I am not saying that he is... I merely think we should not completely reject the possibility.

We have no reason to rule out anything. We haven't been ordered to discover the origins of our guest, or tell anyone what they should believe... we are simply to transport Kahless to the Home World... and while he's with us, he will be treated as an honored guest.
Lieutenant. May I ask you a personal question? In the absence of empirical data, how will you determine whether or not this is the real Kahless?
It was given to me during my Rite of Ascension by a man who had known my father.
Did you observe the Rite here... among these aliens?...
No... I returned to the Home World for the ceremony. But these... aliens have allowed me to conduct other Klingon rituals on the Enterprise. They understand that it is part of me.
You mentioned a son... where is he?
He is visiting my adoptive parents on Earth.
Will he understand our ways growing up among all these... aliens?
I have instructed him in our traditions... but Alexander will have to find his own path... as I did.
A good knife... well forged. But even the best blade will rust and grow dull unless it is cared for...
I was concerned that living with aliens would dull your edge. I am pleased to see that I was wrong.

You have stood alone among these aliens... kept our traditions and our customs... held on to your heritage with no guidance from a Klingon mother or father... and you were willing to face me in single combat knowing that you had no chance to win. You are Klingon... and I would be proud to fight with you at my side.
Commander, there is an incoming message. Text only.
It is from Gowron. He is aboard the Klingon ship Bortas and is requesting that we alter course to rendezvous with him.
The rendezvous coordinates are twenty-three light years outside the Klingon Border. What's he up to? (beat, then to Con Officer) Prepare to alter course. Captain Picard to the Bridge, please.
Welcome aboard, Gowron.
Where is he, Picard?
I assume you're referring to Kahless.
I am referring to the filthy pahtak who is using his name.
Well, the... person in question is in his quarters at the moment.
What have you learned about him so far? What kind of medical analysis have you done? Do you have any theories about his true origin?
We haven't done any analyses.
What kind of fools do you have working for you, Picard? The imposter's been aboard for nearly a day.
If you wanted to run tests on Kahless, you should've sent a Klingon vessel for him.
And have him begin spreading his poisonous lies through a ship of loyal Klingons? Never.
If he's really an imposter you shouldn't have anything to worry about.

Kahless has been dead for a thousand years... but the idea of Kahless is still alive. Have you ever fought an idea, Picard? It has no weapon to destroy, no body to kill. The idea of Kahless' return must be stopped here. Now. Or it will travel through the Empire like a wave... and leave nothing but destruction behind.
... so Gowron has come aboard in order to test your claim.
Gowron knows his days are nearly over... so now he comes crawling aboard with some kind of "test."
We do not have to prove anything to Gowron.
What is this... test?
He has brought a knife with him... a knife that was supposed to be stained with the blood of Kahless.
Gowron has brought the Knife of Kirom? No one is permitted to remove it from the sacred vault.
Gowron does not care about what is sacred.

Gowron wants to run a genetic analysis on a sample of the blood and on you. It should tell us if there is a... biological match. If you agree to the test... I will make the Enterprise facilities available to... ensure that it is conducted impartially.
Perhaps it is time to settle the doubts of those who do not yet believe... I will allow the test.
All right... that should do it.
Computer, run a genetic comparison on this blood sample and the tissue belonging to Kahless.
The genetic patterns are identical.
But how... how can this be?
It is true... Kahless has returned.
Enter.
Koroth, Torin. I had hoped to speak with Kahless...
Another time, Worf. There is much for Kahless to do before we arrive at the Home World... many things to consider.
Worf?
Where are you going?
Kahless, it might be better if --
Go away, Koroth. I've listened to you and Torin until my ears burn with politics. Let me and Worf be alone for a while.
As you wish.
They are good men. But they chatter like tree hens.
I am sorry our replicators do not do justice to Klingon Warnog...
It has been so long since I have tasted any food or drink... there are many things I have forgotten.
Kahless, may I ask you about... death... and Sto-Vo-Kor? Tell me what awaits us beyond this life.
I do not have those answers.
I am merely a... traveller... someone who has journeyed back and forth between this world and the next. While I am in this form, I know only about this world...
And there is much work for me to do in this world... and you will be part of it, Worf.
Me?

It was your purity of heart that summoned me back from Sto-Vo-Kor... and Koroth has told me about the respect you have earned in the Federation and the Empire. I want you to have a place at my side as we restore honor to our people.
Let me tell you about the new Empire we will forge...
... it will be glorious.
It will be war.
You are not a fool, Worf. Do you really think that every Klingon in the Empire will bend his knee and grovel before this man just because Koroth says he is Kahless?
He is Kahless. Your own test proved it.
I will not hand over the Empire to Koroth because of one test.
It is not Koroth, it is --
Of course it is Koroth. Open your eyes... Koroth and the other "Guardians" have always opposed me. This is nothing more than a ploy for them to finally seize power.
Even now, there are warriors on my own ship who want to see Kahless... there are others who believe he is an imposter... the divisions are already forming...
It does not have to be that way... we could all join together and welcome Kahless as a united people.

Don't you see? This is exactly why they want you to join them... because your brother sits on the Council and your voice carries weight in the Empire. They want you to influence others to follow them.

Worf, we fought together once... side by side to keep the Empire from being torn apart... will you stand by and let these impostors destroy all that we fought so hard to protect? Renounce him, Worf. Stand with me and we can hold the Empire together.

You do not understand. Kahless is our future... only with his help can we revive the pure warriors within ourselves. Listen to him, Gowron... open your heart and hear his words as I have. He will restore your faith... as he has restored mine. Give him a chance to lift your spirit and cleanse your heart before you take up arms.
You should not have arranged this without my approval.
I did. Kahless approved.
Yes. Yes, of course he did.
Lieutenant, would my presence here be inappropriate? I would greatly appreciate the opportunity to study Klingon beliefs in this forum, but I do not wish to give offense.
Kahless welcomes all who come to hear his words. Your presence will not give offense.
Thank you.
Koroth. I see that not all fools die young.
Kahless!
Kahless, may I present Gowron, Leader of the High Council.
You may sit.

Long ago, a storm was heading for the city of Quin'lat. Everyone took protection within the walls except one man who remained outside. I went to him and asked what he was doing. "I am not afraid," he said. "I will not hide my face behind stone and mortar. I will stand before the wind and make it respect me." I honored his choice and went back inside. The next day, the storm came... and the man was killed... The wind does not respect a fool. Do not stand before the wind, Gowron.
What was his name?
What?
If you were really there, you should be able to tell us the name of the man outside the walls.
What kind of question is that?
I did not ask you, Koroth. I asked him. Describe him to us... what was he wearing? How tall was he? What color were his eyes?
I do not remember. It was long ago, and in another lifetime.

All that matters is that I have returned to restore faith and hope to my people... to lead them back to the way of honor... to the glory that was once theirs and can be again. Is that what you oppose, Gowron?
I oppose you. I say you are not Kahless... and I will not bend my knee to you as long as I can draw a breath or pick up a blade.
No. I do not believe Kahless will kill him.
A good try, Gowron... but not enough.
You have no joy, Gowron. Is your heart so filled with distrust and suspicion that you have forgotten what it is to be truly Klingon.
"Kahless... the greatest warrior of them all... "

There is no future here... no glorious new era for our people. Gowron was right, you don't know the name of the man who faced the storm... you don't even know what real Warnog tastes like... and you certainly are not the greatest warrior of all. Whoever you are... you're not Kahless.
You've said enough, now get out.
You are using the name of Kahless in some twisted game... for that alone you should die... and if you do not tell me what you have done, I will kill you right here.
The problems with your memory... are a result of... the way you returned.
What do you mean?
We -- the Guardians -- have been awaiting your return for centuries.
But we did not have the technology to bring you back until now. We were able to use an organic sample of the first Kahless to... give you life.
The first Kahless?
A clone. He is a clone.
What is a... clone?
A being created in a laboratory... from genetic material taken from another being. You are a copy... a fraud.
You are not "just" a copy. We gave you more than the body of Kahless.

We found a way to imprint specific information into your neurosynaptic patterns... we gave you memories. And not just any memories... we gave you the experiences of Kahless as written in the sacred texts.

So I did not do any of the things I remember... I was never at the city of Quin'lat... I never went to the Kri'stat Volcano... But what about Worf? I remember apparing to him in the caves of No'Mat when he was a boy...
We gave you that memory as well. Worf told me of his vision when he first arrived on Boreth.

You were not... awakened until the moment we transported you into the cave... and you appeared to Worf. Before that time you were unconscious... in a laboratory where we accelerated your growth, corrected any genetic anomalies that occurred, and gave you the wisdom and memories that --
They grew you in a test tube... like some kind of fungus... then programmed you like a machine.
You are twisting the truth.
You talk to me about the truth? You, who have brought this... lie to life and then called it Kahless?
It is not a lie! Genetically, he is Kahless. And he is needed by our people. You know better than anyone the corruption and dishonor that is destroying the Empire. They need him.
They do not need a false god.
How do you know that this is not the way the prophesy was to be fulfilled? Who is to say that what we did is wrong?
I am. And I will not let this... fraud continue.
Worf, you cannot tell Gowron about this.
Do not give me orders, Koroth.

All right. I won't tell you what to do. But consider this: Do you want Gowron's corruption to infect every corner of the Empire? Do you want our people to continue sacrificing their honor until they are no different from Romulans? If you tell Gowron what we have told you, it will destroy -- -- him... and with him the last chance to restore hope to our people. It's your choice.
They have been here for three hours seventeen minutes.

They refused to transport back to the ship with the rest of Gowron's men. They insisted on waiting here until they see Kahless again. Their faith appears to be unaffected by his inability to defeat Gowron. They still believe.
Then they are fools.
Does that mean you no longer believe this is the real Kahless?
Yes.
I am curious. Do you still believe that the real Kahless will return someday? Or has this experience only deepened the spiritual crisis which originally sent you to Boreth?
I... do not know.
I understand your dilemma. I once had what could be considered a crisis of the spirit.
You?

Yes. The Starfleet officers who first activated me on Omicron Theta told me that I was an android -- nothing more than a very sophisticated machine in human form. However I realized that if I were simply a machine, then I could never be anything else -- I could not grow beyond my programming. I found that difficult to accept. I chose to believe that I was a person, that I had the potential to become more than a collection of circuits and subprocessors. It is a belief that I still hold.
How did you come to your decision?
I believe I made a... "leap of faith."
I will not allow the Enterprise to enter Klingon space with him on board.
The Klingon High Council asked you to bring Kahless to the Home World. Only they can withdraw the request. The Enterprise must continue on its mission.
There is no mission, Koroth... your plan has failed.
I will enjoy watching the life bleed from your veins.
Gentlemen, please. Let us stick to the issue at--
Mister Worf?
Captain, will you excuse us for a moment?
Of course.
The man that appeared to me on Boreth is not the real Kahless. He is a clone.
A clone!
Yes.
Did you really think you would get away with this kind of fraud? I will have you and this abomination put to death with --
It does not matter, Gowron. You will still not be able to stand against him.
What? He's not real. You just said so.

I said he was not the real Kahless... but in the minds of our people he can be just as powerful as Kahless. Even now, two members of your own crew are sitting on our Holodeck... waiting for him to return.
I do not care what they think.

They are not alone... like many of our people, they need something to believe in... just as I did... something larger than themselves... something that will give their lives meaning. They need Kahless.
But when they find out the truth... ?

It will not matter. Despite the facts, they will still believe... They will... make a leap of faith... and there will be others just like them... not everyone... but enough to plunge the Empire into civil war if you oppose them.
What are you saying? That I should just... hand over the Empire?
No... that would be unwise as well.
Then what are you proposing, Worf?
You were right about one thing, Koroth... our people are becoming corrupt and decadent... they need moral leadership. Kahless can be that leader... as Emperor.
There hasn't been an Emperor in three centuries!

The political power would remain with the High Council. Kahless would be... a figurehead. But he would have the ability to rally the people... to lead by example... and guide them in spiritual matters.
The title is meaningless without the power to back it up.

Real power is in the heart. You would have the power to mold the Klingon heart... you could return them to honorable ways... according to the original teachings of Kahless, which are within you... it would be a great challenge, if you have the courage to accept it.
And what will we tell the people about their new Emperor? That he appeared in a cave or a laboratory?
We will tell them the truth... all of the truth. But we will also tell them that even if he is not the real Kahless... he is the rightful heir to Kahless.
And if I refuse to go along with this?
Then my brother and all who support him on the Council will fight you... and I will fight you... and the Empire will fall back into civil war.
What do you say to this, Koroth?
What I say is unimportant. What do you say?
It is acceptable.
Join with me, Gowron. Let us usher in this new era together.
Vorcha-doh-baghK... Kahless.
Farewell, Worf.
Good-bye.
What's wrong? You should be proud of what you have accomplished.
I went to Boreth to find my faith... and for a time I thought I did... but now, my heart is empty again. I do not know what to believe...
You doubt the real Kahless will return one day... you doubt that he is still waiting for you in Sto-Vo-Kor?

Kahless left us -- all of us -- a powerful legacy... a way of thinking and acting that makes us Klingon. If his words hold wisdom and his philosophy is honorable... then does it really matter if he returns? What is important is whether we follow his teachings... perhaps the words are more important than the man.
Q'apla, son of Mogh.
Q'apla... Kahless.
Captain's log, Stardate 41209.2. We are running at Warp 7 to rendezvous with the science vessel S. S. Tsiolkovsky...

... which has been routinely monitoring the collapse of a red supergiant star into a white dwarf. What has brought us here is a series of strange messages indicating something has gone wrong aboard the research vessel.
Well, hello Enterprise. Welcome... I hope you have a lot of pretty boys on board... because I'm willing... and waiting...
S.S. Tsiolkovsky, repeat your message.
In fact... we're going to have a real blowout here... Thought that would interest you. Waiting!
Captain... what we just heard is, well...impossible.
Report.
I believe that last sound we heard was an emergency hatch being blown.
Are you certain... yes, of course you are.
Sensor scan now reveals no life signs aboard, Captain.
Put us on their bridge, Chief.

quote: You were right. Somebody blew the hatch and they were all sucked out into space..
scene: 6    INT. SECOND CORRIDOR - ON RIKER AND DATA (OPTICAL)

quote: Correction, sir, blown out.
scene: 6    INT. SECOND CORRIDOR - ON RIKER AND DATA (OPTICAL)

quote: Thank you, Data.
scene: 6    INT. SECOND CORRIDOR - ON RIKER AND DATA (OPTICAL)

quote: A common mistake, sir...
scene: 6    INT. SECOND CORRIDOR - ON RIKER AND DATA (OPTICAL)

quote: I know! Thank you, Data.

quote: Commander Riker, it's Lieutenant Yar, location Engineering. Ten people here, sir, all frozen. No vital signs.

scene: 6    INT. SECOND CORRIDOR - ON RIKER AND DATA (OPTICAL)

quote: Looks to me like someone was "playing" with the environmental controls, sir. Just let all the heat bleed away into space.
scene: 6    INT. SECOND CORRIDOR - ON RIKER AND DATA (OPTICAL)

quote: That's ridiculous!
scene: 6    INT. SECOND CORRIDOR - ON RIKER AND DATA (OPTICAL)
location: SECOND CORRIDOR - ON RIKER AND DATA

quote: That's what I say, sir.
scene: 6    INT. SECOND CORRIDOR - ON RIKER AND DATA (OPTICAL)

quote: Sir, Lieutenant La Forge in the crew quarters. Something in here.
scene: 9    INT. PERSONNEL QUARTERS - ANGLE ON ENTRY DOOR

quote: Hello!
scene: 9    INT. PERSONNEL QUARTERS - ANGLE ON ENTRY DOOR

quote: Riker to Captain, I have a report for you.

quote: Picard here.
scene: 16   INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON PICARD

quote: They're all dead, sir. Some were apparently blown out the emergency hatches.
scene: 16   INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON PICARD

quote: There were eighty people on that ship, Number One.
scene: 16   INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - CLOSE ON PICARD

quote: Yes sir. As I said, all dead.

quote: Captain's log, supplemental. We are downloading the research information gathered on the collapsing...
... star nearby. I am concerned at being in such close orbit, but the Tsiolkovsky's research records...
... will no doubt predict the time of the star's final collapse.
I can't find anything unusual in any of the tricorder readings they've sent over, Captain.
scene: 20   INT. CRUSHER'S OFFICE - ON BEVERLY, PICARD AND TROI

quote: Give me a theory, Doctor. Anything!
scene: 20   INT. CRUSHER'S OFFICE - ON BEVERLY, PICARD AND TROI

quote: Troi? Did you feel anything from over there?

quote: Perhaps some residual confusion... and exhilaration, too. But I'm not too certain of that.

location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER

quote: Are you saying I'm "drunk?" I feel strange but also good.
scene: 85   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER

quote: Because... (corrects his tone of voice) Because you've lost the capacity for self-judgment. Alcohol does that but this contaminant we've brought back does it even more so.
scene: 85   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER

quote: What would you do if you got your ship back?
scene: 85   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER

quote: It's very important I do because we must immediately put a tractor beam on the Tsiolkovsky, then tow it out of...
scene: 85   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER

quote: Tractor beams are my specialty, Skipper! I'll contact you when that's done; Wesley out!
scene: 85   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER

quote: Wes!
scene: 85   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER

quote: Conn, where are you headed?
scene: 85   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER

quote: Sir! The star; it's beginning to collapse.
scene: 85   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER

quote: What the hell is happening in Engineering?
scene: 85   INT. MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER (OPTICAL)
location: MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON MAIN VIEWER

quote: Lock on, Tsiolkovsky, lock on... lock on, Tsiolkovsky, lock on...
scene: 88   INT. ENGINEERING OFFICE - ANGLE ON WESLEY AND

quote: You got the logic probe? Thanks.
scene: 89   INT. ENGINEERING - ON MACDOUGAL AND RIKER

quote: Where's the sonic driver?
scene: 89   INT. ENGINEERING - ON MACDOUGAL AND RIKER

quote: There. Let's see if this'll cut out his tractor beam power.
scene: 89   INT. ENGINEERING - ON MACDOUGAL AND RIKER

quote: Oh no! No, I must find the answer. Find the answer. Have to find the answer.
Captain -- tractor beam! We just locked onto the Tsiolkovsky!
scene: 93   INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON WORF

quote: Bridge to... to Wesley. Wesley Crusher, come in!
scene: 93   INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON WORF

quote: Data! At least you're functioning.. !
scene: 93   INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON WORF

quote: Fully, Captain, fully.
scene: 93   INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON WORF

quote: Data, intoxication is a human condition. Your mind is different, it's not the same...
scene: 93   INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON WORF

quote: We are more alike than unlike, my dear captain.
scene: 93   INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON WORF

quote: I have pores. Humans have pores. I have fingerprints. Humans have fingerprints. My chemical nutrients are like your blood. (looks appealingly at Picard) If you prick me, do I not leak?
scene: 93   INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON WORF

quote: If this can possibly wait, Doctor...
scene: 93   INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON WORF

quote: May I see you in your Ready Room? It's a private matter... well, actually an urgent one...
scene: 93   INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON WORF

quote: I'm busy, Doctor. Impossible.
scene: 93   INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON WORF

quote: Damn!
scene: 93   INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - ANGLE ON WORF

quote: I believe I'm infected myself.
Do you know what the infection is? Hurry!

Sorry. It is definitely like alcohol intoxication, the same lack of good judgment... For example right now, I find you, well, extremely...extremely... Of course we haven't time for that sort of thing...
What sort of thing?
Oh God would I love to show you.
Doctor, there must be a cure! Some formula, similar to the old one...
Dammit... dammit, dammit, my dear captain. You owe me something. You do realize that, don't you? I'm a woman; I haven't the comfort of a husband, a man...
Not now, Doctor, please...
Bridge to Riker, urgent!
Riker here.
Sir, regret to inform you that the captain appears to be infected. And Data, and...
Thank you, Lieutenant. I'm coming. You'll have to handle this.
Are you saying you'll handle that?
What we're seeing, sir, is a huge chunk of the star's surface blown off, heading for us!
Take us...
Are you alright, sir?
Worf, you know what to do. Take us out of here.
Sir, the controls are still off-line!
Override!
Same result, sir.
Wes, come in please. Wesley Crusher, this is Riker. Come in. This is urgent!
Engineering, urgent. We must have ship's power...
Oh, no, those are control chips... ! Bridge from Engineering...
The star is still collapsing; we're directly in the path of...
I can't help you, bridge! Someone's yanked out all the control chips here...
It was an adult who did it!
I estimate fourteen minutes until that mass gets here... !
No way to replace chips in fourteen minutes, sir. I'd guess two hours, maybe three...
Data could assemble them back faster.
What's that? What's that Wesley?
They're just simple isolinear chips, sir. To Data, anyway. He could shuffle them like cards.
Come on Data. Hurry!
Ship's log, First Officer Riker. The star has begun disintegrating. Enterprise will be destroyed unless it can be moved out of the path of the star material hurtling...
... toward us. Our only hope is for Lieutenant Commander Data in the time we have left, to regain his senses and reconnect engine power to the Bridge.
scene: 109  EXT. SPACE - EXPLODED MASS OF MATERIAL (OPTICAL)

quote: Hi, Mister Data.
Nice to see you, Wesley. What... ?
(overlapping; urgently indicating) Data! We need the engines on-line in a hurry, remember?
Oh yes, I remember too. So, Data, if you don't mind...
We've no time for courtesy! Get those damned control chips back in place, Data! In the correct order!
NOW!
It's like a game of 'how fast can you do it?'
Ah, a game!
I think I can switch this to the main viewer, sir...
We've got eight or nine minutes, at most, Data. Can you finish by then?
No. This will take slightly more time than we have, sir.
Dammit, NO! I can't afford to get it!
Beverly...
scene: 116  INT. CRUSHER'S OFFICE - ANGLE ON BEVERLY

quote: Yes, Jean-Luc?
scene: 116  INT. CRUSHER'S OFFICE - ANGLE ON BEVERLY

quote: You will address me as Captain!
scene: 116  INT. CRUSHER'S OFFICE - ANGLE ON BEVERLY

quote: In which case, dear Captain, you will address me as 'Chief Medical Officer' or 'Doctor.'
scene: 116  INT. CRUSHER'S OFFICE - ANGLE ON BEVERLY

quote: That's true; I started off calling you 'Beverly,' then naturally, you... I'm still not thinking straight!
scene: 116  INT. CRUSHER'S OFFICE - ANGLE ON BEVERLY

quote: Likewise. Where the hell was I just headed?
scene: 116  INT. CRUSHER'S OFFICE - ANGLE ON BEVERLY

quote: If that's something you wanted to test...
scene: 116  INT. CRUSHER'S OFFICE - ANGLE ON BEVERLY

quote: Yes, yes, on Geordi!
scene: 116  INT. CRUSHER'S OFFICE - ANGLE ON BEVERLY

quote: Did you see how I reversed fields on this, Commander? Made it into a repulser beam.
If we had just a minute more, sir...
If this were a hundred times more powerful than it is...
I made this a broader based remedy... I hope. But it's still close to the formula from the old Enterprise's records...
Decades ago, light years away...
But almost exactly the same conditions as here.
What was in that, Doctor? My head's beginning to clear...
Take this to Engineering. I'll make up more hypos for the others.
Why not try it with the real thing?! Why not reverse fields on this, Ma'am? If we only need an extra minute...
It would take weeks of laying out new circuits...
But why not just see it in your head? (thinks, presses switches) Come off the main lead, split at the force activator, then...then... If I could just think straight about this...
We didn't make it, Captain. If we had just a minute or so more...
Yes, then reversing power leads, back through the force activator... repulser beam hard against the Tsiolkovsky...
We're pushing away!
(continuing; into communicator) Bridge, engage engines!
Sir, something seemed to move us aside at the last minute.
scene: 131  INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - FULL SHOT

quote: Do we owe our thanks to Commander Data, sir?
scene: 131  INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - FULL SHOT

quote: Yes. And... Wesley may have given us a few seconds, too.
scene: 131  INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - FULL SHOT

quote: Did he say Wesley? The boy?
scene: 131  INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - FULL SHOT

quote: He said Wesley.
scene: 131  INT. ENTERPRISE MAIN BRIDGE - FULL SHOT

quote: It is only fair to mention Wesley in a log entry, sir.
Fair is fair. And let's credit his science teacher, too.
Congratulations, sir.
To many people.
Data! I'm only going to tell you this just once... It never happened.
I put it to all of you we may end up with a fine crew... if we keep working at it. (nods for emphasis; then) So let's get to our next job, Number One.
Aye, sir. Helm, stand by for warp three. Heading two-hundred ninety-four mark thirty-seven.
Warp three, two-hundred ninety-four mark thirty-seven, sir.
Engage!

Captain's log, stardate 41463.9. We are mapping the Pleiades Cluster which has many young planets and we've been asked by the Federation to visit a group terraforming Velara III, which we would very much like to see. Communications have been erratic and there is some concern about their welfare.
scene: 1    EXT. SPACE - THE ENTERPRISE - VELARA III IN B.G.

quote: Entering standard orbit -- now.
It takes special people to live in such desolation.
Visionaries, who don't see this planet as it is, but as it will be.
I've always wanted to see terraforming in operation.
Hailing frequency, Lieutenant Yar.
Hailing frequencies open, sir.
Velara III base, this is Captain Picard of the starship Enterprise.
Lieutenant Yar... ?
No equipment malfunction on either end, sir. They are receiving.
Velara III, this is the Enterprise. Come in please.
Maybe nobody's home.
We are sensing life-forms, sir.
Velara III, do you copy?
Velara Base to Enterprise. Uh... yes, Captain. Director Mandl here. Sorry for the delay. We weren't expecting visitors.
Terraform Command has asked us to see how you were getting along.
... We were a little behind, but we're back on schedule.
We alarm him for some reason.
Your staff is all well, I presume, Director?
Understandably tired. We're all working very hard, Captain.
Is there anything we can do to help?... You and your staff are welcome aboard for a change of scene and some rest. We have some Holodecks you might enjoy.
No disrespect, sir, we can't afford to take the time.
His fear is escalating.
If you'll excuse me, I must get back to work.
I sense deliberate concealment, sir.
Of what?
I don't know, but it's intense.
We've heard so much about your remarkable achievements in terraforming, that my staff would very much appreciate looking around.
... It's not really the best time. We are at a critical phase just now.
We do not require any special attention.
I'm trying not to be rude, sir, but it would be inconvenient just now.
He's concealing something and it's more than just being too busy. Your announcement about coming down has pushed him almost to the point of panic.
Whether he wants us or not... Director Mandl, unless you are absolutely refusing permission for us to land on your station, please prepare to receive my away team.
As you wish.
Stay on your toes, Number One. Counselor, perhaps you should go along. A man this tense is unpredictable.
Welcome to Velara III. Remember it as it is now, because in a couple of decades you won't recognize the place. Luisa Kim. Gardener of Edens.
Commander William Riker, USS Enterprise. This is Lieutenant Commander Data, Counselor Troi, Lieutenant Yar and Lieutenant La Forge.
This is Bjorn Bensen, Chief Engineer, and Arthur Malencon, our Hydraulics Specialist,
An android.
And third in command of the Enterprise.
Where were you manufactured -- are there others like you?
Both matters are subjects of protracted discussion.
Remarkable.
We don't get visitors. It's exciting to have you here.
We weren't sure how we would be received. Director Mandl seemed less than enthusiastic about our interest.
I should apologize for him. We are at a critical phase. Usually he's quite charming.
We'll stay out of your way, it's just that we've never seen a terraforming station, and couldn't resist the opportunity.
How much do you know about the process?
The theories -- the reports -- but nothing firsthand.
Oh, wonderful. Then let me show you around.
The other two are as veiled and secretive as Mandl, but she is not.

What we're doing is so exciting, so -- inspiring. We take a lifeless planet and little by little transform it into an M-class environment, capable of supporting life. Terraforming makes you feel a little godlike. Is that a terribly arrogant thing to say?
Not at all. It is accurate.

The first phase is selecting the planet. That's very important. It must have the right mass and gravity, the correct rate of rotation, and a balanced day and night. The planet must also be without life or having the prospect of life delveloping naturally. The Federation makes that decision. Then... (she pauses a beat for emphasis) ... we take over.

What you see here -- this station -- is Phase Two. Phase Three involves the water. Usually we create basins, using hydraulic landscaping, but the water on this planet is subsurface, and extremely high in salt content. We are just about to begin pumping and filtering that water, removing the salt, oxygenating and replacing. Next we introduce micro-organisms, and when the process is complete...
... eventually, we'll have a lush, arable, biosphere.
You make it sound poetic.
I think it's the best occupation in the universe.
The efficiency of your hydraulic landscaping is elegant.
It isn't yet -- but it will be. Right now, I'm disturbed by erratic power surges in several of the servomechanisms that control the hydraulic probes.
Could it be the increased conductivity caused by the high saline content?
(with the enthusiasm of one scientist to another) That was my first thought, but..
Arthur.
We checked that out. That wasn't it.
