I'm Director Mandl. I am sorry about being so abrupt during our initial contact, being isolated one tends to forget the social graces. Are you seeing everything you want?
What you are doing here is miraculous.

What we are doing here is working on a difficult, demanding timetable, and there will be no miracle unless Malencon gets the hydraulic probes back on line. We are set to step up to full conversion, immediately. Shouldn't you be in the hydraulics chamber, Arthur?
Now?
Yes.
All right, Kurt.
That must be the master subsurface pump. Impressive.
(indicating another area on the computer screen) This is interesting. How the water table is a thin ribbon between the sandy surface layer and the rock below.
And it follows the contour precisely.
Which would require extreme precision from the probe controls.
Here's something which should interest you. The vegetation graphs are really the key element to successful terraforming.
Incredible. It's planned month by month, decade by decade.
Every single thing we do is specific and exacting. You see grand, romantic concepts. I see unyielding rock under an ocean of sand.
Commander... !
What is it, Deanna?
Malencon. He's in trouble.
Can you open it?
It's jammed.
Let me try.
We're too late.

Captain's log, supplemental. What began as a routine visit to the Federation group terraforming Velara III has become a serious situation. Arthur Malencon, the hydraulics engineer, has been killed in an extraordinary accident.
Situation report, Number One.

(tense, trying to save a life) For safety reasons, we're shutting off all power to the hydraulics room before entering to recover the body. Then we'll beam him up to Sickbay, but from the look of his wounds, it's probably hopeless.
Keep me informed.
Data... ?
Go ahead, Geordi.
All set.
We have your section powered down now. Bensen has locked the master servomotor drive system. It should be safe in there now.
I'm going in.
I will go with you.
Transporter Room, this is Lieutenant Yar. Two to beam up to Sickbay.
I want to go. We should be with him. Kurt, please come too.
Transporter Room, this is Commander Riker. Beam up four at my coordinates.
I have seen malfunctions, but this is unprecedented. Almost as if the laser drill attempted to tear itself apart.
I can't explain it.
The laser blasts seemed to end when the yelling stopped.
Maybe Arthur stopped it -- only not in time.
Not possible.
Then what are you suggesting?
Uncertain. Geordi, would you please return power to the control console in this room. I want to reactivate the program.
I am running the base drilling program.
Servos OFF!
They are off!
Data, what's happening?
Too much to explain.
La Forge to Enterprise. We have a problem!
Open the door!
STAY OUT! It is under control.
Data --
Are you injured?
No.
A year's work destroyed!
I had no choice.
Away team report now! What is happening?
... We were attempting to trace the source of the malfunction when it attacked me.
How much more of this fantasy must I listen to?
None at all, Mr. Mandl. Until this is sorted out, I've provided temporary quarters for you and your crew. I suggest you use them.
You're overstepping your authority, Picard! You have no right to interfere.
An attack on one of my crew gives me the right, Mr. Mandl.
I have a schedule to meet!
Your schedule is on hold, until I have a satisfactory explanation of what happened.
Director Mandl. Wait. Escort the director to his quarters.
Aye, sir.
Proceed with your report.
It would appear that the laser drilling systems had been reprogrammed. As soon as its memory bank received power, it turned itself on and went after me. Fortunately, I was able to cope with it.
Not by much, from what I saw.
I believe it was programmed to destroy any person moving in that room.
Speculation or certainty?
Certainty.
It would have required the talents of a master programmer.
But it was done.

Then the question is not who, because obviously it was one of the three remaining terraformers. The question is why. What are they hiding? What is so important it could make one of them, or all of them desperate enough to take a life?
Shall I have them brought in, sir?
Not yet.
Doctor Crusher?
Malencon never had a chance. The injuries were too severe, the damage too extensive.
The entire Velara III facility has been powered down, Captain.
We've just completed a remote power feed to the life support systems.
Good. Data, I want you and Geordi to return for a more careful inspection.
What are we to look for, sir?
Evidence of tampering, negligence, sabotage... whatever. I don't know, but the answer's there, on the planet.

Tasha, I'd like you to provide Counselor Troi and me with complete personnel files on our three guests. Psych profiles, training, everything. I'm looking for motive, intent... the psychological capacity to commit one murder and attempt another.
Aye, sir.
It seems we've become policemen, Number One.
Geordi. I need some visual assistance.
What is it?
Inorganic. Nothing but basic elements. No carbon... sandy texture... But the flashes are almost... musical. I see color variations and rhythms which are like a melody.
Speculation. Could it be alive?
How could it be alive? It's inorganic.
Whatever this is, it could be what they are covering up -- and the reason someone killed Malencon.
Captain's log, supplemental. On my order, Data's startling discovery of a possible indigenous and inorganic life-form -- something hitherto thought impossible...
... has been beamed aboard so that its true nature might be uncovered.
Activate.
Let's be sure of what we have here. Is the sample organic?
Negative carbon. Negative known life components. Substance inorganic.
Recheck analysis.
Rechecking... Analysis verified. Not organic.
Magnify to screen.
Magnify -- factor rate five. Hold surface. Rate ten. Hold.
What are we looking at?
It's really beautiful. Whatever it is...
What's causing that hum?
Computer, what is the magnification?
Twenty five thousand diameters and holding.
Analysis. The pattern of the flashes.
Not random or repetitive or sequential. Pattern not recognized.
What is the source of the flashes?
Unable to specify. Theoretically not possible from this substance.
Disregard incongruity and theorize as to source?
Life.
What do you mean a life-form?! What life-form?! A Federation recon expedition certified Velara III lifeless.
Understandable, given this particular life-form's novel nature.
And just what is that nature?
Doctor Crusher is still making her determination. I presume you know the Prime Directive, Mr. Mandl.
Are you saying I knowingly defied it?
I don't know. But I intend to find out. You're a man obsessed with what he does. Who knows what an obsessed man would do to keep going? Kill, perhaps?
I create life! I don't take it!
What do you think?
You hit him pretty hard, Captain.
Counselor?
It was useful. I felt two levels. He knew about the life-form. The idea of murder seemed to shock him. I couldn't tell if it was the whole idea, or just being accused of it.
What about his file, Lieutenant Yar? Could he have accomplished the reprogramming that Data says took place?
Mandl holds advanced degrees in Computer Science as well as Artificial Intelligence. It's possible.
What about the others? Including the victim.

Only the victim had the required expertise. But Malencon did work where the... whatever-it-is... was found. Trying to suppress that knowledge would be motive for murder... if Mandl were obsessed enough.
Terraformers are often obsessive. It goes with the career profile.
How do you read the designer?
Possessed of a highly abstracted reality. Lovely visions, little data. You might do better than I.
Luisa... are you all right?
It isn't locked.
Mind a visitor?
Is it true... did you really find a life-form?
It's still being debated in some quarters. But I think so, yes.
What's it like?
We have nothing to compare it to, but it's microscopic... seems colonial... simple... and inorganic. That's why the recon scouts missed it. This one wasn't your mistake.
Everything I've worked for is falling apart.
It's very beautiful. I'll arrange for you to see it, if you like.
Perhaps later.
Captain, this is Doctor Crusher. I think you'd better come to the Medical Lab.
What is it?
Geordi observed movement.
It's not exactly movement, it's a shift in the energy pattern.
Without external influence.
Couldn't coordinated static charges promote the shift?
Yes, if any were present in the jar, but none is.
It's changing.
I can't see any difference.
The infrared range is increasing.
Warning. Input overload. Input overload.
It is projecting an energy field!
And it's increasing!
Only life can replicate itself, Doctor. Inorganic or not, it is alive.
Activate quarantine field.
Quarantine field full!
(continuing; more imperative) Full shield backup!
Translation request being patched.
Translation? From whom?
Evacuating lab.
Full shield backup in place but weakening... translation grhjkj wljkdh...
What's going on with the translator circuit?
bridge, this is the captain. Request emergency power to increase lab quarantine seal...
Do it, Mister Worf. What's the nature of the problem, Captain? We've lost visual.
We have confirmed Data's discovery is life, but more than that - it is intelligent.
How do you know?
It has just taken possession of the Medical Lab.
Because it's trying to communicate with us!

Captain's log, supplemental. We are attempting to deal with the aggressive inorganic life-form which Data brought up from the planet. It has taken over the Medical Lab, and is apparently attempting to communicate with us.
It generates enough energy to interfere with surrounding systems.
Mr. La Forge -- can we see into the lab yet?
Negative, Captain. But, reducing backup to the quarantine seal might help.
Doctor?
I wouldn't.
Continue backup to shield, Lieutenant.
Director Mandl and the others are in the Observation Lounge as you requested.
Counselor, I'll need you. You have the bridge, Number One.
What do you know of this life-form?
Nothing.
You knew of its existence.
Yes.
Is this true? You knew there was life on Velara III?
I knew there were random energy patterns -- I knew that. But that's not life. Not by any definition I have ever heard.
But, you tried to hide that knowledge from us.
They're meaningless silicon crystals, which rebroadcast sunlight. This is absurd.
They are not only alive but they have intelligence.
Why do you say that?
They're trying to communicate with us.
Communicate with you?
I need information, now. When did you first see them? What were they doing? Why did you think they were alive?
... There were patterns, in the sand, appearing and disappearing --
Captain, we've regained a visual on the lab.
Patch visual to Observation Lounge...
I cannot understand the patterns.
Neither can I.
Please show me the spectral analysis. Magnification twelve K.
But is it alive?!
Probability positive...
I wasn't asking you.
Engineering to bridge.
This is Commander Riker, go ahead.
The backup on the lab seal is fluctuating, sir. I think you should come down here.
On my way. Data, you have the bridge. Inform the captain.
Status, Ensign?

The quarantine seal is getting weaker. Every time I try to redirect backup... it goes somewhere else. I think I've... it's... locked three people in a turbolift and two more in the programmers' rest room.
If that's reading right, there is no seal. Give me a lab interior image.
Magnify.
Captain, this is Riker.
We see it too, Number One.
Get that seal back up!
No matter what I do, the energy goes somewhere else. What if it hits the Nursery... Or Sickbay... ?
Hold off. Impossible, Captain. We haven't got the power.
The Universal Translator is coming on line.
Ugly... Ugly... Giants... Bags of Mostly Water...
Bags of mostly water?
An accurate description, sir, of humans. You are, after all, over ninety per cent water, surrounded by a flexible container.
Do you understand me?
We understand. We ask you be gone... We call... We talk... You not listen.
We didn't hear you. We come in peace.
Ugly Bag of Mostly Water... we try at peace... you still not listen. Bag in Dome on Sand of Home... we killed.
It killed Malencon.
We see and hear you now. We didn't know you were there. You are beautiful to us. All life is beautiful.
Bag in dome did know. Made some of us die. Made us kill. War is now with you.
Can you hear me?
Duty stations! Report!
Restabilizing, sir.
Sir...
What is it, Data?
That chaos in the lab, when we were studying it... must have been the energy surge of a reproductive cycle. It is now a colony of single cells which organize as a computer.
More is stronger.
Captain's log, supplemental. We've stumbled on a life-form...
... biologically and psychologically difficult for us to fully understand. The only thing totally clear is that this microbrain, as we've come to call it, has declared war on us.
Their range of influence appears to be concentrated in the Medical Lab, Captain.
All non-essential personnel have been moved to the most distant areas of the ship, sir.
Data -- any analysis of those bolts of light they emit?

That seems to be their method of reprogramming, Captain. Each bolt of light consists of negatively and positively charged ions. A series of program instructions, as it were. They seem to have a quicker rapport with our computers than we do.
What do you expect? They are computers.
Have we disabled the Medical Lab computer console?
Aye, sir, as soon as Data determined the microbrain's method of operation.
I am picking up a decrease in the infra-red intensity.
Maybe the life-form has reached its own energy limit.
Or maybe this is not the end of it. With single-celled life-forms... at least organic ones, cell division can be preceded by a resting state.
The calm before the storm.
Let's use the calm. Medical Lab on main viewer.
It does seem dormant.
Lieutenant Yar - set coordinates to beam it back where it came from.
Coordinates set.
Energize!
Transporter power has been redirected, sir. We are unable to affect it.
Life-form or not... intelligent or not -- the safety of this ship and all on her are my primary responsibility. Data -- evacuate the air from the Medical Lab. I want a vacuum in there.
Environmental systems fail to respond to commands, Captain. It appears the microbrain has successfully interfaced with our computer.
Suggestions? Anyone?
I need your help. We have communicated with the life-form discovered on Velara III.
You have what?!
It has told us that it attempted to communicate with you, and you ignored it.
If it was trying to communicate with us, we didn't understand that.
We didn't try.
What you were doing was so threatening to them that they killed your hydraulics engineer to stop it. They have declared a state of war.
A state of war?!

Yes, and we're on the defensive. I need your help. I have to find some way to fight them. We no longer have control of the Medical Lab, or the computer. At this moment they have the power to destroy this ship and everyone on it.
Unbelievable. What can we do to help?
They said you killed some of them. I need to know how.
I -- I don't know.
Exactly what was Malencon doing when he was killed?
There is a very thin layer of highly saline water under the sandy topsoil. He was siphoning that off.
Why would that kill some of them?
Liquid supports life. Perhaps somehow, that saline water sustained them.
It connected them.
I don't understand.
The microbrains are like our brain cells. Individually a cell has life -- but not intelligence -- yet when interconnected their combined intelligence is formidable.
So that saline fluid is their circuitry.
And to prevent its loss, they killed Malencon.
If we had continued to remove the water... we would have destroyed them all.
Reason enough for anyone to go to war.
Captain -- it's happening again!
If this keeps up, that thing will tear the Enterprise apart!
Captain -- sensors indicate the microbrain expends a tremendous amount of energy during its reproduction cycle. Yet, there is no discernible power drain from our own systems.
Then what's feeding the damn thing!?
Data and I found traces of cadmium salts. Cadmium is a conduit for converting infra-red into electricity.
Meaning?
Meaning the microbrains might be photoelectric.
Okay, let's see if darkness will neutralize them. Kill the lights in the lab, Mr. La Forge. We can at least do that.
Sorry, Captain, can't do it by remote.
Number One...
On my way.
The creatures must have evolved at that narrow layer where the light got through the sand to the water... Drop the water a centimeter below the light penetration level and they starve.
Kill lab lights -- now!
It's slowing down.
Getting dimmer, too.
We copy fine now... more light please...
Darkness death terrible. Go home to warm sand... War over.
We are happy to agree with you.
Riker to Transporter Chief. Pick up the coordinates of the bell jar in the Medical Lab for return to Velara III.
... Coordinates entered, sir.
Riker to bridge. Captain, we're ready to beam it back to the planet.
I wish we were able to learn more about them.
In time, Mr. Data. When we're better prepared.
Our apologies.
And our respect. Lieutenant Yar...
Coordinates set, sir.
Energize!
Captain's log, stardate 41464.2. Declaring indefinite quarantine for the Velara System...
... Returning to starbase with surviving Terraformers.
Captain's log, stardate 41365.9. The Enterprise has been ordered to Starbase 74, in orbit around Tarsas III.

... where a routine maintenance check of all systems will be made, and certain upgrades completed, including the Holodeck, with which we have had problems. I anticipate a glowing report. This ship has performed magnificently -- beyond anyone's expectations.
Coming into position.
Stand by to dock.
Ready to dock.
Engage mooring beams and lock off.
Aye sir.
Docking complete.
Thank you, Number One. Well done, and well done all.
Commander Quinteros; request permission to come aboard.
Granted -- and welcome.
This is Commander Riker.
You're late. We expected you a week ago.
We were unexpectedly delayed at Omicron Pascal.
Is there anything specific you wish to report, or that we should be aware of?
No. We are very pleased with the operation of the Enterprise.
I knew you would be - I was in charge of the team which put her together.
And are these gentlemen the Bynars?
They're not gentlemen or ladies, Commander. They are a unified pair. Always together. This is One Zero.
And this is Zero One.
They just finished upgrading the computers on the Wellington -- did a great job.
Your reputation precedes you. I am pleased you will be improving our system.
It is a great pleasure...
... to work on such a large mobile computer.
You have forty-eight hours, because at forty-eight plus six we have an appointment at Pelleus Five which we must keep.
I thought we'd...
... have more time.
I'm sorry. Our mission can't be delayed. Can we postpone this work?
Oh, no. This is...
... the best time...
... to do it.
We can complete...
... our work within the...
... time allotted.
They work very quickly, but it'll be tight.
Commander Riker and I will stay aboard, and be available should you need us.
Thank you, Captain. I don't think we'll need you until we're ready for inspection.
The Bynars are perfect for this. This is the first time I've come in contact with them.

As I understand it, over time they've become so interconnected with the master computer on their planet that their language and thought patterns have become as near to binary as possible for organic beings.
It will be interesting to see how they improve a computer as advanced as ours.
Well, I'm going to put my feet up, turn on my personal relaxation light and lose myself in the pages of some old novels.
Bridge. And you, Number One? You've earned a good rest. What are you going to do with it?
I've never been good at organizing my time off, but something will come up -- it always does.
I'll be in my Ready Room.
I thought there were only going to be two of you.
Because of the limited time allotted...
... us, we need others...
(picking up on their agitation) Is there a problem?
Ah... No...
...no. No problem.
Then why are you all so excited?
Because we... ah... have to...
... the ah, stacking...
... to reconfigure the computer...
... to communicate with itself...
... more efficiently...
... and at higher speeds.
You act like you don't believe them.
I'm not sure. It's probably nothing.
Maybe it's just how a different species behaves.
Maybe. I'm going to stroll the ship. You have the bridge. Keep an eye on them.
Aye sir.
We've been challenged to a friendly game of Parrises Squares by some of the maintenance personnel -- want to join us on the starbase?
You've already got all the players you need.
We can switch off.
No... if you do that in Parrises Squares you lose the rhythm of the game.
I can't talk you into coming with us?
No. But win, all right? The pride of the Enterprise goes with you.
Rest assured, Commander, we will be victorious, at whatever the cost.
Worf -- it's just a game. You know, a little friendly competition -- work up a sweat, have some laughs, make new friends.
(with a gleam in his eye) If winning is not important... then, Commander, why keep score?
I think he's pulling your leg. Believe it or not, Worf's developing a sense of humor.
Let's hope so for their sake.
Computer -- There's a power reduction in section L-Ninety Four. Explain.
Unoccupied sections are being closed down in order to clear space in the main computer banks. It's necessary to facilitate the system upgrade. Full power can be restored if needed.
What do you think?
scene: 15   INT. OBSERVATION LOUNGE - CLOSE ON PAINTING

quote: First tell me what it's supposed to be, then I'll give you an opinion.
scene: 15   INT. OBSERVATION LOUNGE - CLOSE ON PAINTING

quote: It is an attempt at pure creativity.
scene: 15   INT. OBSERVATION LOUNGE - CLOSE ON PAINTING

quote: What we're investigating is, "Can Data be creative?"
scene: 15   INT. OBSERVATION LOUNGE - CLOSE ON PAINTING

quote: This is my attempt... with guidance from Geordi.
scene: 15   INT. OBSERVATION LOUNGE - CLOSE ON PAINTING

quote: I suggested the Zylo eggs.
scene: 15   INT. OBSERVATION LOUNGE - CLOSE ON PAINTING

quote: Is that what those are?
scene: 15   INT. OBSERVATION LOUNGE - CLOSE ON PAINTING

quote: Keep notes. This project might turn out to be of interest to future scholars.
scene: 15   INT. OBSERVATION LOUNGE - CLOSE ON PAINTING

quote: Really?
scene: 15   INT. OBSERVATION LOUNGE - CLOSE ON PAINTING

quote: Think about it. A blind man teaching an android to paint? That's got to be worth a couple of pages in someone's book.
scene: 15   INT. OBSERVATION LOUNGE - CLOSE ON PAINTING

quote: You look like you're packing up and leaving forever.
Oh -- Commander Riker. No -- I'm just getting my notes together. It's so exciting. Doctor Terence Epstein is at this Starbase.
Is he someone I should know about?

He's the leading mind in cybernetics. He lectured at my medical school. Since the disaster at Micromius I've been working on a theory combining cybernetics and regeneration. It sounds impossible I know -- but I think I have an approach which could work. What an opportunity! To have a chance to discuss this with Doctor Esptein. Sorry, Will, I'd like to stay here and chat -- but I have to be going.
How's it going?
We are almost done...
... the deviation...
... caused by a previous...
... probe has been corrected...
... You may use the equipment...
... anytime you wish.
How much has it been changed? What exactly did you do?
Enhancement...
... nothing more.
This could be perfect!
Let's use him!
Would you like to try...
... the enhancement?
All right. What should I do?
Computer - I need a place to play some music - a little atmosphere.
Specify.
Jazz.
Era?
Circa 1958.
Location.
Kansas City. No, wait. New Orleans. Yeah. New Orleans -- the Low Note. 'Round midnight.
Program complete. Enter when ready.
Very good.
Very good indeed.
Now, computer -- someone to play with. A combo. Say, drums upright bass...piano. And a 'bone for me.
Now -- an audience...
Whoa... too many. I was thinking of something a little more personal...intimate.
Great job, boys.
But, computer... blondes and jazz seldom go together.
(continuing; he turns to the Bynars.) Now that is truly exceptional... (then back to the computer) ...but... more sultry.
Gentlemen, if this is what you call "enhancement" you have a gift for understatement.
What's your name, and tell me you love jazz.
My name is Minuet. I love all jazz except Dixieland.
Why not Dixieland?
Because you can't dance to it.
My girl.
What's a knockout like you doing in a computer-generated joint like this?
Waiting for you.
Waiting for me?!! You can't be serious?
Oh yes, Will -- I've never been more serious in my life.
It's working. All we need...
... is to hold him here for twenty minutes.
Do you mind if I ask you a question about the Bynars?
Why not just ask them?
What is that high-speed sound you make?
That is our...
... primary language.
How can humanoids process information at that speed?
We store the information...
... with these buffers.
We receive information...
... all the time...
... and save it...
... until we need it.
How did you happen to develop this ability?
It happened over...
... a long period of time.
To have a society so interdependent on computers has tremendous advantages.
And a few...
...disadvantages.
Everything under control, Ensign Crusher?
Fine, Captain. I am just trying to learn something about the Bynars.
Where's Commander Riker?
Holodeck Four. Shall I call him for you, sir?
No, I'll wander down and see what's he doing to occupy himself. Keep me apprised.
Yes, sir.
The chick digs you, man.
What makes you say that?
Hey -- look at her.
Maybe it's my music.
Yeah, well - about that... Don't give up your day job.
It's all too real.
Yeah, Slim you got that straight... too real is too right.
Thanks for letting me sit in.
Ain't nothin' to it.
Strange cat...
I know this. If they're in town -- we get 'em.
I am going to have to leave you for a while and see to my duties.
Your work is very important to you.
It is me -- it's what I am.
Can we dance once before you leave?
Sure, why not.
How did you learn to dance so well?
From following you.
I can anticipate your lead. Tell me more about your work -- what is it about it that consumes and enthralls you?
What an interesting choice of words. That's exactly what it does.
You are very fortunate.
I know that.
At this point in your life to be exactly where you want to be... And it's wonderful that you realize it.
I'd be a fool not to know how lucky I am to be on this ship serving with this group of people. It's a dream come true.
Just like this.
A dream? Is that what this is? Is that what I am?
I know you are a computer-generated image... but your smell, the way you feel, your touch, even the way you talk and think is so real.
Thank you.
How far can this relationship go? I mean, how real are you?
As real as you need me to be.
Astounding.
Captain!
Sorry, Number One -- I didn't mean to interrupt.
It's all right, come in.
You picked a wonderful locale. Something I might have chosen myself.
Aren't you going to introduce me?
Excuse me. Yes, yes, of course I am. Captain Picard, this is Minuet... Minuet, this is Captain Jean-Luc Picard.
Enchante. Comme c'est merveilleux de vous voir ici.
Incroyable! Vous etes Parisienne?
Au fonde c'est vrai, nous sommes tous Parisienne.
Oui, au fonde nous sommes tous Parisienne. The spirit of that city can always restore my soul.
I have been hoping to meet you.
Oh. Have I been a topic of conversation?
Indirectly.
Join us, Jean-Luc.
A glass of wine?
Thank you.
Will was saying how much he enjoys this assignment. It's a credit to you. For a ship and crew to function well it always starts with the captain. You set the tone.
At the moment, it's you who are setting the tone. The sophistication of this programming is remarkable.
In what way?

The Holodeck has been able to give us woodlands and ski slopes and figures that fight and fictional characters with which we can interact -- but you are quite different. You adapt. You spoke French to me.
It's very simple. When I heard your name, I merely accessed the foreign language bank.
Impressive.
Oui, mon choux.
Now what are you doing?
I am awaiting inspiration.
Commander Data.
This is Commander Data, go ahead.
I'm getting an indication of possible trouble in Main Engineering.
Can you be more specific?
Not very much. I'm reading a problem with the magnetic field which contains the antimatter. Could you come up here?
We'll go to Engineering since that's where the trouble is. Wes, don't disturb the captain or Commander Riker until we check this out.
Aye, sir.
bridge, this is Main Engineering.
This is the bridge.
Are you running any test programs?
No.
Are the Bynars?
Not to my knowledge. Is something wrong?
I don't know. There's nobody on duty here, and we're getting a strange reading from the magnetic containment field.
The field is deteriorating. Contact the captain immediately. I am initiating Red Alert.
I can't maintain the integrity of the containment field.
If the antimatter is released the ship will be destroyed.
Nothing I do has any effect. I'm losing it. I have rechecked every circuit. This is not a misread by the computer.
Computer -- situation analysis.
Estimate release of antimatter in four minutes eighteen seconds -- seventeen seconds -- sixteen seconds...
Bridge -- Engineering.
Yes. This is the bridge.

Alert starbase. Inform them we are abandoning the ship. Tell them why. Initiate the automated sequence for departure, lay in a course and speed to put maximum distance between the Enterprise and any inhabited planet.
Shouldn't we wait for the captain's approval?
There is no time. Based on all the information presently available the decision is correct. This is Lieutenant Commander Data speaking for the captain -- abandon ship -- this is not a drill.
I say again. All personnel abandon ship. Abandon ship -- this is not a drill -- this is not a drill.

Decks One through Four to Cargo Transporters. Decks Five through Ten: Transporters: One-Two, Three-Four. Decks Six through Sixteen: Transporters: Five-Six, Seven-Eight, Nine-Ten. Decks Seventeen through Twenty-eight to Transporters: Eleven-Twelve, Thirteen-Fourteen. Decks Twenty-nine through Forty-two: Transporters: Fifteen-Sixteen, Seventeen-Eighteen, Nineteen-Twenty. This is not a drill.
scene: 48   INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDORS (CONTINUE SERIES OF SHOTS)

quote: When I reviewed your fifth paper on molecular biology, I knew I was on the right track. You defined the problem as conductivity -- and that's exactly what...
Attention all personnel. Emergency evacuation of USS Enterprise in progress. Report to your stations.
Oh, no! Something's happened to the Enterprise. That's my ship!
Hurry up! We don't have much time! The ship'll be leaving in a minute!
What's going on?
scene: 51   INT. STARBASE COMMAND CENTER - NEW ANGLE

quote: Please stand out of the way.
scene: 51   INT. STARBASE COMMAND CENTER - NEW ANGLE

quote: The Enterprise is being evacuated.
scene: 51   INT. STARBASE COMMAND CENTER - NEW ANGLE

quote: Why?
scene: 51   INT. STARBASE COMMAND CENTER - NEW ANGLE

quote: Some problem in Engineering.
scene: 51   INT. STARBASE COMMAND CENTER - NEW ANGLE

quote: Get the security team together.
scene: 51   INT. STARBASE COMMAND CENTER - NEW ANGLE

quote: Aye, Lieutenant.
scene: 51   INT. STARBASE COMMAND CENTER - NEW ANGLE

quote: Ship's log. Supplemental. This is Lieutenant Commander Data. I have put the ship on automated departure and ordered the complete evacuation of the Enterprise. Everyone remaining is leaving on foot or beaming off.
Computer, where are the captain and Commander Riker?
All decks empty.
Curious. The captain is usually the last to leave.
Let's go! We only have forty-one seconds.
I think we're the last.
I hope we are the last.
Did you see the captain and Commander Riker?
scene: 53   INT. STARBASE SPACE STATION COMMAND CENTER (OPTICAL)

quote: No. Are they not here on the Starbase?
scene: 53   INT. STARBASE SPACE STATION COMMAND CENTER (OPTICAL)

quote: No.
scene: 53   INT. STARBASE SPACE STATION COMMAND CENTER (OPTICAL)

quote: Are you saying they are still on the Enterprise?
scene: 53   INT. STARBASE SPACE STATION COMMAND CENTER (OPTICAL)

quote: Yes. Sir, where's your Transporter Room?
scene: 53   INT. STARBASE SPACE STATION COMMAND CENTER (OPTICAL)

quote: We have to beam back and get them.
scene: 53   INT. STARBASE SPACE STATION COMMAND CENTER (OPTICAL)

quote: You haven't time!
scene: 53   INT. STARBASE SPACE STATION COMMAND CENTER (OPTICAL)

quote: This is Starbase 74. The Enterprise magnetic field is regenerating.
scene: 53   INT. STARBASE SPACE STATION COMMAND CENTER (OPTICAL)

quote: How is that possible?
scene: 53   INT. STARBASE SPACE STATION COMMAND CENTER (OPTICAL)

quote: Unknown.
scene: 53   INT. STARBASE SPACE STATION COMMAND CENTER (OPTICAL)

quote: That changes nothing. The captain and Commander Riker must be in trouble, or they'd be here.
scene: 53   INT. STARBASE SPACE STATION COMMAND CENTER (OPTICAL)

quote: Look!
scene: 53   INT. STARBASE SPACE STATION COMMAND CENTER (OPTICAL)

quote: Your ship's almost clear.
scene: 53   INT. STARBASE SPACE STATION COMMAND CENTER (OPTICAL)

quote: The USS Enterprise has departed in excess of warp one.
... and the boy never found out?
Oh, yes, but not until later. When he finally walked in with his younger sister.
And I'll bet both of them were all smiles.
Yes. And we knew right then both of them had found out.
You handled it in a very thoughtful way. You are very good with people. Don't you agree, Jean-Luc?
She's very different from any images we've experienced on the Holodeck, isn't she? More -- you might say -- intuitive.
It's as though she was plugged into my subconscious and can anticipate what I want her to say even before I'm aware of it myself.
I suppose it's an understandable progression. Computers make decisions based on inputs and we humans give off many subtle signs which communicate our emotions.
It's uncanny. I could develop feelings for Minuet. A desire exactly as I would for any woman.
Doesn't love always begin that way? With the illusion being more real than the woman?
Oh, Jean-Luc, spoken like a true Frenchman.
I think I'll be leaving.
Oh, don't go.
Two's company.
We have time -- there's no rush. I'd like it very much if you would stay.
Yes, stay, Captain.
This is your diversion, Number One. Not mine.
Wait -- we haven't danced.
I don't dance.
Then some more wine.
Thank you, no.
Wait -- please. Please don't go -- you can't. Not yet.
What?
Why -- Minuet -- what's the matter? Why can't he leave?
Exit.
bridge, this is the captain. Situation report.
Riker to bridge.
Computer! Explain Red Alert.
Initiated as a programmed response. The magnetic field containing the antimatter had weakened. There was no fail-safe available.
Why wasn't I notified?
Unknown.
Present condition.
The magnetic field is now restored. Containment is restored. Propulsion is at maximum efficiency.
Locate Lieutenant Commander Data.
Not on board the Enterprise.
Explain.
All Enterprise personnel except the captain and first officer have been evacuated.
Evacuated!? Was the condition that critical?
Yes.
Are we still docked on the starbase?
No.
Position report.
Coordinates four-one-five-nine point two-six by eight-one-nine-two-one by three-one-two. Heading Two-three-three mark four-five.
Destination?
Planet Bynaus in the Beta Magellan system.
The Bynars!
Am I to understand that the Bynars have stolen the Enterprise?
That information is not available.
It's the Bynars -- and you're part of this.
Yes.
They made you the lure to keep me here! They programmed you while I was relaxing.
Yes. When they saw your interest in me, they thought I could distract you and keep you here.
That explains, Riker... What about me?
Your being here was just a fortunate happenstance.
Why do they want me?
What do they want with the Enterprise? What's their purpose?
I am not programmed to give you that information.
Come on, Number One. We've got to regain control of our ship!
What do we do?
Which is the nearest Starfleet vessel?
The Trieste.
I know the Trieste. Too small, too slow.
Plus it's sixty-six hours away.
Where are the Bynars?
... I haven't seen them.
Then they are obviously still aboard. Another Starfleet vessel must be sent to intercept the Enterprise at Bynaus. They might be taking the ship to their home planet.
What makes you think so?
It is the best place for us to start.
Captain's log, supplemental. We now know "who" has commandeered the Enterprise... the Bynars. We can't communicate with the bridge. Commander Riker and I will now try to regain control of our ship.
This way.
But that's toward Engineering.
That's our first stop, to verify the containment, and initiate auto-destruct.
Initiate auto-destruct?
The ship has been commandeered by a force of unknown size and intent. We're here alone. We must assume the worst.
If we don't regain control, no one else will have it either. This is the only decision involving the operation of this ship which requires you and I to agree totally.
It's the allotted time that concerns me.
About that, there is no option.
I know. It's a five minute countdown.

It's sufficient to get to the bridge... once there, either we'll get control of the ship and shut off the auto-destruct, or we won't. The important thing is that this ship does not fall into hostile hands.
Then let's set it and get going.
Recognize Picard, Jean-Luc, Captain... Recognize Riker, William T, Commander.
Set auto-destruct sequence.
Does the first officer concur?
... Yes. Set auto-destruct sequence -- now!
Auto-destruct will detonate in four minutes and fifty-nine seconds... four minutes and fifty-eight seconds... four minutes and fifty-seven seconds...
Let's go. The only place we can stop the count is from the bridge.
What do you make of this?
An enormous amount of data is being received and stored in the main computer.
Just stored. Why?
It's another piece to this puzzle.
Access denied.
They've locked it off.
We've got to find another way to get in.
One of us could beam onto the bridge.
It takes several seconds to materialize. You wouldn't stand a chance.
I could beam into the turbolift, force the doors, and take them by surprise.
No. We'll beam in simultaneously in two different areas of the bridge.
Only four minutes left.
Still no response from the Enterprise.
They would answer if they could. Someone else has control of the ship.
Do you think I am responsible?
Why? How could you have known?
My station is on the bridge.
You can't be on the bridge every minute.
You are wrong, Geordi, I can. I do not need rest or diversion -- I should not have been painting. I was negligent.
That's a pointless discussion. You could have been on the bridge and it still might have happened.
(continuing; to Quinteros) You have three ships in here. We need one of them now.
We're rushing repairs on the USS Melbourne -- but it's still eighteen hours until she'll be ready... There is nothing else you can do.
I'll set a ten-second delay.
Right. Coordinates for Main Bridge -- port forward for me and aft for you.
You're on Pad Two.
Done. Ten second delay... NOW.
Why did you steal my ship?
Please try...
... to help us.
Cancel auto-destruct.
Does the first officer agree?
Affirmative.
Auto-destruct cancelled.
We're in orbit around Bynaus. How are they?
They appear dead.
Let's see if we can get some answers from Bynaus.
Their main computer is off. Sensors reveal all of the equipment on the planet is inert. They can neither receive nor send any messages.
What about all the people in that world who are totally dependant on their computer? Are they still functioning?
No. They are probably just like these Bynars here. Dying.
So, what's this all about? Why did they steal the ship and bring it here? What was their purpose?
They went to a lot of trouble to clear computer space. See what they've stored.
Captain, it's enormous. Every byte of free space in the computer has been filled. They must have made a core-dump from their world to our computer.
I can't get in.
(continuing; reading the Screen) I need a code -- a password -- to access the file.
They were desperate to steal this ship, bring it here to store all this information. Why?
I don't know. I wish they had left a note.
Perhaps they did.
Minuet.
Maybe.
Tell me what this is all about.
A star in the Bynar system went super nova and they miscalculated. The electromagnetic pulse from the explosion was going to knock out their main computer.
Their only chance was to transfer all the stored information and shut down until after it passed. Then, reactivate their system and transfer the information back to this main computer.
And the Enterprise has the only mobile computer large enough to handle all that information.
So what went wrong?
The star went super nova before it was expected and you were late arriving at Starbase 74.
But why steal the ship? Why didn't they say something? Why didn't they just ask for help?
I don't know. I don't have those answers.
Is there anything we can do?
Yes. Return the data stored in the Enterprise's computer back to the one on Bynaus.
How do we do that?
Don't you know?
Yes. If we had the file name. But we don't. Do you?
I don't know what you're talking about. No.
They wouldn't intentionally hide it or make it difficult for us to find. It's got to be right in front of us.
We should call Starbase 74, and see if anyone can decipher this.
Hurry. They're dying. They meant you no harm. It was their world they were trying to save. Help them, Will -- please help them.
Starbase 74 -- this is the Enterprise.
This is Starbase 74. Captain Picard, what's your situation?
We'll get into that later. Right now I must speak with Lieutenant Commander Data.
I am here, sir.
Data, the Bynars have stored an enormous amount of information in the computer. We can't access it, and we must.
The access would be available by code or password.
I know, but what could it be?
File names can be anything.
They want us to find it. They would have kept it simple.
Then a name -- or a place. It could be personal. In this case in binary language which is ones and zeros in groups of eight or sixteen characters.
Could it be that simple? Try it.
That's the file. It'll work now.
Well done, Will. Now access the file and start the transfer.
So much for that idea.
Let me get on the other position. The Bynars always work in pairs, perhaps that is also required.
It appears to be successful. The system has started up -- a resident diagnostic program is running. Their system is incredible.
You...
... did it.
(showing relief and happiness) ... our world is...
... reactivating.
Our people...
... express their gratitude.
... We will return to...
... your Starbase for whatever...
... punishment your system...
... requires of us.
Why didn't you just ask for our help?
You might have...
... said no.
But there was a very good chance we would have said "yes."
Our need was too great...
... to risk rejection.
So you stole it.
Their reason is part of their binary thinking -- for them there are only two choices -- one or zero -- yes or no.
No one's been hurt. They accomplished their objective. They have their world back in order, and we have our ship.
It's been some time since I had the Conn.
But, not to worry, Number One you're in good hands. Starbase 74 -- at warp two.
Engage.
Under complete control.
We are all right, everything is fine. Now -- I want a complete check of all systems and divisions.
What about the Bynars?
Turn them over to Quinteros. There will be a hearing.
We understood that...
... would happen.
That being the case -- permission to leave the bridge.
Permission granted.
Program entered - you may enter the Holodeck.
What's a knockout like you doin' in a computer-generated joint like this?
You're not Minuet.
She's gone. I tried variations of the program, others appeared, but not Minuet.
Maybe that too, was part of the Bynar's program. Some relationships just can't work.
(he can agree intellectually, but emotionally it's not easy) Yes... probably true... but, she will be difficult to forget.
Captain's log, stardate 42353.7. Our destination is planet Cygnus IV, beyond which lies the great unexplored mass of the galaxy.
My orders are to examine Farpoint, a starbase built there by the inhabitants of that world. Meanwhile ...
... I am becoming better acquainted with my new command, this Galaxy Class U.S.S. Enterprise.
I am still somewhat in awe of its size and complexity.
... my crew we are short in several key positions, most notably ...
... a first officer, but I am informed that a highly experienced man, one Commander William Riker, will be waiting to join our ship when we reach our Cygnus IV destination.
You will agree, Data, that Starfleet's instructions are difficult?
Difficult ... how so? Simply solve the mystery of Farpoint Station.
As simple as that.
Farpoint Station. Even the name sounds mysterious.
The problem, Data, is that another life form built that base. How do I negotiate a friendly agreement for Starfleet to use it while at the same time snoop around finding how and why they built it?
Inquiry ... the word snoop ... ?
Data, how can you be programmed as a virtual encyclopedia of human information without knowing a simple word like snoop?
Possibility ... a kind of human behavior I was not designed to emulate?
It means 'to spy, to sneak' ...
(interrupting; delighted) Ah! To seek covertly, to go stealthily, to slink, slither ...
Exactly, yes ...
... to glide, creep, skulk, pussyfoot, gumshoe ...
Captain ... I'm sensing a ... a powerful mind ...
Something strange on the detector circuits ...
It registers as solid, Captain...
Or an incredibly powerful forcefield. But if we collide with either ...
Go to Condition Yellow. And shut off that damned noise.
Shields and deflectors, up, sir.
Reverse power, full stop.
Controls to full stop, sir.
Now reading full stop, sir.
You are notified that your kind has infiltrated the galaxy too far already. You are directed to return to your own solar system immediately.
That's quite a directive. Would you mind identifying what you are?

We call ourselves "the Q". Or you may call me that; it's all much the same thing. And I have presented myself to you as a fellow ship captain so that you will better understand me. Go back from where you...
Stay where you are!
Data, call medics!
He's frozen. Can you feel the cold?
He would not have injured you! Do you understand this; the stun setting?
Knowing humans as you do, Captain, would you want to be captured helpless by them? Now, go back or you will certainly die!
Is he still alive?
For now. We'll do our best, sir.
Your little centuries go by so rapidly, Captain. Perhaps you'll understand this better.
Actually, the issue at stake is patriotism. You must return to your world and put an end to the communists. All it takes is a few good men.
What? That nonsense is centuries behind us!
But you can't deny Captain, that you're still a dangerous, savage child-race.
Most certainly I deny it. I agree that we still were when ... ... humans wore costumes like that four hundred years ago...

At which time you slaughtered millions in silly arguments about how to divide the resources of your little world. And four hundred years before that you were murdering each other in quarrels over tribal god-images. And since there have been no indications that humans will ever change .....
But even as far back as... ! ... that costume, we had begun to make rapid progress.
Oh? Shall we review your "rapid progress"?
Rapid progress to where humans learned to control their military with drugs.
Sir, sickbay reports that Lieutenant Graham's condition is better.
Concern for one's comrade. How touching.
And now, sir, a personal request. Permission to clean up the bridge?
Lieutenant Worf is right, sir. As Security Chief I can't just stand here and ....
Yes, you can, Tasha.

Ah, yes... better! (deep breath, feeling it) Then later, on finally reaching deep space, humans of course found enemies to fight out there too. And to broaden those struggles.... (indicating Worf and Tasha) .... you again found allies to permit still more murdering and all over again the same old story.

No! The most dangerous 'same old story' is the one we're meeting now! Those who go on misinformation, half-information, self-righteous life forms who are eager not to learn but to prosecute, to judge anything they don't understand or can't tolerate.
What an interesting idea. Prosecute and judge?
And suppose it turns out we understand you humans only too well?
We've no fear of what the true facts about us will reveal.
The facts about you? Splendid, splendid! You are a veritable fountain of good ideas. There are preparations to make, Captain, but when I return...
... we will proceed exactly as you suggest!
Sir... respectfully submit our only choice is to fight. If we Klingons understand anything, it is the meaning of that kind of talk.
My sentiments too, sir. Fight or try to escape.
Sense anything, Commander?
Its mind is much too powerful, sir. And frightening. Concur we avoid further contact if possible!

From this point, no station aboard, repeat no station, for any reason will make use of signals, transmission or intercom. (crossing quickly to Ops and Conn) We'll try to take them by surprise. Inform engineering to make ready for maximum acceleration. We'll find out what this Galaxy Class can do.
Aye, sir.
Records search, Data. Results of detaching the Saucer Section at high warp speeds.
Inadvisable at any warp speed, sir.
Search theoretical.
It is possible, sir. But absolutely no error margin.
Attention bridge crew!

Using print-out only, notify all decks to prepare for maximum acceleration. Maximum, you're entitled to know, means we'll be pushing our engines well past safety limits. Our hope is to surprise whatever that is out there, try to outrun it. Our only other option would be to put tail between our legs and return to Earth as they demand.
Engine room ready, sir.
scene: 27   INT. BRIDGE - ANGLES INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER

quote: The board shows 'green', Captain. All go!
scene: 27   INT. BRIDGE - ANGLES INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER

quote: Stand by... (takes his seat, checks bridge, then) ENGAGE!
scene: 27   INT. BRIDGE - ANGLES INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER

quote: Velocity warp nine point two.
Heading, 351 Mark 11, sir.
Steady on that.
The hostile is now giving chase, sir. Accelerating fast.
We're now at Warp nine point three, sir. Which takes us past the red line, sir.
Continue accelerating. Counselor, at this point I'm open even to guesses about what we've just met.
It... it felt like something beyond what we'd consider a 'life form'.
'Beyond'?
Very, very advanced, sir. Or... Or certainly, very, very different!
Sir, we're at warp nine point four.
Hostile is now beginning to overtake us, sir.
Are you sure?
Hostile's velocity is already warp nine point six, sir. Shall I put them on main viewer?
Reverse angle on viewer.
Magnifying viewer image.
Hostile's velocity now at nine point seven, sir.
Ops, inform Engineering we need more!
Engine room attempting to comply, sir. But they caution us...
Go to yellow alert!
Arm photon torpedoes, Weapons Station. Place them on ready status.
Torpedoes to ready, sir.
That was a design tremor, sir. A warning.
Hostile now at warp nine point eight, sir.
Our velocity is only nine point five, sir.
Projection, sir. We may be able to match the hostile's nine point eight, sir. But at extreme risk.
Now reading the hostile at warp nine point nine, sir.
Attention bridge. Print-out message, urgent, to all decks. (selecting the right words) All stations on all decks, make ready to detach ship's saucer section.
You will command the saucer section, Lieutenant.
I am a Klingon, sir. For me to seek escape while my captain goes into battle....
You are a Starfleet officer, Lieutenant.
Aye, sir.
Note in ship's log that at this startime, I am transferring command to the Battle Bridge. Make the signal, Data.
Captain's log, stardate 42354.1. Preparing to detach saucer section.
... so that families and the majority of the ship's company...
... can seek relative safety while our vessel's stardrive, containing our Battle Bridge...
... and main armaments, will turn back and confront the mystery that is threatening us. Lieutenant, your torpedoes must detonate close enough to the hostile to blind it at the moment we separate.
Understood, sir.
Worf, this is the Captain....
Yes Captain?
Begin countdown.... Mark!
All decks acknowledging, sir.
Starship separation.... six, five, four, three, two, one....
Ship's log, exact moment of separation, stardate 42354.22.
scene: 41   EXT. ENTERPRISE - ANGLES ON SEPARATION MECHANISM (OPTICAL))

quote: All torpedoes have detonated, sir.
scene: 42   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER

quote: Reverse power and hold this position.
scene: 42   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER

quote: Reverse power...decelerating.
scene: 42   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER

quote: That will bring them here in just minutes, sir.
scene: 42   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER

quote: Will we make a fight of it, Captain? If we can at least damage their ship....
scene: 42   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER

quote: Lieutenant... are you recommending we fight a life form that can do all those things? I'd like to hear your advice.
scene: 42   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER

quote: I... spoke before I thought, sir. We should look for some way to distract them from going after the saucer.
scene: 42   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER

quote: All forward motion stopped, sir.
scene: 42   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER

quote: Commander, signal the following in all languages and on all frequencies: we surrender. State that we are not asking for any terms or conditions.
scene: 42   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER

quote: Aye, sir. All language forms and frequencies.
scene: 42   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - INCLUDING MAIN VIEWER

quote: Historically intriguing, Captain. Very, very accurate.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Mid-21st Century, the post-atomic horror....
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: All present, make respectful attention to honored Judge!
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Careful, sir. This is not an illusion or a dream.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: But these courts happened in our past....
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: I don't understand either, but this is real. I can feel that!
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Get to your feet, criminals!
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: At least we are acquainted with the judge, Captain.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Attention! On your feet, attention!
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: You are out of order!
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: The prisoners will not be harmed... Until they are found guilty, of course.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Dispose of that.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Can we assume you mean this will be a fair trial?
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Yes, absolutely equitable.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: (continuing to Mandarin-bailiff) Proceed.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: (refers to his portable viewscreen) Before this gracious court now appear these humans to answer for the multiple and grievous savageries of their species.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: How plead you, criminal?
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: If I may, Captain.... Objection, your honor. In the year 2016, the new United Nations declared that no Earth citizen could be made to answer for the crimes of their race or forbearers.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Objection denied!
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: This is a court of the year 2049, by which time more 'rapid progress' had caused all 'United Earth' nonsense to be abolished.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Tasha, no...
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: I must... ... because I grew up on a world that allowed things like this court. And it was people like these that saved me from it. I say that this so-called court should get down on its knees to what Starfleet is, what it represents...
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: You barbarian! That girl....
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Criminals keep silence!
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: You've got a lot to learn about humans if you think you can torture us or frighten us into silence. Are they still alive?
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Uncertain. Lieutenant Graham was when our medics thawed him out.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: You will answer the charges!
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Or what? Or this, or worse? Or death? I suggest you take a better look at human history.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: You are charged, criminals. How plead you?
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Just a moment ago, you promised "the prisoners will not be harmed." We plead nothing so long as you break your own rules.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: I suggest you center your attention on the trial, Captain. It may be your only hope.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: And I suggest you now may be having second thoughts about this trial! You're considering that if you conduct it fairly, which was your promise, you may lose.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Lose?
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Yes, even though you're judge, and prosecutor....
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: And jury.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Accepted... so long as you keep to your agreement. (indicates Troi and Tasha) And assaulting prisoners is hardly a fair trial.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: This is a merciful court.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: SILENCE!
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Continuing these proceedings, I must caution you that legal trickery is not permitted. This is a court of fact!
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: ... court of fact! We humans know our past, even when we're ashamed of it. I recognize this court system as the one which agreed with Shakespeare's suggestion -- "Kill all the lawyers".
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Which humans did.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Which led to the rule: "Guilty until proven innocent".
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Of course. Bringing the innocent to trial would be unfair. (leaning in; voice amplified) YOU WILL NOW ANSWER TO THE GRIEVOUS SAVAGERY CHARGE AGAINST HUMANITY.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: We'll be happy to answer specific charges. "Grievous savagery" could mean anything.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Obviously it means causing harm to fellow creatures!
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Such as you did when you froze a member of our bridge crew? Will you be joining us in the dock here?
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: You fool. Are you certain you want a full disclosure of human ugliness? So be it! Present the charges.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Criminal, you will read the charges to the court.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: I see no charges against us, your honor.
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Criminal, you are out of order!
scene: 46   INT. "Q" COURTROOM - EMPHASIZING PICARD, DATA, TROI, TASHA

quote: Soldiers... ... you will press those triggers if this criminal answers with any word other than "guilty"...
Criminal, how plead you?
Guilty...
... provisionally so.
The Court will hear the provision.
We question whether this court is abiding by its own trial instructions. Do I have permission to have Commander Data repeat the record?
If this is legal trickery...
Your own words, your Honor. Exactly what followed his Honor's statement that the prisoner would not be harmed?
Yes, sir. The Captain has asked the question... "Can we assume this will be a fair trial?" And in reply, the judge stated...
(continuing in "Q"'s VOICE) "Yes, absolutely equitable."
Unacceptable testimony, entirely unacceptable... !

If your Honor pleases, there is a simple way to clear up this disagreement. (waits until he has "Q"'s attention) We agree there is evidence to support the court's contention that humans have been murderous and dangerous. I say "have been" ... and therefore we will respectfully submit to a test of whether this is presently true of humans.
I see, I see. And you petition the Court to accept you and your comrades as proof of what humanity has become.
There should be many ways we can be tested. We have a long mission ahead of us...

Another brilliant suggestion, Captain. But your test hardly requires a 'long mission'. Your immediate destination offers more challenge than you can possibly imagine. Yes, yes, this Farpoint station will be an excellent test of human worth.
Stand respectfully. All present, respectfully stand!
This trial is adjourned to allow the criminals to be tested.
This honorable court is adjourned!
Captain, you may find you are not nearly clever enough to deal with what lies ahead for you. It may have been better to accept sentence here.
Uh... what is present course, Ops?
It's exactly what the Captain ordered, sir. Direct heading to Farpoint Station.
Confirm we are on that heading, sir.
Know anything about Farpoint? It sounds like a fairly dull place.
Actually, Ops, I've heard just the opposite.
Personal log, Commander William Riker, Star Date 42354.4, at Farpoint Station.
... U.S.S. Hood has dropped me off at Farpoint Station where I await the arrival of the new U.S.S. Enterprise...
... to which I have been assigned as first officer. Meanwhile...
... I have been asked to visit the office of Farpoint Station's Administrator.
scene: 68   INT. OLD CITY CORRIDOR - PANNING RIKER

quote: I thought you might like to know, Commander Riker, that we've still no word from your vessel. But, I trust we have made your waiting comfortable?
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: Luxurious is more like it. Would it seem ungrateful if I ask for some information?
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: Anything!
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: Fascinating how in the midst of an old city like this, you've built a completely modern tritanium and duraglass space station. Your energy supply must be as abundant as I've heard.
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: Geothermal energy is the one great blessing of this planet. I'll have all the details of that sent to your quarters.
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: Thank you. But it still seems incredible how you've built this station so rapidly and so... so perfectly suited to our needs.
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: Would your care for an Earth delicacy, Commander?
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: Well, if there's an apple there...
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: It doesn't matter... what I was saying was... (sees something out of SCENE) Well, I'll be damned!
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: Ah... ah yes, there was another selection here...
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: Zorn, I would have sworn it wasn't here a moment ago.
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: And does your failure to notice it make it unwelcome? The same with Farpoint Station, Commander.
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: We hope a few easily answered questions about it won't make Starfleet appreciate it less.
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: I'm sure it won't, sir. And this is delicious. Thank you. Good morning, Groppler Zorn.
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: Good morning.
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: You've been told not to do that. Why can't you understand? It will arouse their suspicions.
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: ... and if that happens, we will have to punish you. We will, I promise you. We must!
scene: 69   INT. ZORN'S OFFICE - OLD CITY - DAY - ANGLE ON RIKER AND ZORN 69

quote: Doctor Crusher...
Mother, it's Commander Riker.
And hello to you, Wesley. Enjoying Farpoint Station?
Yes, sir.
Saw you and thought I'd join your stroll, if I may.
Actually, we're about to do some shopping.
I've been meaning to visit the mall myself. If I'm welcome?
Of course.
If you're wondering about Mom, Mister Riker, she's isn't actually unfriendly. She's just shy around men she doesn't know.
Wesley... ! (swallows her annoyance; to Riker) I believe that means he would like us to be friends.
I'm willing, Doctor. And although we're not officially part of the Enterprise yet, I thought there might be something useful we could do while we wait.
"Useful"? How and what, Commander?
Investigating some things I've noticed here, Doctor. The last was a piece of fruit...
Would this be available in emerald green?
I'm sure, Commander, there are reasons for a first officer to want to demonstrate his energy and alertness to a new captain. But since my duty and interests are outside the command structure...
Isn't it nice he happened to have the right color?
Thank you. I'll take the entire bolt. Charge it to Beverly Crusher, Chief Medical Officer, USS Enterprise.
Let's see, where were we?
I was accusing you of inventing work in order to curry favor with your new captain. I apologize.
Finding the exact right color took him only about twelve seconds, Mom.
Maybe this is something Jean-Luc Picard will want looked into.
Jean-Luc? You know Captain Picard?
When I was little, he brought my father's body home to us.
Yes, Wes, long, long ago. Shall we continue the walk? I'd like to know you better, Mister Riker.
Where is she? They say she's never late -- not since the old burrhog took over the captain's chair.
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: You wouldn't be talking about the Enterprise, would you, Ensign Markham?
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: Sir. Yes, sir.
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: You can stand at ease, gentlemen. We're not on the Enterprise yet.
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: You know we're assigned to her, sir.
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: Riker. I'm slated to be First Officer. I read the service records on all new personnel on the trip out. Excellent academic record at Starfleet Academy, Mister Markham.
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: Thank you, sir.
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: And you, Mister LaForge. Captain Dreyer praised your performance on the Hood. Why did you request transfer to the Enterprise?
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: Who wouldn't, sir? The biggest, newest, fastest starship in the fleet --
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: Commanded by the best burrhog in the fleet. Right, Mister Markham?
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: Yes, sir.
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: I've already forgotten who used those words.
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: Shouldn't we have heard something from her by now, sir?
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: Commander Riker?
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: Yes?
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: The Enterprise has been picked up on our monitors, sir. I should tell you, sir, it is only the Stardrive Section.
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: What about the Saucer Module?
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: We've received no explanation, sir. But the captain signals that you're to beam up immediately.
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: Our new captain doesn't waste time.
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: A good rule for all of us to follow, gentlemen.
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: Enterprise, this is Commander Riker on Farpoint. Standing by to beam up.
scene: 76   INT. FARPOINT LOUNGE - DAY - ON GEORDI AND MARKHAM

quote: Lieutenant Yar of Security, sir. Captain Picard will see you on the Battle Bridge.
scene: 0    INT. STARDRIVE TRANSPORTER ROOM - ANGLE ON PLATFORM (OPTICCAL)
location: STARDRIVE TRANSPORTER ROOM - ANGLE ON PLATFORM

quote: Battle bridge.
With the saucer gone, can I assume something interesting happened on your way here?
I'll let the captain explain, sir.
We are cleared into the standard parking orbit, sir.
scene: 81   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: Make it so.
scene: 81   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: Commander Riker, sir.
scene: 81   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: Riker, W.T., reporting as ordered, sir.
scene: 81   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: I really didn't expect to welcome you to half a starship, Riker. Is the viewer ready?
scene: 81   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: All set up, sir.
scene: 81   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: We'll first bring you up to date on a little... "adventure" we had on our way here, Commander. Then we'll talk.
scene: 81   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: This way, sir.
scene: 81   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: Message from the Saucer Module. It will arrive here in fifty-one minutes, sir.
scene: 81   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: Inform them we'll hook up as soon as they arrive.
scene: 81   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: Bring him to my Ready Room when he's done there.
scene: 81   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: He calls that "a little adventure"?
scene: 81   INT. BATTLE BRIDGE - ANGLE ON PICARD

quote: Come.
Wow!
Exactly.
This "Q", sir... is he crazy? I mean, seriously?
Seriously, does it really matter how we judge them? We're dealing with something that can juggle starships as if they were pebbles.
It's a rather astonishing "little adventure" you've had, Captain.

The issue isn't what we call it, Commander. The important thing is we can be dead certain... accent on dead... that "Q" wasn't joking. We're alive only because we were placed on "probation", a very serious kind of "probation".
Go.
The Saucer Module is now entering orbit with us, sir.
Acknowledged. Commander Riker will conduct a manual docking. Picard out.
Sir?
You've reported in, haven't you? You are qualified?
Yes, sir.
Then I meant now, Mister Riker.
You say you will be doing this manually, sir? No automation?
As ordered.
Two percent rise. Up angle adjustment three degrees. Maintain docking speed.
Level her out. Maintain docking speed. Docking crew, prepare for reconnection.
All stop. Her inertia should do the job now.
Rejoin lock-up... now.
Enterprise log, First Officer entry. Ship's modules rejoined, stardate 42354.71 with command now transferred back to the main bridge.
Neatly done, sir.
I don't imagine many mistakes happen under Captain Picard.
No sir, they don't.
I'm Lieutenant Worf, sir. Captain Picard requests you come immediately to his quarters.
Come!
A fairly routine maneuver but you handled it quite well.
Thank you, sir. I hope I show some promise.
Some coffee.
No thank you, sir.
And now I have a kind of "what sort of second-in-command have I inherited?" question.
Yes sir, I thought you might.
I noticed in your envelope that Captain DeSoto thinks very highly of you. One curious thing, however, you refused to let him beam down to Altair IV?
In my opinion, sir, Altair IV was too dangerous to risk exposing the captain.
I see. A captain's rank means nothing to you.
Rather the reverse, sir. A captain's life means a great deal to me.

Let me postulate something here, Mister Riker. Isn't it just possible that you don't get to be a starship captain without knowing when it's safe to beam down or not? Isn't it a little presumptuous for a first officer to second guess his captain's judgment?
Permission to speak candidly, sir?
Always.

You've been a first officer yourself. You know that assuming that responsibility must, by definition, include the safety of the captain. I have no problem with following the rules you lay down. But under no circumstances will I compromise your safety. If you have a problem with that, sir, you can put me back on the Hood before she leaves.
You don't intend to back off that position?
No, sir, I can't.
One further thing... a special favor I have to ask of you.
Anything, sir.
Using the same kind of strength you showed with Captain DeSoto, I'd appreciate it if you can keep me from making an ass of myself with children.
Sir?
I'm not a family man, Riker, and yet, Starfleet has given me a ship with children aboard.
Yes, sir. And families...
And I don't feel comfortable with children. But, since a captain needs an image of "geniality" toward the little monsters, you're to see that's exactly what I project.
Aye, sir.
Welcome to the Enterprise, Mister Riker.
Yes sir, Commander?
Thank you, Lieutenant. Is Commander Data on duty?
Commander Data is on a special assignment, sir. He's using our shuttlecraft to transfer an admiral over to the Hood.
An admiral?
He's been aboard all day, sir, checking over medical layout.
Why the shuttlecraft? Can he just beam over?
I suppose he could, sir. But the admiral's a rather remarkable man.
But, sir, the transporter could have you on the Hood in a matter of seconds, Admiral.
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: Have you got some reason to want my atoms scattered all over space?
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: No sir. But at your age, sir, I thought you shouldn't have to put up with the time and trouble of a shuttlecraft.
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: My age? Hold it right there, boy, what about my age?
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: Sorry, sir. If that subject troubles you...
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: Troubles me? What's so damned troubling about not having died? How old do you think I am?
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: One hundred forty-seven years, Admiral. According to Starfleet records.
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: Explain how you remember that so exactly.
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: I remember every fact I am exposed to, sir.
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: I don't see any points on your ears, boy, but you sound like a Vulcan.
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: No, sir. I am an android.
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: Almost as bad.
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: (at a loss, but still respectful) I thought it was generally accepted, sir, that Vulcans are an advanced and most honorable race.
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: They are, boy. They are. And also damned annoying at times.
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: Yes, sir.
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: This is a new ship, boy, but she's got the right name. Remember that.
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: I will, sir.
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: You treat her like a lady. She'll always bring you home... FADE OUT.
scene: 105  INT. ENTERPRISE CORRIDOR - ANGLE AT INTERSECTION

quote: Show me the results of Captain Picard's most recent physical examination.
Already at work, Doctor?
Yes, on a subject that's very important to this mission, Captain. (unhurriedly to computer) Screen off.
I wanted to say "welcome aboard."
Thank you, Captain.
And I thought I should talk to you very personally about your assignment here.
I wanted you to know I protested your posting to the Enterprise.
Oh? Do you consider me unqualified?
Hardly. Your service record shows you exactly the kind of CMO I'd want.
Then you must object to me personally. Has it to do with our last meeting?
I'm trying to be considerate of your feelings, Doctor Crusher. For you to serve with a commanding officer who would continually remind you of such a terrible personal tragedy...
If I had any objections to serving with you, I wouldn't have requested this assignment, Captain.
You requested this posting?
Captain. My feelings about my husband's death will have no effect on the way I serve you, this vessel, or this mission.
Then, welcome aboard, Doctor. I'm pleased to have you here.
Thank you. And now, if I can return to my duties...
Well... as I said, "welcome Aboard".
Have you signaled the Hood, Mister Riker?
Your exact message. Bon voyage mon amie. Aye, sir.
And what was my answer, computer?
